PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
if open not-for-profit health funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament

The petition of citizens of Australia points out that the community deplores the persistent refusal to ban pornography in X and NVE Videos, Films and Publications, and deplores the resulting escalation of crime and sexual crime in the Australian community.
Because Parliament has a direct and heavy obligation to ensure the safety of women and child-victims, your petitioners therefore request the House:
to ban the importation, and availability of pornography in Videos, Films and Publications,
to prevent black-market trading by banning the possession of X and NVE material,
vote against any recommendation to extend Video and Theatre Film Classifications and Guidelines into television standards,
ensure that Pay Television does not exceed the program limits of Television standards,
control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation,

give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This Act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Queensland Disaster Relief Funds
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:

We are concerned that the National Party in Queensland is diverting money given by the Federal Government to the Queensland Government to alleviate natural disasters; that it might not be finding its way to its intended targets; and that it is being diverted to the coffers of the National Party itself or otherwise to expansion projects promoted by members or supporters of the National Party.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray the Federal Government be asked to legislate for an audit of account from the Queensland Government for every dollar or cent provided by the Federal Government for any type of relief operation in Queensland.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows that we oppose any mining or mineral exploration in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.

1. Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park.

2. Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post and Telecom Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
we support the decision of the Federal Government to remove the rate exemption status of Australia Post and Telecom from 1st July 1989;
we are, however, totally opposed to the Hawke Labor Government's proposal to `clawback' from local authorities 90 per cent of the revenue that will be received from levying these rates;

we condemn the Hawke Government for its failure to maintain local government with an adequate level of funding given that total Commonwealth assistance to local government has declined by more than 8 per cent in real terms over the past three years;
we call on the Hawke Government to withdraw their rates `clawback' proposal as part of its contribution to the provision of a proper and adequate level of funding to local authorities.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION (CONVERSION INTO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill amends the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Act 1970 to convert the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC) to a public company, called the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Limited. It will also remove a variety of statutory controls which inhibit SMEC's commercial operations.

The responsible Minister for the Corporation, my colleague, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Barry Jones, will retain strategic oversight of the new company in line with the Guidelines for the Reform of Government Business Enterprises (GBE).

The Bill is a major step in implementing the reform package for the Corporation announced on 17 August 1988 and is part of the Government's comprehensive program to improve the performance of Government Business Enterprises.

It is also a further step to those already taken by this Government in the last five years to make SMEC a commercially viable organisation able to stand on its own two feet and to compete profitably and effectively with the private sector in the international market place.
In taking this route, the Government explicitly recognised:
the Corporation's outstanding international reputation for engineering excellence, particularly in the Asia Pacific region;
SMEC was ranked 62nd in a 1988 world survey of international engineering consulting firms;
its contribution to the export of engineering services
both as a winner of export awards and in assisting the development of the Australian engineering consulting industry through joint ventures and in gaining an overseas track record.
SMEC's head office will remain based in Cooma and the new company will continue to contribute benefits to the Cooma region.

Unlike many other GBEs, SMEC does not have large capital requirements. Its assets lie in human capital and its skills base, as a professional organisation marketing its skills in an international arena.

The Corporation was established under the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Act 1970 to preserve the professional engineering expertise developed during the construction of the Snowy Mountains scheme. Its functions now include investigating, advising on, designing, supervising, maintaining and operating engineering works both within Australia and overseas.
Since 1970 SMEC has completed 1350 projects in 50 countries with a capital value of $4500 million and has earned consulting fees of $294 million.

It has received a capital contribution from the Commonwealth totalling $16.6 million while returning dividends to the Government totalling $3.3 million. In addition it has paid corporate taxes amounting to $11 million, as well as $7 million in State payroll and land taxes and $1.3 million in local government taxes.

The Corporation recorded losses between 1983-84 and 1986-87, but returned to profitability last year as a much leaner totally restructured organisation. In 1987-88 SMEC recorded an operating profit before income tax of just over $270,000 as opposed to a budgeted loss of $1.5 million.
This was a remarkable achievement by the Board and the Corporation and marks the turnaround in the fortunes of the organisation.
The return to profitability is continuing through 1988-89 and it is anticipated that a substantial dividend will be forthcoming from the 1988-89 result.

I want to pay tribute here to the efforts of my colleague, the Minister for Administrative Services, Stewart West, who as the former Minister for Housing and Construction had responsibility for the Corporation until the changes to the machinery of government in 1987. Acknowledgement is also due to the Board of SMEC under the chairmanship of Geoffrey Cook, for its major achievement in bringing SMEC back to profitability. SMEC has already made large strides in directions marked out by the Government's strategy for GBEs.

Since 1983, the Government has made capital injections to fund redundancy packages and provide working capital; amended the SMEC Act to provide greater commercial freedom, and appointed a Board of Directors to give access to a greater range of management talent from the engineering, marketing, finance and trade union sectors.
The Corporation has introduced revised management and budgeting systems, corporate and business development plans and marketing strategies.

A new superannuation scheme was introduced in March 1987 and consideration is at present being given to bringing this new scheme even more in line with schemes presently operating in the private sector.

Other commercial actions taken by SMEC included the disposal of surplus staff housing and adjusting housing rentals closer to market norms, as well as the consolidation of SMEC's operations in Cooma on one site thus eliminating high rental costs.
The reform package is a further significant step and this Bill is a major element, bringing the process of reform even closer to completion.
Other important elements of the reform package are:
revised remuneration arrangements for the Managing Director with the amendment of the SMEC Act contained in the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Act 1988;
revised industrial relations co-ordination arrangements; and,
new planning and accountability mechanisms.
When the nexus was broken with the Public Service Board in June 1986 SMEC came under the umbrella of the Department of Industrial Relations.

Now, under the draft revised arrangements, increased responsibility and autonomy are to be devolved to SMEC but it will be expected to continue to comply with Government wages and industrial relations policies, and with guidelines (yet to be approved) which will specifically apply to:
wages and conditions of employment matters covered by the national wage case principles;
terms and conditions of employment with flow-on implications such as leave, allowances, hours of work and penalty payments;
redundancy and retrenchment conditions;
superannuation as an element of remuneration; and
procedures for handling significant industrial disputes.

New planning and accountability mechanisms include the provision by SMEC of a three-year rolling Corporate Plan. This plan is to be updated annually and is a comprehensive document outlining the Corporation's goals and financial targets, and strategies and actions to achieve those goals. It also includes an assessment of the commercial environment.
The responsible Minister will also maintain strategic oversight of share purchases in subsidiaries and associates, and the establishment of subsidiaries and joint ventures.
Financial targets will be set and SMEC will report annually giving account of performance against goals.

There is at present a senior Departmental officer with observer status at the Board meetings and it is intended that this practice will continue. It is also intended that the current composition of the Board remain unchanged with the present Directors being the initial Directors of the new company pending the first general meeting.

As with any public company SMEC will be subject to its Memorandum and Articles of Association and these will be prepared by the Attorney-General's Department. On behalf of the Commonwealth as the shareholder, the responsible Minister will exercise control in a similar manner to shareholders in any other company. In accordance with the proposed Memorandum and Articles of Association the responsible Minister shall have the power to appoint and dismiss the SMEC Board Directors.
Following conversion to a public company the responsible Minister may, if he wishes, issue policy guidelines to Directors as and when required.

The Bill by making SMEC subject to the Companies Act 1981 has the twofold effect of making SMEC a public company and enabling the removal of many of the statutory controls that have applied in the past and which are inappropriate for a public company.

The requirement to operate in accordance with the Companies Code places on directors responsibilities to shareholders (in SMEC's case the Commonwealth) and other obligations which provide for the protection of the Commonwealth's interests.
It is intended that SMEC start operations as a public company limited by shares and incorporated in the Australian Capital Territory on 1 July 1989.
To summarise, this Bill:
provides for the conversion of SMEC to a public company under the Companies Act;
maintains the corporate identity of SMEC so that all existing contracts, its taxation position and other assets and liabilities are unchanged upon conversion;
provides for all staff to continue employment on their present terms and conditions and preserves all their accrued entitlements;
removes the day to day bureaucratic controls over the commercial decision making processes of the corporation; and,
replaces these with the strictures of the requirements of the companies legislation, and places SMEC on the same footing in this regard as any other public company.

In conjunction with the Bill, mechanisms will be established for strategic oversight of the new company's activities by the Government and to ensure that the company operates within wages and industrial relations policies of the Government.
A major benefit of this legislation is that the company maintains the same corporate entity as the Corporation.

Continuity of corporate entity dispenses with the need to transfer assets and liabilities from the Corporation to the new public company and means that all contracts, agreements, and arrangements entered into by or on behalf of the Corporation which are in force immediately before the transition to a public company will apply to the new company.
This route is the same as that taken by other GBEs such as Australian Airlines and ANL.

The Bill removes controls such as the requirement for the Treasurer's approval for individual borrowing arrangements, and investment and banking arrangements. However, SMEC will remain subject to the Loan Council global borrowing limits and will be liable for the Commonwealth borrowing levy on any borrowings. It will however forego all forms of Government guarantee and will not be able to claim protection from the shield of the Crown.

The Bill also removes the requirement for SMEC to obtain ministerial approval for non project related contracts, and the requirement to have its accounts audited by the Auditor-General. The SMEC Board must seek the responsible Minister's approval to the appointment of the proposed company's future auditor.

The amount of share capital will be fixed under the Bill at a maximum of $5,207,807 which represents the capital contributed by the Commonwealth as at 30 June 1988 less accumulated losses. The capital will be divided into $1 par shares, with all shares to be held, at least initially, by the Commonwealth.

The Bill also allows for shares to be issued at a premium which is to be determined by the responsible Minister. If a premium is determined, there will be a transfer from the share capital account to a share premium account to reflect that premium and the number of shares issued will be reduced accordingly. The purpose of this is to allow for the possible future introduction of a staff equity participation scheme. The share premium account would be necessary to enable the repurchase of shares from the staff as they leave the employment of SMEC.
The possibility of such a scheme is yet to be fully considered by this Government and will not be introduced without prior consultation and agreement of SMEC's staff and unions.

The Bill provides for the conversion of SMEC into a public company in four steps. The first step involves the creation of share capital, and the application by SMEC to the National Companies and Securities Commission to be registered as a company.
When SMEC issues shares, provisions of the current Act which relate to the current capital structure of SMEC will be repealed, by proclamation of the relevant repealing provision in the Bill.
The next step is the transition of SMEC to a public company.

The final step is automatic and ensures that SMEC maintains its present corporate entity. That is, the section of the current Act dealing with the establishment of SMEC is, by force of the Bill, repealed immediately after SMEC becomes a registered company by proclamation of clause 12 of the Bill.
The taxation position of the Corporation is to become the taxation position of the company in all respects including losses.

On transition to a public company each staff member of the Corporation will become an employee of the company on the same terms and conditions as applied to his or her employment by the Corporation. Accumulated entitlements such as long service and recreation leave, and sick leave will be preserved.

The existing provisions covering superannuation will be maintained on transition for staff who are members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. All new staff since the introduction of the SMEC scheme in 1987, are only eligible to join the SMEC scheme.
Those staff who have mobility rights under Part IV of the Public Service Act 1922 will retain those rights.

The Bill also contains consequential amendments to other Acts to ensure that the new company remains subject to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987, and exempt from the Freedom of Information Act 1982. The Schedule to the Sales Tax Assessment Act which identifies those Commonwealth bodies which are not exempt from sales tax will be amended to delete reference to the Corporation. SMEC was not previously exempt from sales tax and as a company it will continue to pay sales tax.

The Bill does not involve additional expenditure by the Commonwealth, nor State and Territory taxes on the transfer of assets as part of the proposed re-organisation of SMEC in recognition of the fact that there will be no change in the Commonwealth's beneficial ownership.

This Bill represents a further step in the Government's program of micro-economic reform in the freeing up of Government Business Enterprises from the burden of detailed day to day bureaucratic controls, but maintaining strategic oversight controls. It is also a further step in the Government's efforts to ensure the full commercial viability of SMEC recognising its unique position as a government owned consulting engineering firm and its leading involvement as an Australian company in engineering consultancy projects in our region.

upon which Senator Macklin had moved by way of amendment in respect of the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988:
At end of motion add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should examine and report upon:

and upon which Senator Hill had moved by way of amendment to Senator Macklin's proposed amendment:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night there was a little confusion, but I understand that the variation which the Australian Democrats made to their amendment was simple to substitute `the Government' for `Attorney-General's Department'. I was in the process of moving our amendment to that, which sought to substitute `the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs' for `the Government'. I hope the Government will not take that as disrespectful, but it happens to be my view that an investigation and report from a Senate committee might well be undertaken more expeditiously. I now regret, as the months have gone by, that clauses 9 and 10 were not referred to the same Senate committee at the end of last year. Had that been the case, the whole of the debate concerning the relationship between the Designs Act and the Copyright Act as they affect those provisions could have been considered in time and with all due effort. The advice of the Senate through its committee system would now be before us. At any rate, that did not happen. If I had a choice I would take that course today, but I know that the Government and the Democrats would not support such a move.

SPEECH.PARA: The third best option is that the Senate express an opinion today that the Committee, notwithstanding the passing of the legislation at the second reading stage, should address its mind to the design questions and report back to the Parliament. If our amendment to the Democrats' amendment is unsuccessful, I would nevertheless like to hear from the Government as to how it interprets the Democrats' amendment which proposes that the Senate express its opinion that the Government should examine and report. Is the Government prepared to indicate that it will accept the advice and prepare a report in accordance with the detail of Senator Macklin's amendment? How long does the Government think it might take to bring down that report? Is it willing to indicate that it will put a report to the Senate so that at least that report can be noted and debated in this chamber and perhaps, if necessary, referred to the appropriate Senate committee for further consideration? But I urge upon the Democrats and the Government that a better choice in this amendment of the Australian Democrats would be to express the opinion that the Senate Committee look at the question rather than simply relying on the Government to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be convenient for the Senate if I indicate that, of course, the Government does not accept Senator Hill's amendment to send the matter to a Senate committee. In relation to Senator Macklin's amendment, it is the intention of the Government to draw on all the resources available to it from within both the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce which has the primary oversight of the patents and designs legislation, which is relevant, along with the copyright legislation, to the particular problems which have been outlined and which need further clarification and consideration as sought by Senator Macklin's amendment. That process will be got under way. As soon as is feasible, a report will be made and perhaps I can table it in the Senate.

These amendments relate to the interaction between the Copyright Act and the Designs Act. One thing I learnt quickly in this place was to count. I realise that these amendments will be unsuccessful because of the agreement that has been reached between the Government and the Australian Democrats. They have, in effect, implemented the first step of that agreement by having carried this morning Senator Macklin's second reading amendment. Nevertheless, I think it is important that I say a few words to outline the reasons why I have moved these amendments and why it would still be our view that they should be carried by the Committee.

We appreciate the concerns of artists and craftspeople as to the deficiencies in the existing law. During the development of these amendments and the debate in the other place, and between the other place and the Senate, there has been a great deal of material supplied to interested senators, and I suspect to other senators, detailing the reasons why, as I said, artists and craftspeople have called for the amendments that are contained within the Government's Bill. There is no doubt that they have suffered as a result of the existing legislation in terms of the ease with which they can lose control of their property which can be used for industrial purposes. I believe that this is explained as well as anywhere in the Australian Copyright Council's bulletin No. 61 on copyright and design law reform issues. This publication looks particularly at the concerns that the artists and craftspeople have had with the section 77 of the Act. The publication states:

Section 77 provides that where work used as a design is industrially applied to articles which are sold, let for hire or offered or exposed for hire, then the artistic work loses copyright protection in relation to use on the type of article to which it has been applied. After 16 years copyright is lost in relation to the use of the registrable design on all articles. Under regulation 17 of the copyright regulations, the design is deemed to be applied industrially if it is applied either on more than 50 articles or to one or more articles manufactured in lengths or pieces.

In short, the effect of section 77 is that if an artistic work is used as a design on more than 50 articles or on one which is manufactured in lengths or pieces, then design registration will be essential. Once an industrial application of this type has occurred the copyright owner can no longer rely on copyright to prevent unauthorised use of the work on those articles.

Not surprisingly, therefore, the artists and craftspeople have wanted to bring protection of their property clearly back within the provisions of the copyright legislation rather than the designs legislation. The deficiencies, from their point of view, of the design protection regime are also detailed in bulletin No. 61. We understand that and we have noted the large volume of recent submissions from a range of artistic and craft bodies throughout the country urging the Senate to pass clauses 9 and 10 as urgently as possible and without variation. Nevertheless, as is often the case in this business, there is another side to the story. In this instance, the other side concerns industrial designs which, it seems to us, will lose protection as a result of the passing of clauses 9 and 10 in an unamended form. We understand that many designs cannot be registered under the Designs Act and although there are technical reasons why this is so, the fact that they cannot be registered has considerable consequences.

There are other reasons why the designs cannot be registered. If a design has features of shape or configuration, by definition it is a design and cannot be registered under the Designs Act. If a design is such that its features cannot be judged by the eye, likewise it cannot be registered. If a design constitutes a method or principle of construction, such a design cannot be registered. This causes us concern and, obviously, also causes considerable concern to those who are in the business of industrially utilising designs and wanting to maintain that protection. It has therefore been suggested that this question of the loss of protection through the interaction of these two Acts in the light of the two new clauses being advocated by the Government should be referred to a Senate committee for detailed consideration, not in any way in an attempt to avoid the extra protection that seems justified to artists and craftspeople, but to avoid what seems to us and to others, including the Law Council, the unintentional consequences. Clearly, the matter has not been referred to a Senate committee and that is regrettable. We came up with a solution which we believed would, in effect, still save the day in relation to those designs. That is basically what is included in the substance of our first three amendments. Our first amendment reads:
Page 1, after subclause 2 (1), insert the following new subclause:

``(1A) Section 10 commences on the day on which a provision amending the Designs Act 1906 commences, being a provision that enables the registration, under that Act, of a corresponding design that in the absence of such a provision, is not registrable under that Act for any reason other than that it is not new or original.''.

We are asking for a delay in the commencement of section 10 until alterations can be made to the Designs Act to provide the protection which we believe is lost implementing these two provisions in their current form. The Minister's second reading speech last night made it clear that the Government will not accept that amendment and the Australian Democrats have indicated that they will not accept it. The deal done between the Australian Democrats and the Government on this issue is rather to pass the second reading amendment, which we did this morning, and refer this designs question back to the Government for further consideration.

It is needless for me to say that the Government in any event should be considering this matter but at least we now have the statement of the Minister this morning that it will do so and that it will report to the Senate, so that the substance of our concerns can be looked at in detail and, if necessary, as I said a little while ago, be again referred to a committee. We regard the matter as urgent and we hope that the Government will treat it likewise.

Other alternatives were open, in our opinion, to achieve the objectives. One was that clause 9 could have been amended to give the protection that was necessary to artists and craftspeople, with only clause 10 referred to a committee for detailed consideration. That was something that I explored with the Australian Democrats' advisers, but they were not of a mind to go down that path.

I am trying to indicate that we were not rigid in believing that the proposition that we put in these amendments is the only way to address this matter. While we believed and still believe that it is the best way, when it became apparent that it would be unsuccessful in this chamber we explored all other possibilities. Unfortunately, it seems to us that the best of those possibilities has been unacceptable to the Government and to the Australian Democrats and that we have no alternative but to rely upon the Government's report, which we can now look forward to under the second reading amendment that has been passed today. It was important for me to move the amendments at least to emphasise our concern in relation to this matter, even though I am prepared to acknowledge that it is somewhat of a fruitless task.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the amendments moved by the Opposition with regard to this item. As Senator Hill has just said, there has been a great deal of discussion on these matters, and the propositions put by the Opposition had, for us at least, an initial attraction. A problem undoubtedly exists in this area. The difficulty in dealing with this legislation is that there does not seem at the moment to be an effective way out without some sort of massive restructuring exercise. Indeed, there is probably not a way out within the context of the legislation. That is why the Senate has sought from the Government, on my motion, a more detailed look at the relationships between items which may be of a craft nature but which may then become a matter of industrial design.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government amendments to the original legislation undoubtedly have a great deal of support in the community. I should like to mention some of them briefly. For example, the Institute of Modern Art has said in its letter to the Australian Democrats:
Clauses 9 and 10 . . . are important for the continued growth of Australia's artistic and cultural life, and will redress an inequity widely criticised . . .

The Australian Writers Guild said that these are truly important reforms which it sees as justified and indeed even conservative. Other supporting groups include the National Association for the Visual Arts; the Aboriginal Artists Agency Ltd; Craft Australia, which, of course, represents a very large number of bodies and has constituent craft councils in every State; and Actors Equity of Australia. One from which I should like to read is from Tiwi Aboriginal Designs, which acts as the agent for the Tiwi people. It has written:
Over the past 10 years the Tiwi Aborigines, who own and operate their own incorporated Screen Print workshop, have had their fabric designs stolen on six occasions to my memory.

On each occasion the law was inadequate to protect them and my company has had to resort to threats of exposure in the press unless a royalty settlement was agreed to. Unfortunately redress outside of the law has been difficult to recover. Their designs have been copied and then imported into Australia from Bali and the USA as well as copied by several Australian companies.

When one considers the commercial worth of many of those designs now, it is extraordinary that that type of product has not been previously protected by law. It seems to us that it is now impossible to go back on the Government's move which has sought to fix up this problem.
The Faculty of Law, for example, at Sydney University, through its lecturer on law, Shelley Wright, on industrial and commercial property, says:

I believe that the failure to pass these amendments, sacrificing the broader issues of fairness to authors and artists to a small sector of industry who would like to maintain a questionable monopoly the Copyright Act was not designed to give them, would be an abdication of the responsibility of Parliament . . .

I am not sure that I necessarily go along with the notion of a questionable monopoly with regard to industrial design. In fact, what we have here, as correctly set out by Senator Hill, is a clash of claims. That is nothing new to those of us who have been working with this legislation. It is an area in which principles clash on a fairly regular basis.
However, the proposition has been put by many other people but probably most clearly by the Australian Copyright Council in a letter to us as follows:

In my letter of 20 March 1989, together with a background paper and other supporting materials, the Council urged that clauses 9 and 10 of the Bill be passed unamended as soon as possible. We did, however, indicate that we would not object to one of the options put by Warman International Ltd. This was that an amended clause 9 be passed alone.
I have discussed this compromise position with officers of the Attorney-General's Department and now agree with those officers that this option is not technically possible.

It was our view at the time that there could possibly be an amended clause 9 that might deal with the issue. We realised, on further reflection, as did the Copyright Council, that this really is not possible. The letter from the Council goes on:
Accordingly the Council withdraws the qualified support it had given to this option and urges that clause 9 and 10 both be passed in an unamended form as a matter of urgency.

I cannot go through the rest of the large number of representations on this issue that have been made around the country. The upshot of the exercise is that although this is not the optimum position which one would like to have achieved, I believe the best course that is open to this chamber at this time is to pass clauses 9 and 10, as moved by the Government, and hope that the Government will look clearly and rapidly at the types of protection that we need in other areas. One of the problems for people working in the industrial design area is that these clauses may not be so attractive. The claws on a dredge are nowhere near as attractive to most people as the Tiwi design, and they may very well have lost out. On the other hand, one should be very clear that what we are talking about in the industrial design area is of significant economic worth to the community. We should not push aside the claims made by the people dealing in the industrial design area. Those claims need to be addressed, and need to be addressed rapidly. The fact that some of those designs could fall outside such protection without anybody knowing about it, and without the person who thought they possessed the design protection knowing that they no longer have it, is a situation which ought not to be allowed to continue, and we need protection in that area as well.

The last point I wish to raise-and I found it extraordinary when I came across it in some discussions I had on this Bill over the last couple of months-is that I was unaware that things such as ratios were able, under the previous operations, to be protected. I found that rather extraordinary. Indeed, I hope that in the general look that we have at this area some of the past practices with regard to copyrighting and protection will themselves be reviewed. It seems to me totally anomalous that one should seek any protection for ratios. The ultimate context, of course, would be that somebody would want immediately to rush out and seek a copyright for pir2 and, hence, tie up absolutely everything to do with anything that is a wheel.

I have in my possession a case involving the protection of a series of ratios. This case happens to affect a number of companies in my own State which deal with the construction of dredgers and the supply of dredgers overseas. They thought that they had a coverage on them, but discovered that somebody else had managed to protect the notion of ratios. I thought that the whole thing was absurd. I then had the opportunity of talking to the person who originally designed the equipment. He assured me that, indeed, the material I was reading was correct-that those ratios had been secured.

I think the area of design registration and protection is one that could do with a great deal of careful analysis, but I must admit that that probably needs to be done in two phases. There needs to be-and I take this to be the implication behind Senator Hill's amendments-immediate protection, because we will face some serious problems if we do not move to some type of protection under either the Designs Act or the Patents Act, or some amendment that we will need with regard to those pieces of legislation. I have not made a study of either of those Acts or the possibility that we will be able to seek some type of immediate protection, but I assume that the Government, in its response today, will be able to indicate that it is already undertaking something along these lines. It is not as though these Bills have landed on us out of the blue. This matter has been the subject of intensive discussions over the last few weeks. I hope that the Government is not waiting for the passage of this Bill before any action is taken. If it does, some of those companies could suffer severe detriment.

Therefore, in not accepting the amendments put forward by Senator Hill, I do not want it taken that we reject the intent behind them. It is just that we feel that the counterclaim is excessively strong. The damage that has been done up to now in terms of that whole area of crafts and artistic productions has been massive, and the Government has at least got that part right. That should be secured, and additional work needs to be done in the other area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the amendments moved by Senator Hill. There is almost nothing that I need add to the response of Senator Macklin which indicates very clearly that we are in something of a dilemma, something of a predicament. It may be that, in protecting artists and craftspeople in a way which has certainly earned their plaudits-and that is perhaps the principal objective of these provisions-there is a gap, some small area of difficulty in the relationship between the copyright and designs areas, which, nevertheless, is proving extremely difficult to bridge.

SPEECH.PARA: The registration system under the Designs Act is regarded as one of the broadest in the world, I am told. I think it was implemented in 1981 under a previous government. It was recognised then as securing a great expansion of the range of designs capable of registration. If a product does not qualify for registration under that wide system of registration, it is arguable that it may not be appropriate at all. This is one of the matters which ought to be looked at. It will be looked at in terms of the second reading amendment which has been accepted by the Government.

The type of protection which might be offered by the Copyright and Design Acts, or by some amalgam of the two, or by some new methodology, is of such importance that the committee that meets within the government structures ought to have before it not only the formal terms of reference but also a transcript of the full debate carried out in this chamber. The comments by Senator Hill and Senator Macklin will be most helpful in putting the context and flavour of what might otherwise be a fairly arid set of terms of reference. I believe that the concerns that have been expressed will be taken into account. That is certainly my intention.

The removal of copyright protection for three-dimensional industrial articles, which is what we are really talking about, may mean that manufacturers will be free to manufacture an article if upon searching the appropriate industrial property register the article is not covered by, for example, patents or design protection. But in so far as the manufacturer will be free to manufacture an article without the risk that there may exist a design in which copyright subsists, then I believe that the manufacturing sector will be aided. At least this was the view, as I understand it, of the 1973 Franki Copyright Law Committee on Reprographic Reproduction, which reported on this copyright designs interaction problem.

The Government does not believe that the passage of these clauses ought to be delayed pending amendment of the Designs Act to enable registration of designs not presently registrable under that Act. But I undertake that the full Hansard transcript of the comments made by Senator Hill and Senator Macklin will be part, effectively, of the terms of reference of the committee to be set up within the Government to provide the report to the Senate which has been sought.

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite the Minister also to refer the Law Council's advice, of which the Minister no doubt has a copy, to whatever subcommittee within government which is to address this problem. It is a helpful document. Obviously, the Law Council has done a lot of worthwhile work in this area. Private sector expertise should be used as much as possible in an effort to find the best resolution of this difficulty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee would be disadvantaged if it relied simply on the speeches of Senator Robert Hill and Senator Michael Macklin. As Senator Hill made that modest admission himself, it might be best if the advice to the committee were supplemented by the submission of the Law Council of Australia. I will ensure that that is done.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Clauses agreed to.
Proposed new clause 10a.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a suggestion to the Committee for dealing with this matter. Two of the proposed new subclauses in our amendment No. 4 deal with the subject of media monitoring. They would become sections 103c and 103d of the Act. If it is the wish of the Senate I suggest that we should deal with those two before moving to the third one, which is on a slightly different issue.

—It is our intention to move an amendment to proposed new clause 10a, but it is currently being drafted. We have spent about a week and a half drafting it and it is still coming out of the mall somewhere. Our approach is slightly different from the approach in Senator Hill's amendment. Would it be possible to move on to subsequent items and come back to this matter when our amendment is available? It would seem to be better to have a composite debate on a variety of approaches that might be able to be taken to this matter. In the absence of our amendment for a statutory licence it would not make a great deal of sense to complete this debate and come back to it at a later stage.

—Senator Hill, is it acceptable to defer consideration on your proposed new clause 10a to a later stage in the debate? At the moment there is a single amendment covering proposed new sections 103c, 103d and 103e. Do you wish to move part of the amendment now? I thought Senator Macklin's suggestion was that we should defer consideration of proposed new clause 10a, get on with the remainder of the Bill, and then come back to proposed new clause 10a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed new clause 10a deals with three matters. Two matters relate to media monitoring, and I understand that those are the matters which Senator Macklin wishes to be deferred and which he is addressing in the form of another proposed amendment. The third matter deals with a different subject, fair dealing for the purpose of research or study which would become a new section 103e in the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: CHAIRMAN-And you would like to pursue that now?

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the Committee could deal with that amendment at this time. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 5, after clause 10, insert the following new clause:
``10a. After section 103b of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:
Fair dealing for purpose of research or study

`103e (1) A fair dealing with an audio-visual item does not constitute an infringement of the copyright in the item or in any work or other audio-visual item included in the item if it is for the purpose of research or study.

`(2) For the purposes of this Act, the matters to which regard shall be had in determining whether a dealing with an audio-visual item constitutes a fair dealing for the purpose of research or study include:
(a) the purpose and character of the dealing;
(b) the nature of the audio-visual item;
(c) the possibility of obtaining the audio-visual item within a reasonable time at an ordinary commercial price;
(d) the effect of the dealing upon the potential market for, or value of, the audio-visual item; and
(e) in a case where part only of the audio-visual item is copied-the amount and substantiality of the part copied taken in relation to the whole item'.''.

I do not wish to speak at length on this amendment, which will create a new section 103e of the Act to provide for fair dealing where an audio-visual item is to be used for the purposes of research or study. As I understand the position at the moment, this would be a breach of copyright. In this instance we have adopted a submission from the vice-chancellors of this country who have advocated that audiovisual items should, as much as possible, be treated in the same way as the written word. It seems to us that this is a logical extension. It provides for fair dealing, not an open slather. These matters in principle were set down in the principal legislation when technology had not developed as far as it has today. In fact, one of the great challenges of copyright legislation is to reflect the pace of change in this area.

Anyone engaged in research or study would be well aware of the importance of audiovisual material. It is not surprising, therefore, that principals of colleges of advanced education and vice-chancellors of universities in this country have come to the Parliament seeking the updating of the copyright legislation to include this provision, which would allow such protection as to enable research and study to be conducted with the use of audiovisual material without the fear of infringing the existing copyright law. As I have indicated, we adopted their submission and we bring this amendment to the Parliament for its consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty with the amendment proposed by the Opposition is that the introduction of such an exemption for fair dealing for research or study cannot be easily justified. In conjunction with the overall scheme for remunerated copying, such as the proposed educational television copying licence, we believe that it provides potential for abuse. This is especially so in the audiovisual area where the technology is peculiarly adapted to the making of copies of entire works.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1986, when we introduced exemptions for fair dealing with audiovisual materials for purposes of criticism and review and reporting news, we refrained from introducing a provision to allow fair dealing with audiovisual items for research and study. I believe that, in the overall context of the Bill, that approach should be retained in the Act that we are trying to put together now. We cannot see this provision being easily slotted in. In fact, we think it is incompatible with the framework of remunerated copying that we think is an important principle to establish in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not able to follow the Minister's brief comments. We certainly feel that there is a difficulty here. As I understand it, the current arrangement that has been agreed to still does not allow a person to make a copy of an audiovisual item. In other words, it falls under the general scheme. Audiovisual items are not treated differently from printed material. There is already a fair dealing provision for individuals for the purposes of research and study. I have some difficulty coming to grips with the notion that we need to make a special exemption, as I had originally thought that this was included in the legislation. Is the Minister of the view that that is included? Can he simply outline in general what individuals would be required to do if they wished to use audiovisual material for the purposes of research?

—I am advised that, if people wish to make use of audiovisual material, they have to seek the permission of the copyright owner, or purchase it, the remuneration being made available to the copyright owner. In other words, the whole scheme is designed to ensure that the copyright owner is remunerated for the use made of his or her creative talent by the student or the researcher. That is the scheme that underlies the approach in this legislation to the audiovisual area.

-The Minister is saying that audiovisual material does not differ in any way from printed material. Given the bulk of some of this material and given the removal of the provision concerning the detailed keeping of copies and so forth that has been quite sensibly arranged, a person is able to make a copy of a page of an article for the purposes of a quotation in, say, a term paper that he is writing. I assume that that is on a par with a person making a copy of, say, a photograph for the purposes of inserting that into a term paper. If I am wrong, we may need Senator Hill's amendment. I assume that Senator Hill in his amendment is saying that that is not the case. I am trying to seek clarification from the Government that that is the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Committee knows, there is a fair dealing for criticism and review in relation to audiovisual copying. As for the question of the single photograph, I am not sure that I can provide a straightforward answer at the moment. I am advised that section 40 of the present Act would allow fair dealing with a single photograph or a small item such as that. Section 40 (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: A fair dealing with . . . artistic work . . . for the purpose of research or study does not constitute an infringement of the copyright in the work.
Section 40 (1) of the Act should cover that situation.

TALK.START.PARA: -That is how I had understood it. I wonder whether Senator Hill would like to respond by saying which particular area he felt was not covered. My understanding is that the ways in which most students and researchers would use audiovisual material have been covered in much the same way as has printed matter. Obviously Senator Hill, by way of his amendment, believes that there is still a significant area which is not covered by fair dealing. I am still somewhat at a loss as to which areas Senator Hill is referring and which he feels are not adequately covered. If he still feels that there are such areas, as his amendment appears to suggest, it may be that we need to deal with them. I am still trying to come to grips with understanding which particular area Senator Hill is now aiming at. I felt it related to most of the items, other than, for example, a total reproduction of a film, which I fail to see as being necessary for the purposes of research. Under the normal processes, one could view the copy of the film obtained by an educational establishment for study purposes. I am trying to visualise in my own mind which part of the audiovisual area Senator Hill has in mind that he does not feel is covered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 40 of the Copyright Act 1968, as the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has indicated, allows fair dealing `with a literary, dramatic or artistic work, or with an adaptation of literary, dramatic or musical work, for the purpose of research or study' without infringement of the copyright in the work. The Act sets out the matters to be taken into account in determining whether the usage of that material is so limited. These matters are set out in proposed new section 103e (2), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this Act, the matters to which regard shall be had in determining whether a dealing with an audio-visual item constitutes a fair dealing for the purpose of research or study include:
(a) the purpose and character of the dealing;
(b) the nature of the audio-visual item;
(c) the possibility of obtaining the audio-visual item within a reasonable time at an ordinary commercial price;
(d) the effect of the dealing upon the potential market for, or value of, the audio-visual item; and
(e) in a case where part only of the audio-visual item is copied-the amount and substantiality of the part copied taken in relation to the whole item.'.''.
That adopts the type of language used in section 40 (2) of the principal Act.

I think the answer is involved in the interpretation of the word `work'. As I understand it, there are limitations as to how that has been interpreted. It was the view of the Vice Chancellor's Committee that section 40 as a whole has not been interpreted sufficiently widely to allow usage in this form for audiovisual items. It might be helpful if the Minister were to say to us that this practice is more useful than it used to be, and that the court will be directed to take into account the learned advice of the Attorney-General in these matters that, in the view of the Government `work' should be interpreted sufficiently widely to include audiovisual items. It might also be changing the law; I am not sure about that. I look to the definition of `work' in the existing Act and I see that it means:
a literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work.

That does not advance my argument far at all. Therefore, I presume that one needs to go one step further and look to the precedents. The Minister no doubt is on top of those, having sitting alongside him a team of advisers. No doubt he will tell us whether `work' has been interpreted by the courts to allow audiovisual items of the type that we propose to include in this proposed new section to be permissible under the existing regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is that an audiovisual thing is not a work but is a subject matter other than a work. The fact is that the single photograph of which Senator Macklin spoke that could be incorporated in a paper having been copied, would qualify as an artistic work, at least in theory.
—It would?

—A single photograph. But a video tape, record or some sort of broadcast material are regarded as subject matters other than works. A student could go into a university library or media resource centre, or whatever they are called these days, and view a film, listen to a broadcast or a tape recording, or play a record or whatever, and that would not infringe copyright. Obviously there is no copying being done. But once a copying is undertaken of this subject matter other than a work covered by section 40 (1), then it is felt that the creative person who contributed to that film, tape or record or whatever it might be, should receive some remuneration. I have already pointed to the proposed educational television copying licences as an example. There is also some potential for abuse which must be recognised. I believe that, in conjunction with this comprehensive idea that the creators of works should be remunerated for their creativity, the proposal put forward by Senator Hill does not sit with the scheme which the Government wishes to see put into the law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not at all sure now that I am as clear about this as I was when I started. I thought I had a reasonable handle on what the audio- visual exercise was. The Minister's explanation has now made it a murky area indeed. What we are talking about in the audio-visual area could encompass an enormous range. The Minister is now saying that some of those are works. In other words, certainly a single photograph is a sole artistic item and could be treated as such. It could very well be a work. But a longer item-for example, a broadcast-is not. There are a number of crossover areas. I want to be clear in my mind that these are not included. An example is microfiche. In other words, I presume that a microfiche of printed material is dealt with in the same way as the printed material. I believe it is; at least until this debate started I believed that that was the case. I presume that reproduction of printed material in an audio form is treated as the printed material. In other words, we have within our universities, colleges of advanced education and technical colleges the ability to provide for blind people and others printed material in an audio form. I understand that that is not being treated as audiovisual material; I hope it is not. My understanding was that it would be treated in its original form as a printed material.

SPEECH.PARA: Excluding all of those-I would like the agreement of the Minister that my interpretation of those particular items is correct-we are then looking at a number of other categories. I am still somewhat worried that a copy or a copy of a part is not allowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is allowed but you have to pay the creative component.

—I had assumed that copying of a part by a student for the purposes of studying was something which in fact came under the fair dealing. I must admit that, if it does not, I would lean much more towards Senator Hill's position than I did when I started. It seems to me that there is an excellent argument which relates to students studying. Let us say that a student is required to make to a tutorial group a presentation with regard to the causes, say, of the Second World War and he finds in the audiovisual area some early German material on the rise of Hitler. The student may wish to take a copy of part of it to play back in the tutorial room. I think that is the type of example that Senator Hill was referring to. It seems to me to be a perfectly permissible exercise. It is not for the purposes of circumventing copyright. It will not do a detriment to anybody. It is, in fact, for the purposes quite specifically of research and study. The quality of the reproduction will probably be sufficient for the tutorial room but for no one else. In other words, I had assumed that the use of parts of a copy, in terms of the audiovisual material, would be dealt with in the same way as the use of part of an article or a small portion of a book.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister is not able to assert that that is the case, I must admit that I would want to support Senator Hill's position. Seemingly what he has done is to diagnose more correctly the situation than I have done. I had assumed that those normal operations were in fact simple fair dealing. If the Minister cannot clarify that, I will have to indicate support for Senator Hill's amendment on that ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin asked, first, what might count as subject matter other than works. If he looks at section 85 and those that follow he will get some idea of the definitions of sound recordings, cinematograph films, television broadcasts and sound broadcast. Obviously, that is the area that we are talking about. It falls outside the fair dealing provision of section 40 subsection (1) and following provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: It also should be noted that, under the blank tape royalty scheme, students may copy sound recordings. That will be able to be undertaken in that particular area. We are talking about the need to provide a system. We are talking about an overall system that, so far as possible, allows to be properly remunerated the creative endeavours of a person who puts something down, for example, let us say, on film.

In relation to the educational institution environment and so on, one has many students who obviously have access to libraries where videotapes, film material and television broadcasts are stored on tape. One of the factors which have led to the decision not to have a fair dealing provision inserted in the clause is the problem of abuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has it been specifically addressed or is it just one of these areas that has yet to be considered?
—It has been thought about.
—Who has been thinking about it?

—We have been thinking about it, Senator. I am using `we' in the larger sense, not referring to me specifically, up to this moment. The fact is that, where one has the technology available to allow students to copy videos that are of interest to them, even apart from their tutorial assignments, one has the situation where possible abuse could occur. There is a potential there which would lead to great difficulty in monitoring the copy that has been made to provide for a three-minute presentation to a tutorial group as opposed perhaps to obtaining a video of a favourite program for enjoyment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is in that context and in the overall context of trying to ensure that those who make these films and contribute to their production that it is important that they be remunerated for any copying of their work. The Government believes that the sorts of situations which Senator Macklin has pointed to ought to be met by some contribution from the educational institution concerned for the creative endeavours that have gone on behind that particular production.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply remind the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that protections currently exist in subsection (2) of section 42 to avoid abuse of fair dealing in relation to works and that, similarly, we are including protection in subclause (2) of our proposed section 103e. I really do not think that the argument about abuse-the Minister used the example of someone taking a videotape of a favourite program home for entertainment-has any merit at all. It seems to me that what is occurring is a development of technology and that, when the Act was drawn and passed, work was then looked at as matters of a fixed form, if I may so describe them. Now, of course, if we are looking at educational research purposes, which is what we are talking about, there is now available material of a different nature. One such type of material is that which we describe here as audiovisual. This aspect certainly is of concern to the educational institutions in this country, otherwise they would not have brought it to our attention and the Government's attention. They are simply asking that the law be updated to reflect the new technology, not that it be extended in some way as to go beyond the scope of the fair dealing provisions that exist in relation to works. I guess another way of doing it would be to expand the definition of works. The Opposition has done it slightly differently by specifically seeking to insert a parallel clause which deals with audio-visual items. This is simply another technique of achieving the same objective. Surely it ought to be carried unless there is something that fundamentally distinguishes an audiovisual item from one of these other forms of more traditional fixed work. I must say that I have a great deal of trouble personally distinguishing-if I might respectfully use Senator Macklin's example-between a slide and a small piece of a video tape. It seems to me to be very much of the same nature. I cannot see why one should have the benefit of fair dealing provisions in the Act and the other should not as it relates to research and education being undertaken within our institutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that if honourable senators had a look at section 103a they might find some scope there for a fair dealing with an audiovisual item. The section states:

SPEECH.PARA: A fair dealing with an audiovisual item does not constitute an infringement of the copyright in the item or in any work or other audiovisual item included in the item if it is for the purpose of criticism or review . . .

It is suggested by my advisers that in relation to the sort of situation which Senator Hill had in mind where matters are brought in to a tutorial group and thrown up on the screen for the purposes of criticism and discussion of that particular item, then that might indeed provide a dealing which did not infringe copyright. As I say, the main argument is that with the type of material we are dealing with-the audiovisual material and the copying of whole works which otherwise should be remunerated in order to benefit the producers, the authors, the creators of those particular works the potential for abuse is such that we do not believe that Senator Hill's amendment ought to be carried because it goes against the whole aim to ensure that those who produce these works receive a fair remuneration for their effort and endeavour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that it was a good effort. However, it does seem to me an extraordinarily long bow to suggest that we are dealing with the item of criticism or review. I know that lawyers are very creative, but it seems to me that if one were selecting a piece of material for criticism or review it would be with regard to that material. Senator Hill has been talking about making use of audiovisual material for purposes of study and research which may not have anything to do with the intrinsic merits of the particular material that one is using, but one is using it to amplify, illustrate, spell out or clarify some other matter. I think it is extraordinary that in the Act a reviewer has the ability to escape any problems if he happens to say that this is a nasty bit of work. If he says that a restaurant is cooking in a particular way and he ends up with a defamation, that is his problem. If a person says that this particular film is a pretty trashy piece of work, then people will be able to copy it and look at it at leisure. But if a person wishes to use part of that work for the purposes of illustrating, for example, the manners of a particular period, then that is not fair dealing. I accept the proposition of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) of the protection of copyright. It might very well end up on a restriction of knowledge rather than anything else.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that Senator Hill is perfectly correct in suggesting that the world is moving on and that more material is likely to be found in forms other than on the printed page. On the basis of this discussion, when I first came into the Parliament, I thought that this matter was covered. I now find the point that I thought was adequately covered is certainly not adequately covered and I therefore express support for Senator Hill's amendment because I think that it does cover that area. I do not think that the Minister should be too concerned because Senator Hill has made it very difficult with his proposed new section 103e (2). One has to hurdle items such as the purpose and character of the dealing; the nature of the audiovisual item; and the possibility of obtaining the audiovisual item within a reasonable time at an ordinary commercial price which means that it would rule out most of the items the Minister has referred to. In other words, his favourite program is down at the local video store at a reasonable price-generally $1 or a couple of dollars to hire. We are probably only looking at those items which are not commercially available, which are held only in collections and which are quite specifically held for the purposes of research and study. On that basis I indicate that the amendment that Senator Hill has put together, in the light of the Minister's answer, is a very reasonable and a very moderate one. I would have thought that the Government could very well wear that without too much problem at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst there is a certain amount of sense in what is being put by the Opposition, and supported by Senator Macklin, I think that one has to try to put oneself in the place of the producer of a videotape which has perhaps some educational merit or even is produced specifically for use by students or by those involved in making use of libraries in tertiary institutions or even in the general library system for their own edification rather than for a particular course. If one created a situation where the continuous copying of that particular video did not attract some sort of remuneration to the producers and creators of that particular work--
—We are not talking about that.

—I think the honourable senator is talking about that. He said that if it is copied by students in the library on one of these machines, then they need not pay any remuneration to the copyright owner. In that situation we could be depriving a producer of such a work of the incentive actually to produce it because the simple single sale to the University of Tasmania, for example, might not produce sufficient remuneration to justify the expenditure involved in putting together such a video. If it is used by a number of students who copy it, then I do not see why they should not make some contribution to enable the producer to get back and to make a profit on the considerable work that has gone into putting together that educational videotape. It is really that sort of situation that I think we ought to be keeping in mind if we are trying to create an industry-this has been, quite rightly, pointed out by Senator Hill-which embraces a new technological method to make this sort of material available in a way which is absorbed more readily because of its more interesting presentation by students. Really I think that is the final comment I would make in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the debate further, but I just draw the Minister's attention to placitum (d) where we specifically say that the effect upon the dealing and the potential market is to be taken into account. I think I should stress that in moving this amendment we are not in any way wanting unreasonably to limit the remuneration of those who provide the works, the base material. In fact, when the Minister looks at the next set of amendments that we are about to move, he will find that in the normal situation of copying audiovisual material we want to bring that within a licensing regime that provides not only access but also fair remuneration to those who have property in the material.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now leave the remainder of Opposition amendment No. 4, by agreement, and go on to the remainder of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Page 5, clause 12, proposed section 135a, lines 37 and 38, definition of `collecting society', leave out the definition, insert the following definition:
`` `collecting society' means a body that is, for the time being, declared to be a collecting society under section 135b;''.
(6) Page 6, clause 12, at end of proposed section 135a, add the following new definition:
`` `television broadcast' includes an audio-visual item within the meaning of section 135b.''.
(7) Page 6, clause 12, proposed section 135b, lines 21 to 27, leave out proposed section, insert the following section:
Audio-visual items
``135b. In this Part:
(a) a reference to an audio-visual item is a reference to sound recordings, cinematograph films, television and broadcasts;
(b) a reference to a broadcast includes a television or sound broadcast and includes any work, sound recording or cinematograph film included in that broadcast;
(c) a reference to the making of a copy of an audio-visual item is a reference to the making of a copy of the whole or part of that item.''.
(8) Page 6, clause 12, proposed subsection 135e (1), lines 41 and 42, leave out, ``or in any work, sound recording or cinematograph film included in a television broadcast,''.
(9) Page 7, clause 12, proposed subsection 135f (1), lines 27 to 29, leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsection:
``(1) The copyright in a broadcast is not infringed by the making of a preview copy of the broadcast.''.
(10) Page 7, clause 12, proposed subsection 135f (2), line 30, leave out ``television''.
(11) Page 11, clause 12, after proposed section 135n, line 19, leave out the heading ``Division 3-The collecting society'', insert the heading ``Division 3-Collecting Societies''.
(12) Pages 11 and 12, clause 12, proposed section 135p, line 20 (page 11) to line 3 (page 12), leave out the proposed section, insert the following section:
Collecting societies

``135p. (1) Subject to this section, the Attorney-General may, by notice in the Gazette, declare the body named in the notice to be the collecting society for all relevant copyright owners or for such classes of relevant copyright owners as are specified in the notice.

``(2) Where the Attorney-general declares a body to be the collecting society for a specified class of copyright owners and subsequently declares another body to be the collecting society for that class of copyright owners:
(a) the first-mentioned collecting society ceases to be the collecting society for that class of copyright owners on the day on which the subsequent declaration is made; and

(b) any remuneration notice given to that collecting society ceases to be in force to the extent to which it relates to licensed copies of works or other subject-matter the copyright owners of which are included in that class of copyright owners.
`(3) The Attorney-General shall not declare the body to be a collecting society unless:
(a) it is a company limited by guarantee and incorporated under a law in force in a State or Territory relating to companies;
(b) all persons who are included in a class of relevant copyright owners to be specified in the declaration, or their agents, are entitled to become its members;
(c) its rules prohibit the payment of dividends to its members; and

(d) its rules contain such other provisions as are prescribed, being provisions necessary to ensure that the interests of members of a collecting society who are relevant copyright owners or their agents are protected adequately, including, in particular, provisions about:
(i) the collection of amounts of equitable remuneration payable by administering bodies under section 135h or 135j;
(ii) the payment of the administrative costs of a collecting society out of amounts collected by it;
(iii) the distribution of amounts collected by a collecting society;
(iv) the holding on trust by a collecting society of amounts for relevant copyright owners who are not its members; and
(v) access to records of a collecting society by its members.

`(4) Where the Attorney-General has declared a body to be the collecting society for a specified class of copyright owners, the Attorney-General may refuse to declare another body to be the collecting society for that class of copyright owners unless satisfied that to do so would be in the interests of those copyright owners, having regard to the number of members of the first-mentioned society, the scope of its activities and such other consideration as are relevant.''.

The Opposition's amendments Nos 5 to 12 all deal with the one subject matter, that which I just mentioned to the Minister, the extension of the provisions that are included in the Bill relating to copying of television material to cover other mediums of communication such as audiovisual material. I again indicate that the amendments have resulted substantially from representations of the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals in Advanced Education.

Technology has moved on and the Government, a little more slowly than some, at least in the amendments which it put before the Committee today, caught up with the value of television in this area. So it has in its amending legislation new part Va, which deals with the copying of television broadcasts by educational and other institutions. The Vice-Chancellors' Committee is particularly interested in the educational aspect of this matter. It suggests to us and to the Government that, whilst extension into the area of television is to be applauded, we should seize the opportunity to encompass other areas of audiovisual communication. We have adopted that proposal and put it before the Committee today.
