Whether it concerns for example, the copying of original radio material or existing audiovisual material, there seems to be an argument that within educational institutions it is worth while.

As we all know, we have already overcome the debate that there should be proper remuneration to those who have property in the original material. Why not provide a remuneration regime similar to that which is proposed by the Government in relation to television for these further extensions of communicative vehicles? By means of these amendments, we put that before the Committee. We define audiovisual items to include sound recordings, cinematograph films, television and broadcasts. Most of the amendments that follow are of a supplementary nature. However, we recognise that by bringing in other types of material we may well create a need to divide the collecting societies. In other words, it may not be possible to get a single collecting society for interested owners; it may be necessary to divide the society into a number of collecting societies. We do not seek to set that form in concrete. My colleague Senator Puplick might wish to make some comments on that also. We seek to provide some flexibility in that regard.

We certainly press upon the Committee the wisdom of updating these provisions to include other methods of communication, particularly radio broadcasts. We cannot see any logical reason why the copying of published audiovisual material should not be included, as has been sought by the vice-chancellors and the directors and principals of advanced education bodies, provided that fair remuneration is included within the scheme for the owners of the intellectual property. That is the rationale of the amendments that we put to the Committee. We submit that they are logical extensions, that they have merit in the same way the previous amendment-which, I am pleased to say, the Committee adopted-had merit. I therefore commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators will know, the scheme put forward in the Bill for the consideration of the Senate relates to television broadcasting only and not to radio because it was impressed upon us that this was the area of greatest need and an area in which new technology can clearly be used in schools for teaching purposes. We ought to catch up with that clear fact.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as radio broadcasts are concerned, section 200 (2) of the Copyright Act already provides a workable exemption, enabling educational institutions to copy broadcasts intended for educational purposes. In addition, new section 200 (2a) will provide that it is not an infringement of copyright in a radio broadcast to make a copy of the broadcast for educational purposes. Educational institutions have impressed upon us the need for a wider scheme to allow for radio broadcasts perhaps to be subject to a statutory licensing scheme. Their main interest is in the schools broadcast-type material and that, as I say, is sufficiently covered and permitted to be copied under section 200 (2).

We have already covered some of the ground with respect to audiovisual items. It may be thought that now there is a provision for fair dealing with audiovisual items for research or study, the sort of scheme that is now being put forward is not required. If the other place agrees to our amendments, we will have permitted that audiovisual material which is used for study purposes-within the various qualifications and in the ways suggested by Senator Hill's amendment, which has been accepted by the Committee-to be exempted from the provisions of the Copyright Act concerning the need for remuneration. In that situation, to go any further and put in the sort of scheme that Senator Hill has in mind is unnecessary. It is the claim of Senator Hill that his amendment for fair dealing will not discourage copyright owners from producing educational audiovisual material. I hope that is the case, but I think we should rest with the amendment we have passed, if it is accepted in the other place, rather than go on to put together the major and elaborate scheme which Senator Hill proposes here.

Some drafting matters also appear somewhat unusual, for instance, the end effect of the definitions offered by Senator Hill. The honourable senator said that a television broadcast includes an audiovisual item and an audiovisual item includes a sound recording. So it ends up with a television broadcast including a sound recording. I do not know that that is necessarily unusual in the annals of the drafting of legislation. It is one of the oddities that ought to be pointed out to the Committee.

My real point is that radio broadcasts, such as the school broadcasts which are a very important part of the work of educational institutions, are sufficiently covered. I believe that fair dealing with audiovisual materials has already been provided for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a brief comment on one of the aspects of the Opposition amendments which are before the chamber at the moment. Opposition amendment 12 deals with collecting societies per se and proposes to leave out proposed section 135p in the Government's legislation and substitute a new proposed section 135p. The rationale for this has been covered in a large part by the comments that Senator Hill has already made on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to draw attention to one particular aspect of our proposed new section 135p, subsection (4) of which provides in effect for the establishment of more than one collecting society for this purpose. It will be seen that, in the Government's Bill, proposed new section 135p (2) provides:
The Attorney-General shall not name more than one body in a declaration and shall not make a declaration while an earlier declaration is in force.
In other words, only one collecting society can be declared at any particular time. Proposed section 135p (4) reads:

``(4) Where the Attorney-General has declared a body to be the collecting society for a specified class of copyright owners, the Attorney-General may refuse to declare another body to be the collecting society for that class of copyright owners unless satisfied that to do so would be in the interests of those copyright owners, having regard to the number of members of the first-mentioned society, the scope of its activities and such other considerations as are relevant.''.
In other words, it provides that it is at the discretion of the Attorney-General to declare that there may be more than one collecting society for the purposes of this part.

I wish simply to make the comment that collecting societies exist in a number of areas which are provided for within copyright law. They exist in relation to the photocopying of material, the broadcasting of music and various other aspects. There is only one collecting society in each of these areas and those persons who are copyright owners are really put on a take it or leave it basis in respect of the operations and activities of those collecting societies.

Some societies have operated very well. I have no complaint, for example, about the way in which this has tended to operate in relation to music broadcasts and rebroadcasts. But, on a number of occasions, the owners of copyright have complained to me that the activity of their collecting society is unsatisfactory, that, as clients, they are dealt with in an unsatisfactory fashion and that they have absolutely no redress because the Government has created, as it were, a statutory monopoly for undertaking these activities and only one society operates in this particular area.

Under the Government's proposed new section 135p (2), there would in fact be a single collecting society. The Government endorses the monopoly position and those people who are not satisfied with the way in which that operates would not have any redress and the Attorney-General would in effect have to abolish one collecting society and establish a new single collecting society if the society simply did not perform its functions properly. Our amendments suggest that there could be the situation in which it would be advantageous to the owners of copyright to have more than one collecting society which might in fact do slightly different things and be responsible for slightly different aspects of the very broad scope of activities that this new section in the legislation is to cover.

I would value the Minister's explanation on one matter. I am interested to know the extent to which the Parliament-not the Attorney-General, the Auditor-General or some other officer-is kept informed of the work and activities of these collecting societies. I do not want improperly to anticipate a matter in debate, but it will be seen that, in relation to the proposed reports that are to be forwarded to the Attorney-General dealing with the administration of the blank tape levy, which comes under Part Vc of the legislation, the Opposition's proposed amendment 17 requires that the report that is to go to the Attorney-General be forwarded by the Attorney-General to the Parliament.

There are too many instances creeping into legislation in which reports by bodies whose existence is dependent upon the will of the Parliament are sent to Attorneys-General, to officers or to Ministers, but are not then forwarded to the Parliament so as to allow the Parliament to undertake some scrutiny or some observation of the activities of the organisation for whose creation the Parliament has been responsible. I should value the advice of the Minister for Justice on the extent to which the Parliament is kept informed of the operations of the collecting societies. It seems to me that some of them end up lodging reports with State corporate affairs commissions or similar bodies rather than lodging them with the requisite Federal Minister or department.

Frankly, it is very difficult to get hold of copies of annual reports of collecting societies to see how they have administered their operations, discharged their statutory responsibilities and how much money they have spent on their administration as distinct from forwarding it to the owners of the copyright on whose behalf they are supposed to be acting. That is a very unsatisfactory way of going about things. There needs to be a far greater degree of reporting back to the Parliament about the operations of these bodies. In this instance, particularly given the extended scope which Senator Hill, on behalf of the Opposition, has proposed for the operation of this whole area, there ought also to be the possibility, in a legislative form, of the Attorney-General designating more than one organisation to be a collecting society for the purposes of this part, because he has to be satisfied, in the terms of our amendment, that it would be in the interests of the copyright owners for that to be undertaken, having regard to the requirements that are set out in the Opposition's amendments to which I have been making reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the clause about reporting to parliament?
—That was in relation to the blank tape area.
—Collecting societies having to report to parliament?

—That is correct. I was referring there to our proposed amendment No. 17, which relates to the requirement in the Government's legislation to the forwarding to the Attorney-General of a report on the operation of the blank tape levy. Our amendment would require the Attorney-General to then forward it to the Parliament. We are simply establishing the principle quite clearly that Parliament ought to be directly provided with the information. The matter I was raising with the Minister was the mechanism by which the Government believes that the Parliament can scrutinise the activities of the collecting societies. Why is it that reports of collecting societies which have been established by parliamentary enactment are not immediately available to Parliament, even in the sense of being tabled as, for example, the reports of administering authorities under bounty legislation are tabled? For example, the annual report of the Bounty (Books) Act, which shows the distribution of money under that Act, at least keeps Parliament informed. I think there are also provisions under the Public Lending Right Act for that sort of information to be readily available to Parliament. It does not appear, however, that Parliament has equal access to material which arises as a result of the operations of collecting societies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -We are dealing with a variety of amendments together. The one concerning television broadcasts is interesting. By and large, the Government's reference to a television broadcast covers all things broadcast on television, including, for example, a cinegraphic film. Senator Hill proposes that we expand that, by means of his amendment, to include other areas and any work, including a cinegraphic film. There are difficulties here because there are two quite distinct areas. The principle of being able to copy from a television broadcast is quite different from the principle of being able to copy a film.

SPEECH.PARA: A television broadcast is one which, at some time, has gone to potentially every member of the public. In other words, by whatever commercial mechanisms now available it is possible to broadcast a particular film to literally everybody, so that everybody has a chance to see it. Hence, one can say that such a broadcast of a film has exhausted the market. Indeed, as I understand it, in terms of the commercial potential of new films, there has been a significant discussion within the commercial television context as to which part of the market is exhausted by showing a film on television. That consideration partly influences the way in which prices are set for a variety of films. That is quite different from any broadcast of any film on its own which never, theoretically or practically, exhausts the market. That fact is taken care of in a commercial context by the cost of the hire of a film for showing to a limited audience in a theatre or elsewhere.

As the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) alluded to by way of reference to the radio, the use of many television broadcasts by educational institutions is by way of the easy method of copying directly from the broadcast. In fact, it is almost beyond the financial means of every school in Australia to hire most of the films which are currently released, except when they have film nights and show films which almost pre-date the beginning of cinema and whose prices are reduced to a level which schools can afford to pay.

I am worried by Senator Hill's amendment, which seems to broaden the definition. I am not at all sure whether this is intended because he still seems to be intending that a television broadcast be an audiovisual exercise. Amendment No. 6 means that we are adding, at the end of proposed section 135a, in a definitional context, that `television broadcast' will now include audiovisual items. He is then going to leave out section 135b and insert:
. . . a reference to an audio-visual item is a reference to sound recordings, cinematograph films, television and broadcasts;

My reading of that, and I may be wrong, is that it seems not to link films any longer to their broadcasting on television, but to have them standing on their own. I do not know whether that was the intention of Senator Hill's amendment. I hasten to say that I am not a lawyer, but my reading of it is that Senator Hill's intention was to include it with television broadcasts. However, as drafted, it seems to pull it out from that inclusion. I could not support that second proposition because, as I have just argued, I see them as being in two different contexts-two quite different markets and two quite different commercial operations. In the proposed amendment to section 135b, Senator Hill seems to take it back within that category by saying:
. . . a reference to a broadcast includes a television or sound broadcast-
presumably here we are talking about radio-
and includes . . . film included in that broadcast.

That is a reiteration of the Government's proposition, and takes it back into the same category. Senator Hill might be able to disabuse me of that, but that is my reading of his amendments at the moment. I could not support dealing with a film in that way because it seems to violate the whole basis upon which the copyright exercise is being proposed.

The next item, which Senator Puplick spoke about, is the revamping of the collecting societies. His passionate appeal for more than one collecting society arises, no doubt, from his desire to have competition in this area. I would not necessarily want to argue against that, except to say that the area is still a relatively new one, and I am not convinced by what Senator Puplick said, namely, that there is a need for duplication in that area. I accept the point he made that it is a dramatic exercise when one wishes to go from one society to another, but it may be that the very drama of that exercise-in other words, the winding up of the whole collecting society and handing it over to somebody else-should be more vigorously used to pursue those aims that Senator Puplick quite rightly raised. That is, the clients of the collecting society ought really to be the ones whose satisfaction those collecting societies should be seeking to provide. Where people are not satisfied, it seems to me that the Attorney-General may need to be somewhat more responsive. I am not persuaded that there is a need at this time for any more than one collecting society in any one area. After considering the material that has been provided to me, and some of the things which Senator Puplick has said, of which we have had notice, while there has been some dissatisfaction, I am still not persuaded that that dissatisfaction is likely to go away because there are two societies. Much of that dissatisfaction has arisen from the novelty of the situation and the need for these people to bed themselves down.

Senator Hill's amendments would significantly enhance the possibilities of the collecting societies being able to perform the tasks that they are being asked to perform. I should have thought that it might be appropriate to allow that to stand and to review this at some later stage, rather than seek now to provide for more than one society. Once we do that, there are other problems that emerge pretty rapidly. At least, at the moment, we know that a collecting society has exclusive control of an area. If it does not have exclusive control, what does it have? Much as Senator Puplick may wish to make work for the bureaucrats who draw up regulations, I think that this could end up being a technical nightmare. I do not want to lend our weight to that particular proposition at this time.

I think that the points made by Senator Puplick do have validity inasmuch as the clients of these collecting societies are the ones whose interests should be addressed. I wonder whether or not there is a mechanism within the Attorney-General's Department to receive complaints of this type. Perhaps the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) will be able to inform the Committee that this mechanism is working and still working well. On the basis of those points, I am unable to support the amendments proposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might deal first of all with the question of the collecting societies, because I think that Senator Puplick has made some points which, in so far as they have validity, can better be addressed by the Parliament at this stage in the evolution of the role of collecting societies of these sorts. From the point of view of users of these materials there is merit in an educational institution, for example, knowing that there is only one society to which it has to make payments. There is the simple question of administrative convenience, which ought to be looked at. Of course, there is also the question of the attitude of the clients, the users, the copyright owners. As I understand from the advisers, those people are quite happy, generally speaking. No complaints have been received by them though, obviously, proper representations have been made by some to Senator Puplick. On the whole, copyright owners themselves seem to be satisfied with the scheme of the single collecting society which is proposed. Clause 135p provides:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) The Attorney-General shall not declare a body to be the collecting society unless:

(d) its rules contain such other provisions as are prescribed, being provisions necessary to ensure that the interests of the collecting society's members who are relevant copyright owners or their agents are protected adequately, including, in particular, provisions about:
(i) the collection of amounts of equitable remuneration payable . . .
(ii) the payment of the administrative costs of the society . . .
(iii) the distribution of amounts collected by it;
(iv) the holding on trust by the society of amounts . . . and
(v) access to records of the society by its members.

Those are important provisions, which give some protection to the copyright owners in relation to the collecting society. Though it is not necessary, because the Democrats are not supporting Senator Puplick in this regard, I think that it might be advantageous, since this is the Committee, to make a concession, in parliamentary terms, to the honourable senator. In relation to the annual report and accounts there is a provision in clause 135r which states:

`The collecting society shall, as soon as practicable after the end of each financial year, prepare a report of its operations during that financial year and send a copy of the report to the Attorney-General.
Perhaps amendment No. 17 could be adapted. I might propose an amendment after proposed new section 135r, perhaps a new clause (1a). I propose later to move:

`(1a) The Attorney-General shall cause a copy of the report sent to the Attorney-General under subsection (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the receipt of the report by the Attorney-General'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just add it to proposed new subsection (1), after the word Attorney-General.

—Well, possibly. It may be that the Clerk can make some adjustment at the conclusion of the committee stage. In principle, what I am signalling is that at the committee stage it might be useful to have a provision inserted concerning action by the Attorney-General on receipt of the report. Clearly, the first report of the collecting society would be of interest to the Senate. Members would be interested to see how it was beginning to work. It would provide an occasion for debate and for a review of the work of the collecting society. I understand that the amendment that I have moved is likely to receive support.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the more substantial matters in the bundle of amendments moved by Senator Hill, I think that many of the points made by Senator Macklin are valid. I wish to emphasise that I think that, now that we have-if it is accepted in another place-a provision which allows for fair dealing, by students in particular, in a range of audiovisual materials, we have made a sufficient concession to the diminution in the remuneration that might otherwise be available to the producers of these audiovisual materials. The further step that Senator Hill has suggested is not necessary, and I do not believe that we should put in jeopardy the growth of this particular very important industry within the educational framework. Of course, the necessary remuneration for the very high costs associated with the production of these videos must be kept in mind if we are to allow for their growth and development in this country. For that reason also, I agree with Senator Macklin that the Opposition's proposal, in its substantive parts, as opposed to those relating to the collecting societies, should also be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had some discussions with the Australian Democrats on this matter. As I understand it, they have sympathy for our position, as it extends the provisions contained in the Government's Bill dealing with the copying of television broadcasts to include copying of radio broadcasts. That is logical, because there is no real distinction, from the point of view of an educational institution, between the natures of those media. They are similar, in that, once they go out, they are lost, unless they are copied and obviously, therefore, become very useful resources within educational institutions. The Minister sought, in some way, to distinguish radio from television by reference to section 200 (2) of the Act, which he said provided an existing capacity for the institutions to copy radio broadcasts.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty is that that capacity to copy is limited to broadcasts that were intended to be used for educational purposes. So they had to have been intended to be used for that purpose at the time they were made-a matter which is not, of course, within the mind of the educational institution. Furthermore, it has got to be the intention of the broadcaster, not any objective test, as to whether a broadcast has educational or research merit. In other words, what the Minister says is correct up to a point, in that there is a very limited exemption in the existing Act. But it is limited, and in a way that makes it very difficult to be used effectively by the educational institutions. I need to stress that there is no attempt in these amendments to avoid the need to pay to the owner of the copyright proper recompense for the owner's work. That is what we do; we set out a structure for payment. The Minister might concede that we are being more consistent with the previous position he argued today when he said that the owner is entitled to payment. As I read section 200, it does not provide for payment at all. So the educational institutions have come to us and said, `Radio is logically the same as television. Give us the capacity to copy it for the benefit of our students and we accept, consistent with the theme of the legislation, that the owner of the copyright is entitled to recompense'.

That is one of the subject matters with which we have dealt in this series of amendments. We have attempted to incorporate within them the second subject matter that was raised under this heading by the vice-chancellors-that is, the copying of already published audiovisual material. As I understand it, the position of the Australian Democrats is that they would not accept that amendment at this time for the reasons that Senator Macklin has outlined. Therefore, it would seem to me to be sensible to split the matters that we have included in our amendments. I think it can be simply done but I need to ask for a suspension of the debate on this provision, in the same way as one other amendment earlier in the day was left for a later hour this day, in order that I might effect these simple changes, which I hope will enable at least that part relating to radio broadcasts to be passed by the chamber this day.

I reiterate that is a useful reform. It is a further progression. It is consistent with the theme that the Government has put before us in terms of television. Perhaps the Government has failed properly to appreciate the limitations of section 200 of the existing Act. No doubt it would wish to be consistent and I cannot see any logical argument why the Government, in being consistent, would not support the extension to radio for educational institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek clarification on that point. Senator Hill is saying that certain educational institutions have pressed this upon the Opposition.
—The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee has pressed it not only on the Opposition but also, I presume, on the Government. It is just that we have addressed the matter and the Government has not.
—I am told that the matter of radio has not been put to the Government by the vice-chancellors.

—I draw the Minister's attention to a letter to the Hon. Lionel Bowen, MP, Attorney-General, Parliament House, Canberra, ACT, dated 17 November 1988, which specifically presses this matter upon the Government. I regret that the Minister's advisers are shaking their heads. We have only a copy of the letter.

—I still want to know whether the effect of the Opposition's amendment will be that those schools which presently take broadcasts at 9.00 or 10.00 in the morning, or whenever school broadcasts are done for educational purposes, and which presently are not subject to the requirement that payment be made, will be brought into the Opposition's scheme so that the many schools throughout Australia that make use of educational broadcasts, schools broadcasts and so on under section 200 will have to make a payment. Are they amongst those who have sought to do this?

—We are not seeking to limit the effect of existing section 200, which deals with a selective form of broadcasts-the ones the Minister has been talking about-the school-type broadcasts which are clearly under the educational channel and for educational purposes. We are attempting to deal with that mass of other material which may have educational benefit as recognised by the educational institutions but which does not come within section 200. We say that there should be a capacity to copy that material upon the payment of an appropriate fee. That is the nature of the extension that we are seeking.
—So within the Opposition's scheme the present section 200-type provision would remain and that would be an exemption?
—Yes.
—I understand it somewhat better now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before this chamber determines whether it will defer consideration of these matters to a later hour to facilitate my colleague's sorting out the two parts of his amendment, which is before this chamber, I would like to respond to the Minister's comments regarding collecting societies. I simply thank the Minister for accepting the suggestion that the Attorney-General shall cause the reports which are forwarded to him to be presented to the Parliament. I believe that it is an important matter of principle simply to keep the Parliament properly informed of reports of this nature so that those who are interested in observing how the obligations of the collecting societies under the legislation are being discharged will be able to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not press the matter of the authorisation or declaration of more than one collecting society. I think the position of the two sides on this matter has been adequately canvassed. Senator Macklin has clearly indicated that the Australian Democrats do not support the establishment of more than one collecting society in the field we are dealing with at the moment, but I thank the Minister for having taken up the suggestion about the reports being provided to the Parliament. I think it is greatly to his credit that he is prepared to be flexible on this matter and to accommodate us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

``(1a) The Attorney-General shall cause a copy of the report sent to the Attorney-General under subsection (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the receipt of the report by the Attorney-General.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (13) Page 18, clause 13, after proposed subsection 135zj (1), insert the following new subsection:

``(1a) Notwithstanding any of the provisions in subsection (1), the copyright contained in a periodical publication is not infringed by the making of one or more copies of the whole or a part of that article by, or on behalf of, a body administering an educational institution if the copying is done for the purpose of supplying the material to persons undertaking a correspondence course, or an external study course, provided by the educational institution, for the teaching purposes of which the copies are made.''.
(14) Page 18, clause 13, at end of proposed subsection 135zk, add the following subsection:

``(2) Notwithstanding any of the provisions in subsection (1), the copyright contained in a published anthology of works and comprising not more than 15 pages in that anthology, is not infringed by the making of one or more copies of the whole or a part of that work by, or on behalf of, a body administering an educational institution if the copying is done for the purpose of supplying the material to persons undertaking a correspondence course, or an external study course, provided by the educational institution, for the teaching purposes of which the copies are made.''.
(15) Page 19, clause 13, after proposed subsection 135zl (1), insert the following new subsection:

``(1a) Notwithstanding any of the provisions in subsection (1), the copyright contained in a literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work (other than an article contained in a periodical publication) is not infringed by the making of one or more copies of the whole or a part of that work by, or on behalf of, a body administering an educational institution if the copying is done for the purpose of supplying the material to persons undertaking a correspondence course, or an external study course, provided by the educational institution, for the teaching purposes of which the copies are made.''.

These amendments deal with the familiar question of external students. I say it is a familiar question because I think even the Minister will concede that the Government is being lobbied on this question. Certainly the Opposition, and I have no doubt the Australian Democrats, have been lobbied by educational institutions throughout the country, including the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals Ltd, and also by individual institutions. One that immediately comes to mind is the Roseworthy Agricultural College in South Australia. This fine institution, which has a proud record, has some small external student capacity. I understand that it offers in the external mode a graduate diploma in agriculture and in natural resources. It makes the point that all these institutions have made, and that is that it operates within a tight budget and fears that the Government's changes to this legislative framework will result in greater costs to it which, in one form or another, get passed on and are therefore a disincentive to students.

The interpretation of the Government's amendments, which has been accepted by the educational institutions, is that they remove the exemption that currently exists for external study students. Therefore, the materials which are essential to the operation of external studies and which need to be copied and forwarded to students would come within the full copyright payment regime that is otherwise provided within the legislative framework. They were exempted before for sound reasons. I refer to the economic stress that is placed on students because of distance from education facilities and the importance of as much as possible putting those students in the same positions as those who live within cities and have much easier access to educational bodies. It is an exemption, and there is no way of running away from that. One can understand some disappointment on the part of the copyright owners at any form of exemption. I am aware that there is some disappointment in respect of the exemptions that are given to parliamentarians under the existing Act. But as there was merit in that argument, there appears to be merit in the argument that external students should receive an exemption.

As I understand it, that argument was found to have merit and was advanced in the report of the Franki Copyright Law Committee on Reprographic Reproduction which was referred to earlier in debate today by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). We have accepted the representations made by the educational institutions in this regard. Therefore, we bring to this Committee amendments 13, 14 and 15. Each of the three amendments covers the same subject matter, the first dealing with periodical publications, the second with anthologies, and the third dealing with literary, dramatic, musical and artistic work. But the scheme of each is the same. Persons undertaking a correspondence course or an external study course provided by educational institutions are to be exempted in respect of copies made for teaching purposes. In other words, the copying party is not infringing the Act by taking copies in a limited form which can be used for the educational purposes.

As I understand it, it has been argued that we should try to equate as much as possible the position of a student in a city, who has access to library facilities and who already has the advantage of section 49 of the existing Act, with that of external students who do not have that same privileged position under the Act. Therefore, this is an attempt to try as much as possible to treat them equitably. I commend the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I spent some time in the second reading debate dealing with the issue of external students. We believe that the people who produce this material should not have to bear the costs involved with assisting somebody who is disadvantaged by living in an area that is remote from the institution in which he is studying. Obviously there is a problem in this area. The Opposition has moved some amendments and I also have an amendment. I believe that this matter needs to be dealt with in some form. I have proposed a fair dealing on a literary work which, I admit, does not go as far as the amendment moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Other than for lecture notes, which I shall come to in a moment, it would be seen as fair dealing for an external student to ask someone to make a copy of relevant material which an internal student would be able to make a copy of. In other words, external students would be allowed to use copies for the purposes of study that are obtained from university, college or institute libraries. The reason that we have gone this way and not the way followed by the Opposition is to try to get some type of correspondence between the two. I noted at the end of Senator Hill's comments that he also is seeking the same type of exercise.

My preference would not be to go down the track of my amendment either-in other words, that the Government would pick up the tab. However, I am mindful that we would be dealing with the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). I must admit that I am somewhat daunted by the prospect of trying to get him to agree to such an exercise in regard to external students. It is important in a country such as Australia to examine this area.

My hope is that the distance education sector of our educational establishments will be far more highly developed than it is at the moment. It seems to me that it is the one area that is so obviously useful for Australia. Being a nation with a small population on an enormous land mass, one would think Australia would have had one of the most highly developed distance education sectors in the world. That is not the case. We have a very poor record in this area despite the brilliant work that is done by the people who currently operate within it. Most of them are operating with often inadequate resources and in outmoded facilities with very cramped conditions. They do an heroic task in the worst of circumstances.

When one looks at the problems of external students one is met by two things. The first is that unfortunately in Australia we are still largely relying upon paper. We are not using other electronic methods of communication to a very great extent. There is work being done. Some work is being coordinated, for example, by the universities and colleges of advanced education in a cooperative way to look at this particular problem. But they are not getting very far. In 1989 it seems to me that we should not just be starting; we should have the thing up and running. When we are looking at external students we find that one of their major problems is access to the library and, within the library, access to journals. In relation to the problem of access to the library, if we take the example of books, an enormous proportion of the cost of running external studies is carting very large volumes around the country through Australia Post. People would be surprised at the weighty tomes that fly around this country. That obviously is an absurd wastage. At the moment there is no more efficient way to do it unless some funds are put in for more electronic methods by which students could access the libraries, particularly journals and books.

Secondly, students who study externally confront an even worse situation when they come to the problem of journals. Even internal students cannot borrow a very large number of journals that are currently available in our tertiary institutions. The reason for that is that journals are a very expensive part of the library. Libraries have cut back again and again on the number of copies. To keep a complete list they almost have to make sure that those copies of journals never leave the library precincts. Under those circumstances an external student is massively disadvantaged in terms of current information. We need to look at that area and how to deal with it. On the one hand the rights of the person who has written the stuff must not be overriden in order to pick up a community disadvantage. On the other hand the right of external students to a fair operation needs to be addressed.

Our method has been one of fair dealing. I am not quite sure which method the Government wants. Can I suggest it will have to have one or the other? I would like an indication as to which particular unlikely horn the Minister wishes to impale himself upon. I have worked through this issue for quite some time now. I must admit that I cannot see any other reasonable way. I have tried to limit my amendment to a form of literary works because the current context happens to be literary works for external students. I have left out lecture notes, as I say, because they are a particular exercise, as those people who have had anything to do with distance education would know. It seems to me that the lecture notes context is one that would be inappropriate because they are produced in the numbers that are necessary for the number of students. With the new context, many of those lecture notes are the precursors to more significant publications. As lecture notes are run off and provided to the students as part of the course they are undertaking, it does not seem that they need to be included here. It could even create a significant literary disadvantage to many academics if they were included.

All other works, however, of a literary nature would be included as part of a fair dealing operation. I imagine the way that this would work would be simply that the student would ask somebody, probably the external librarian in the institution in which they are studying, to make a copy for them for the purposes of research or study. In other words, to be a third party to do the fair dealing that an internal student would be able to do as they are on campus and these students are off campus.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin has referred to external students to some significant extent. I want to raise the question of blind students in part under this section and, more particularly perhaps, under section 5, blank tapes. Blind students certainly need most of their resources on tape so that they can listen to them in the form that has just been referred to. More particularly, I raise the question of blank tapes so that material can be read on to tapes for them. I have in mind a particular student that I have dealings with and speak to. Her family is spending vast sums of money on having material translated into braille and read on to tapes. Her family has to purchase the tapes and also has to pay somebody to do the reading if they are not able to do the reading themselves. There was some mention earlier of the Blind Society of Australia or institutions. My particular concern is for the parents purchasing tapes for blind students.

—I cannot quickly find part Vb of the proposed new Act which deals with blind students. Proposed new section 135zp deals with multiple copying of works by institutions assisting handicapped readers. It is a very long section. I know that it deals with braille and other matters. It is a bit difficult to do it on the run. Perhaps we may look at that over the lunch hour.
—I merely wanted to mention blind students in the context that Senator Macklin has. I merely refer to the fact that I would like an answer on that when the Minister gets to part Vb as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will ensure that that is done. In relation to the question of copying for external students, what the Government has in mind, of course, is meeting many of the problems that have been adverted to by Senator Macklin. Senator Macklin pointed to the disadvantage suffered by external students and their inability perhaps to take advantage of the fair dealing provisions under the Act. I think that is what he was getting at. The Government had in mind that under proposed section 153c (3) of the Bill, which is inserted by clause 17, it would enable the making of regulations to allow the Copyright Tribunal to have regard to various matters in setting copying rates.
—I cannot find it.

—It is a regulation-making power; that is all it is. I want to describe the sort of regulation that the Government has in mind. We have in mind that the Tribunal would be able to consider discounting the royalty rate payable by institutions for copying for external students to the extent that the copying could be properly described as equivalent to fair dealing copying. This would avoid the possibility of any abuses that might occur if there were an outright exception, which is more or less directed to Senator Hill's proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal will be better placed, after examining samples and circumstances of copying by institutions, to assess how much of that copying could be realistically characterised as what external students could have done by way of fair dealing had they had access themselves to the material copied. It may turn out, in other words, that educational institutions will pay no more for copying for external students than they do at present. However, a benefit to educational institutions under the new scheme is the ability to operate under a much more streamlined and cost-efficient system from the point of view of their administration. As we know, the present system is pretty chaotic. Thus the new scheme offers clear advantages to educational institutions that should not be lost sight of. The needs of the copyright owners, which I think Senator Macklin is conscious of, are also protected in this way, but the task would be given to the Copyright Tribunal to perhaps, as I say, set a differential rate or discount the royalty rate payable by institutions for copying for external students when it has made an assessment, as it is best placed to do, of the sorts of materials which are called upon by tutors, supervisors or teachers to be made available to their external students. We believe in that way that many of the problems that have been identified and rightly emphasised by both Senator Hill and Senator Macklin may properly be met. I might think about this over lunch.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some difficulty in distinguishing between what the Minister has just said and what Senator Macklin has said, except the comments made by the Minister are more complicated. Both the Minister and Senator Macklin are aiming for a fair dealing arrangement, but the Minister is attempting to set a task for the Tribunal of which I have trouble appreciating the detail. I am trying to envisage what tests the Tribunal is to take into account to determine what is a reasonable remuneration. It may be that something obvious has escaped.
—What right would it have to do that? I find it very odd.

—The body we are talking about, the Copyright Tribunal, is a specialist body. It is very competent in this field and has the expertise. It can take evidence and it can find, for example, in New England that most of the material being sent out to students-let us say 85 per cent of it-is the sort of material that an internal student sitting in the library would have access to under a fair dealing provision. If it had made that determination then it could set an appropriate royalty rate for the institution to pay.
—Surely it is reasonable to assume that all the material would be available to the student who had access to the library?

—I have made that concession. It may turn out that that is the case, but I think it gives greater certainty and assurance anyway to the copyright owners that their interests are not going to be somehow overridden by the Parliament without the sort of expertise that could be brought to bear by a copyright tribunal looking at the actual situation institution by institution.

—I appreciate that the Minister is trying to come to the same conclusion. I defer to his knowledge since he was the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I am just wondering upon what power one might be able to make a regulation which would run against the explicit provisions contained in the legislation. Will the Minister decide whether an amendment to that effect might be a more appropriate way to go? Like Senator Hill, I find it very difficult to envisage upon what grounds one would make that exemption because potentially, as Senator Hill said, the entire library is open to an internal student. What students use is really up to them. Potentially none of the library is available to the external student. We are trying to actually bring them together. I am not sure upon what grounds anybody is going to make a decision. The external student could want anything and seek anything that is in the library.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter that I think the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) should explain to the Senate. It arises from a press release which was put out by the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) on 3 May 1989 with respect to the future use of the athletic stadium, usually known as the National Outdoor Stadium, at Bruce. For a long time it has been the Government's intention to make this facility available as a rugby league stadium for the Canberra Raiders. Certainly I-like many others in Canberra-am pleased at the concept of developing the facilities to enable the Raiders to be a more effective team. They are an important asset to Canberra. At the same time, I am extremely disappointed that in doing so the Government intends to destroy the international standard athletics facility at the stadium. I cannot see why it is not possible to develop each of these facilities and retain the athletics stadium.

SPEECH.PARA: However, that is not the only aspect of the matter I wish to raise today. In the press statement put out by the Minister two days ago, he referred to the fact that the chartered accountants firm Price Waterhouse has been engaged to negotiate the financial agreement with the Raiders. Further down in the statement it would appear that the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Administration will be leasing the facility to the Raiders:
It is proposed that the ACT Administration will lease the Stadium from the Australian Institute of Sport and negotiations on the terms and conditions of the lease are well advanced.

The statement refers also to the fact that the Institute's athletics warm-up track will be upgraded to a national standard facility. What I want to ask the Minister is: Who owns the National Outdoor Stadium at Bruce and who will be leasing it to the Raiders? That is important for the people of Canberra to know. The stadium was originally established by the then Minister, Mr Ellicott, as a national athletics facility. As I understand it, the stadium has been retained as a Commonwealth facility and remains so under the Department of the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It has been managed by the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS).

It is my recollection that when Mr Brown was Minister for Sport he intended that there should be a leasing of the facility, that he wanted to obtain a lease for the Institute from the Department of Administrative Services but that the arrangements for the National Capital Development Commission to define the actual boundaries of the facility were never completed and so discussions between Mr Brown and Mr Uren, the then Minister for Administrative Services, did not result in the lease being issued to the AIS. So I was somewhat intrigued when I saw in the Minister's press statement that the ACT Administration will lease the stadium from the Institute. At the beginning of these arrangements one of the stumbling blocks was that the AIS did not have a lease and so could not issue a lease to the Raiders, as it thought it might have done as part of the early negotiations. The question is: When did the AIS obtain the lease of the stadium from the Department of Administrative Services?

We all know that Commonwealth facilities are purpose-built and that when they are no longer to be used for that purpose they revert from whoever has had the use of them to the Department of Administrative Services. I think that is covered by the Lands Acquisition Act 1955. That has happened recently as, we all know, with the provisional Parliament House. It no longer being used for the purpose for which it was built, it has reverted to the custody or care of the Minister for Administrative Services. It is my view that the stadium is still a Commonwealth asset. The Minister's press release states:
It was essential to make these decisions prior to the establishment of the ACT Government to make sure the momentum of the project was maintained.

Is this asset, having been transferred by some means or other to the ACT Administration, going to appear in the financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the ACT Government as a debt owing by the ACT to the Commonwealth, as will be the case, for example, with the Googong Dam and other facilities which are going to become the assets of the ACT? Is this a Commonwealth-owned facility; how did it get into the hands of the ACT Administration; is it a gift, or is it a capital asset which is being transferred? It is very important that answers to these questions be given. If it is a gift, I would then go on to ask, `What are you going to do, Commonwealth Government, about facilitating the ACT to get an Australian football team based in Canberra? The ACT Australian Football League is most anxious to do so. It has elaborate plans drawn to develop the Phillip oval as a suitable venue for Australian football in the national league. Will it be given the same sort of assistance to develop that facility? Will the Cannons, in time, be given the same sort of assistance to develop a stadium which will hold more than the 5,000 people whom they now attract to the indoor stadium?

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did we give to the Eagles, the Western Australian team, or the Brisbane team?

—Senator McKiernan has raised a very good question. I am trying to find out what is happening. That is my point. What is happening? I believe that the Commonwealth owns the stadium. I want to know whether the Commonwealth is giving it or selling it to us. I think we are entitled to know what the arrangements are and how it can then be leased by the ACT Administration, which I believe does not own it at present, to some other group. These matters ought to be disclosed. The facts ought to be known.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, it worries me a little when the Minister, in his statement, talks about the need for this to be done `before the ACT Government is established'. Three Ministers are involved in one way or another; Senator Richardson, Mr West and Mr Holding. Clearly they have come to some agreement about a Commonwealth facility. They are planning that it be available to be leased by the ACT Administration to the Raiders. I would like to know what arrangements these Ministers have come to between themselves. I doubt whether in New South Wales, Western Australia or Queensland an asset of this size would be just given by the Commonwealth Government to the State Government. Doubting that, I wonder whether that is what is happening here. If it is, the Government should clearly say so and we would say, `Thank you very much'. The fact that the Government has not said so is what concerns me, as does the value at which this asset will be transferred and the value at which it will have to be paid back by the people of the ACT in the future arrangement. I hope that the Minister will make a statement and put the matter beyond doubt as to who owns the facility and what the legal situation is, so that all of us will know. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the content of the Minister's press release headed `Raiders Relocation to Bruce', dated 3 May 1989.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
RAIDERS RELOCATION TO BRUCE

The Minister for the Arts and Territories, Clyde Holding, today announced the engagement of Price Waterhouse, Chartered Accountants, to negotiate a financial agreement with the Canberra Raiders for the long term hiring of the National Outdoor Stadium at Bruce. Price Waterhouse will negotiate on behalf of the ACT Administration.
``The finalisation of financial arrangements with the Raiders is an important step in ensuring the successful relocation of the Raiders to Bruce for the 1990 football season,'' Mr Holding said.

To allow the Raiders to move to Bruce, an undertaking was given that the Stadium would be redeveloped to make it suitable for rugby league and other field sports. In addition, athletics facilities will be provided by upgrading the existing athletics warm-up track to a national standard facility.

``Design work for the redevelopment of the Stadium and the athletics track is almost complete. All parties have been working closely together to ensure the facilities meet user requirements and that the timetable for the Raiders to commence at Bruce in 1990 is achieved.

``It is proposed that the ACT Administration will lease the Stadium from the Australian Institute of Sport and negotiations on the terms and conditions of the lease are well advanced,'' said Mr Holding.
``It was essential to make these decisions prior to the establishment of the ACT Government to make sure the momentum of the project was maintained.
``I believe it is very important that the high quality facilities at Bruce are redeveloped as soon as possible for the benefit of the ACT community,'' he said.

``Not only will the Raiders have a significantly improved home ground, but it will also be possible for other field sports to make use of this community asset. The ACT athletics community will have access to a national standard athletics field with a new grandstand and associated administrative facilities.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to add further to the case I have been building over a series of weeks in relation to allegations of corrupt practices in banks in Australia. Honourable senators may have seen the cover story in the Bulletin of last week entitled `Why the banks are bastards'. I will continue to pursue, as I say, the allegations of corrupt practices and the provision of evidence that supports those allegations, as I have done now for several months. In the course of the next 15 minutes I will be seeking leave to table certain further evidence, as I have done in the past. I think honourable senators are aware that I have now tabled in the vicinity of 30 affidavits, sworn statements or signed documents in support of 35 allegations-very serious allegations-of corrupt practices in Australian banks. I seek leave, therefore, initially to table further signed documents and affidavits in relation to three further cases, Dunn in dispute with Westpac; Stay in dispute with Westpac; and Todd in dispute with the Commonwealth Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I will briefly elaborate on these cases because they are three further examples of the sorts of relationships which now prevail between banks and their customers and clearly illustrate, yet further, the sound and very valid grounds, I believe, for serious allegations of corrupt practise.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look first of all at the allegations of Mr Dunn in his dispute with Westpac. It is typical of the 33 affidavits I have now tabled. Mr Dunn's accountant forged cheques on Mr Dunn's company at the Westpac Bank to the amount of $192,000-odd. The accountant, David Barr, was charged, tried, found guilty and sentenced to 11 years in gaol. The amount of money stolen from the company accounts by the accountant was determined by an audit, requested by the bank and paid for by Mr Dunn at a cost of $11,000. Mr Dunn requested that the bank replace the missing funds but it did not reply to his requests. Mr Dunn's company has now, apparently, in one fell swoop lost approximately $200,000 through no fault of its own. It was forced to mortgage its Mascot factory and property to find the funds to sustain the business. The two biggest creditors were Blue Metal Industries (BMI) and Mitsubishi.

BMI, with which Westpac had its accounts and whose managing director is presently managing director of Westpac owned AGC, suggested a scheme of agreement. The bank agreed that the Dunn home be transferred to a shelf company owned by the Dunns and began negotiating about the missing funds. Six months later, without the Dunns' knowledge, the business was sold. Mr Justice Needham of the equity division of the Supreme Court of New South Wales dismissed BMI's scheme manager for these illegal actions. Mitsubishi requested an investigation into what appeared to be a conspiracy and possible fraud. The liquidator, who had been nominated by BMI, then sold the Dunns' home and paid out the mortgage to the bank. The bank later settled the claim on the forged cheques on terms which were not to be disclosed and the liquidator received approximately 25 per cent of the total claim. Mr Dunn and his wife are now in excess of $200,000 at loss. They have lost their business and they have lost their home. The Dunns' case is not atypical of the 33 cases that I have now cited in evidence.

I turn now to the case of Mr Stay, who is in dispute with Westpac. It concerns offshore borrowing. Mr Stay is typical of the estimated 1,400 cases of people in Australia who were caught in the Swiss bank scam in 1984-85. Mr Stay's complaint is that he received very bad advice about offshore loans from the bank's representative and that the bank behaved unethically, in securing its own interests in relation to the loan, far and above the interests of its clients. It is precisely this type of case that I was suggesting be referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That proposition was defeated by the combined vote of the Opposition and the Government on 5 April.

I turn now to the case of Mr Todd, who was in dispute with the Commonwealth Bank. He needed a guarantor for an unsecured loan from the bank and approached his brother, Geoffrey, who agreed to guarantee $19,000 by putting up two State Bank deposit stocks of $17,000 and $18,000. Mr Todd says that it was agreed by all at the meeting at the bank that Mr Geoffrey Todd was guaranteeing only $19,000 for a period of six months and nothing further, that he would be able to use the remainder of the State Bank deposit stocks whenever he wished, that they were not part of the guarantee and had only been put up in their entirety in order not to affect interest earned.

After problems with his company, Mr Todd was told by the bank that the guarantee was for $35,000 over 10 years, and not $19,000 over six months, as he had been led to believe. Mr Todd's company was liquidated, whereupon the bank registered a mortgaged on Mr Todd's brother's house and then applied pressure to sell the house. Mr Todd was told that if he transferred $50,000 to the bank he would be completely released. He borrowed $50,000 from the CBS building society and transferred it to the bank, whereupon only $18,000 was released. He is still waiting for the rest of the money.
I have cited only three further examples. Progressively each week I will cite and build up more and more evidence which typifies these cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this all in writing?

—It is all substantiated. I can provide the substantiating documentary evidence. In my remaining time, I would like to turn to a very serious matter indeed. On 5 April the Senate debated my proposition that the matter of alleged corrupt practices in banking be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. As I said, it was defeated by a combined vote of the Government and the Opposition. In that debate, Senator Stone, responding on behalf of the coalition, cited, tabled and had incorporated in Hansard five personal letters from the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank to me. Mr Don Sanders, the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, has written five letters to me. Senator Stone apparently had been supplied with copies of those letters and he chose, as part of his contribution to the debate, to incorporate in Hansard four of those five letters. I had neither responded to those letters personally, nor had I tabled them in the Senate because I was continuing my analysis of what they told me.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major thrusts of Senator Stone's criticisms was that I had not been doing my homework. I have spent literally thousands of hours, in relation to the hundreds of cases that I have before me, doing homework on this issue. Senator Stone claimed that I had not been doing my homework and chose to table and incorporate in Hansard four personal letters on which I had not yet finished my homework, and about which he obviously had not done his. I now wish to cite the implications of two of those letters because they are in Hansard, they contain inaccurate statements, they are grossly misleading and they warrant correction. I will now cite for the Senate and table documents which I hope will rectify the situation.

One of the letters was the Commonwealth Bank's explanation of what had happened in relation to the Great Australian Hat Company in Western Australia. Mr Sanders said that an earlier document, an affidavit, that I had tabled which said that the Great Australian Hat Company had been virtually stolen by a former manager of the Commonwealth Bank in Western Australia for a sum of $200,000 or less was inaccurate, and that the business had changed hands on 17 August 1988 at a figure of $990,000. He actually cited the contract in his letter. That contract never existed. It may have been drafted. It may, perhaps, on 17 August have been intended, but it was never put into effect. The business was actually sold two months later. After considerable duress and enormous pressure upon Mr Derek Gilliland, the owner of the business, it was sold for less than $200,000, a 400 per cent difference in the figure cited by Mr Don Sanders. He cited a contract which was never put into effect. I seek leave to table the contract which did effect the transfer of that business-at a cost of less than $200,000, not at a price of $900,000, as had been misrepresented in Mr Sanders's letter to me. That misrepresentation was tabled by Senator Stone in support and defence of his former colleague and manager of the Commonwealth Bank, Mr Sanders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to see the document first.
—Senator McLean, if you show the document to the Minister you may be given leave a little later.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I would like to read to the Senate a statutory declaration of Mr Derek Gilliland in relation to the statements made to the Senate by Mr Sanders. The statutory declaration reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I, Derek Stewart Gilliland . . .
He identifies himself as a businessman of a particular address in Western Australia-

Managing Director, do solemnly and sincerely declare that the statement by Mr D. N. Sanders, Managing Director, Commonwealth Bank, in his letter of the 8 February 1989 to Senator McLean is a total lie. The truth of the matter is that I DEREK GILLILAND former owner of THE GREAT AUSTRALIAN HAT COMPANY was forced to sell that company to AERODALE HOLDINGS a $2.00 company owned by Mr Clem Gannons and his wife for TWO HUNDRED THOUSAND DOLLARS ($200,000.00) on the 17th October. Included in the TWO HUNDRED THOUSAND DOLLARS ($200,000.00) was EIGHTY THOUSAND DOLLARS ($80,000.00) worth of plant and equipment. In actual fact Gannon obtained this multi million dollar company for ONE HUNDRED AND TWENTY FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS ($125,000.00). I was forced to sell THE GREAT AUSTRALIAN HAT COMPANY to Mr Clem Gannon (member of the WACA and Umpire) by sustained threats and harassment from my Bank Manager Mr Hugh Beavan (Member of the WACA and chief selector of the West Australian Cricket team) and his assistant Mr Scott McClelland. The sustained harassment and threats against me, my dogs and horses brought me to the verge of a nervous breakdown. I signed the Sale Agreement without even showing it to my accountant or solicitor.
The budgeted net profit for THE GREAT AUSTRALIAN HAT COMPANY this year was to be ONE MILLION DOLLARS ($1,000,000). The Company had never made a loss but always an increased profit.

The threats against me and my animals have been continuous in an effort to get me to run away, culminating in a threat against my life if I attended Paul McLean's press meeting in Western Australia and if I dared to speak out Mr D. N. Sanders statement that THE GREAT AUSTRALIAN HAT COMPANY was sold to Gannon Nominees Pty Ltd for NINE HUNDRED AND NINETY THOUSAND FOUR HUNDRED DOLLARS ($990,400.00) is a blatant lie.
AND I make this solemn declaration by virtue of Section 106 of the Evidence Act 1906.

I read this extremely serious statutory declaration into the record to rectify and to stand alongside the letter from Mr Sanders to me which was incorporated in Hansard at the request of Senator Stone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean, earlier you sought leave to table a document. Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

—In summary, progressively over the last few months Mr Sanders has expressed surprise at allegations of corruption. He has denied allegations of corruption. He has told us that there have been thorough investigations of those allegations when, in fact, the vast majority of people making them have not been approached by either the Commonwealth Bank or the Federal Police. So if there has been an investigation it must have been superficial; it must have been shallow.

SPEECH.PARA: I have tabled evidence here today that, in the personal letters that Mr Sanders sent to me, which Senator Stone had incorporated in Hansard, there have been gross misstatements. I have tabled a statutory declaration by the defendant in this matter that they are, in fact, lies. This is an extraordinarily serious situation and one which I draw to the attention of honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our State of Tasmania is often referred to unfairly by sections of the media. Therefore, not all Australians fully appreciate our unique lifestyle, our heritage or the contribution the State makes to the national economy. I wish to take the few minutes afforded me by this debate to refer to a booklet produced by the Tasmanian Development Authority referred to as The Little Tassie Fact Book. This booklet contains many interesting facts and figures. It is designed to encourage mainlanders and overseas investors to establish enterprises in Tasmania and to encourage visitors to visit the State.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will be interested in some of these facts which for me make Tasmania the best place to live in the world. Hobart has less than half Sydney's annual rainfall. I think that is pertinent at present. On average Tasmania is warmer than the Spanish capital, Madrid, and is closer to the equator than the Azores or Rome. It has the oldest live theatre, the oldest continuing licensed public house and the greatest complement of public buildings in Australia.

The Richmond Bridge, in a beautiful village just outside Hobart, is the oldest bridge in Australia, and the Waverley woollen mills in Launceston are the oldest woollen mills still operating in the nation. The Van Dieman's Land Co., which runs Woolnorth on the far north west coast, is the only royal charter company still operating in the world, having received its charter in 1825 from King George III. In Tasmania a higher proportion of land, 22.6 per cent, is set aside for recreation and conservation than in any other State of the Commonwealth. Tasmania's central plateau region is one of the world's last publicly accessible wild trout fisheries and my State possesses the finest brown trout angling in the southern hemisphere, providing all brown trout stocks in Australia and New Zealand.

In the field of education, Tasmania remains at the forefront. In 1869 Tasmania became the first colony in the British Empire to make school attendance compulsory. In 1946 it became the first Australian State to make school attendance mandatory up to the age of 16 years. Tasmania's school expenditure per student exceeds the Australian average by nine per cent. Under the policies pursued by the Tasmanian Liberal Government, State charges and taxes have been kept amongst the lowest in the Commonwealth. For example, pay-roll tax is about 20 per cent below the national average. The cost of employing private sector workers is nearly nine per cent lower in Tasmania than the national average and labour on-costs for each employee are significantly lower than the national average. Tasmania's hydro-electric scheme continues to provide clean, efficient power, with domestic electricity prices being about 20 per cent below the average of other States. One fact that may be of interest to honourable senators is that Tasmania generates twice as much electricity from hydro resources as does the Snowy Mountain Hydro-Electric Authority.

In the agricultural field Tasmania also leads the way. More than 27 per cent of the State is used for primary production. My State produces more than 60 per cent of Australia's processed peas and has the world's largest lavender farm. Tasmania is free of any diseases which plague mainland primary producers, including Mediterranean fruit fly, anthrax, blue tongue, Q fever and rinderpest. Tasmania has the largest quail producing enterprise in the nation and is the only State with a duck breeding program. Tasmania produces the largest quantity of onions of any State. One interesting statistic to ponder is that Tasmanian dairy cows actually produce more milk than other States-over 3,705 litres per cow each year. Other States produce on average 200 litres less. If I add Tasmania's unique leatherwood honey, its top woollen carpets, its first class furniture, such as the Hansard table in this chamber, its wines and its internationally renowned cream and cheeses, it is clear that Tasmania has a great deal to offer. Although we are only a small State with about three per cent of the national population, some of the facts that I have mentioned show that Tasmania is more than pulling its weight to bolster and invigorate the national economy.
