SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 June 1987, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, announced the opening of his campaign for the election that he had called because he had seen a political opportunity of being re-elected. He announced that the great agenda for the Hawke Government during its third term would be micro-economic reform. One of the areas where he announced there would be major micro-economic reform was broadcasting. The Prime Minister, in that campaign policy launch, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor proposes also to reform substantially the Broadcasting Act, rendering this nightmarish piece of legislation simpler, easier to understand and administer and shorn of unnecessary burdens currently suffered by licensees and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

The truth is that, like every other area, there has been no micro-economic reform in the broadcasting area, notwithstanding the rhetoric of the Prime Minister or the grand promises that he made in that speech and subsequently. There has been no micro-economic reform. What we have had in the broadcasting area are insignificant, minor Bills, such as this one-so unimportant that it is debated during a Thursday lunchtime. There will be no discussion about it and no major speeches from the Government about it. The Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, will not even be present in the chamber while the Bill is being debated, because it is so insignificant.

The Bill fixes up some mistakes to do with the grandfathering clauses in an earlier piece of legislation, the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill. They are absolutely insignificant and not worthwhile dealing any further with. There are major matters of concern to all who are interested in broadcasting which have not been dealt with by this Government, but have been allowed to lapse.

Let me mention the inaction of the Minister, Mr Willis, who has taken over the portfolio of Transport and Communications. Three months ago I asked for a departmental briefing on a very minor matter that was stage two of the Government's announced national metropolitan radio plan. Every other department that I have ever been involved with has been able to provide me with a briefing within 48 hours. I know that this Department was able to provide me with a briefing within 48 hours because my staff was told that the briefing was ready, but that the Minister wanted to have a look at it before the departmental officer came to speak with me about the matter-as if the departmental officer was going to tell me something of major significance that the Government did not want me to know. The Department was also talking about sending over with the departmental officer an officer from Minister Willis's personal staff. What happened? I had requested the briefing repeatedly. My staff had requested it repeatedly. At one stage we were told that the briefing had been taken by Minister Willis overseas, so that he could consider it while he was there. Glory be! A departmental briefing was requested for a shadow Minister, and the Minister is so reluctant to allow anyone to know what is going on in his department that three months later I still have not received the departmental briefing.

That is an indication of the snail-like pace that this Minister is displaying in relation to the whole of his portfolio. He has been given one of the major portfolios of the Hawke Government-Transport and Communications, an area where micro-economic reform is absolutely essential to the future of this country. This country is going down the drain at the rate of $15 billion a year. Micro-economic reform is the one area where the Government can actually do something to address the issues, and the Government has given the major portfolio to Minister Willis, who is incapable of crawling anywhere at any pace to do anything. It is a disgrace that the Prime Minister does not call him in and remind him of the agenda that the Prime Minister announced in 1987 for bringing in micro-economic reform.

The Broadcasting Ownership and Control Bill (No. 2) 1988, this Bill, was introduced in the other chamber in November last year. The Bill has taken until May this year to get into the Senate and it is absolutely, totally insignificant.

What is the Government doing about the lack of powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as it faces the problem of how it is going to deal with the Bond matter? That is a matter of major importance. What is the Government doing about it? It is doing absolutely nothing. There are no Bills before us, no proposals, no press releases, no statements-nothing. The Government will allow the Broadcasting Tribunal to get further and further along the road, give it no help, force it ultimately either to make the terrible decision it is faced with, or do nothing. The Prime Minister, this Minister and this Government have known about this problem for 18 months. Fifteen to 18 months ago it was mentioned by the Chairman of the Tribunal.

Let me give a practical example. Recently there was an application for the renewal of a television licence for television station BKN in Broken Hill. The question of the adequacy and comprehensiveness of the service was canvassed and the member for the Broadcasting Tribunal who was dealing with the matter found that the service was not adequate and comprehensive. So she found against the television station, but she could do nothing about it other than to revoke the licence. She knew that if she revoked the licence the people of Broken Hill would not have a television service. So what did she do? She had to renew the licence because she was not prepared to deprive the people of Broken Hill of the service. That example has nothing to do with the Bond matter, but it is the sort of problem which the Broadcasting Tribunal is now being confronted with in regard to the Bond matter-and this Government does absolutely nothing. There is not even a press release-not a Bill rushed through the Parliament to give the Tribunal some additional powers to cope with its problem-nothing.

What is the Government doing about audience reach? We know that in the television area at least two networks appear to have exceeded the statutory limitation of 60 per cent of audience reach, and what are those companies to do about it? It appears that they may be forced to divest themselves of some of their licence ownership. Who will suffer? The people who will suffer will be the people of Adelaide because the licences that would most easily be disposed of are the licences for Adelaide. That would mean that there would be a network all around Australia except for Adelaide. The people of Sydney, the people of Melbourne, the people of the other capital cities would be part of the network, but the people of Adelaide would not. They may be able to buy into the network-they may be able to use the network in some way or other-but their companies would have an insignificant input into the nature of the programs being put on the network because they themselves would be so insignificant. So the people of South Australia, the people of Adelaide, are the people who will suffer as a result, again, of this Government's inaction.

The current audience reach limit is 60 per cent, but the coalition policy is to extend it to 100 per cent if the Government does certain things to free up that sector of the broadcasting network. We have said that the Government should allow the introduction of pay and cable television, which it is doing in some respects in a Bill we have before us for consideration at present. It should substantially streamline the television licensing procedure. It should enact cross-media ownership rules between pay and cable television, which it is not doing, and it should order an inquiry by the Tribunal into the issuing of new television licences. We have said that if these things were done we would support a 100 per cent audience reach.

The Government's policy is to extend the audience reach from 60 per cent to 75 per cent, but is the Parliament going to be given the opportunity to consider any of these matters? No, certainly not under Minister Willis. Certainly, in no way under Minister Willis will anything be done which in any way might be controversial or which might bring the matter forward for consideration or debate. Under this Minister nothing is done. Everyone has to remain silent because they are frightened that they are in the run-up to another election. They feel that they are operating in an area where it is best to do nothing. To be seen to do nothing is apparently more acceptable to this Government than to bring any of these matters forward for consideration.

Today the Senate is faced with a minor, insignificant broadcasting Bill dealing with some technical changes to previous legislation. The amendments are of a minor technical nature. They involve no change in the Government's policy. They are irrelevant and uninteresting. That is what the Prime Minister brings forward through his Minister, Minister Willis. That is what the Government brings forward as part of its great agenda for micro-economic reform-the major piece of reform brought about by the Hawke Government during its third term. It is a wimpish piece of legislation that deals with nothing. It is all we have seen as the fruits of the Government's proposed substantial reforms of the Broadcasting Act.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Crimes (Hostages) Bill. In fact, the Opposition will support any reasonable measure to reduce hostage-taking or other forms of international terrorism. This Bill will enable Australia to accede to the International Convention Against the Taking of Hostages. I understand that that Convention was unanimously adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on 17 December 1979 and came into force on 3 June 1983. So progress would appear to be somewhat slow, but better late than never. We are prepared today to give our support to the measure.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that this Bill should be looked at in conjunction with other pieces of legislation which have been passed by this Parliament since the early 1970s: the Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act 1972; the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973, and the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act 1976. Mr Acting Deputy President, it has been the international experience that states acting alone have had major difficulties in deterring the horrific practice of the taking of hostages. As you might imagine, all sorts of international pressure can be brought to bear upon an individual state, a nation state, which is determined to act in a way which we would have thought was in the best interests of the world community, that is, to prosecute hostage-takers with all due force of the law.

It is equally evident that if states are prepared to cooperate and act together, the whole world community, provided that it can reach a common position, has the capacity to give that added strength to individual states in dealing with these international criminals. That, as I understand it, is the basis of the Convention, a convention under which the world community came together through the auspices of the United Nations and tried to set down a framework by which each nation state undertook to deal with hostages and to deal with other nation states in relation to hostages. I have on previous occasions applauded the work that the UN does. Often that work gets very little credit. This is another example of where the UN, as a framework for the world community, has been able to bring nation states together to reach a common position in dealing with this scourge.

The Convention, as I read it, provides that states will pass required criminal legislation, that the acts of these hostages will come under criminal legislation within the state and that they will be dealt with within the state in accordance with that legislation. Therefore, this Bill before us today creates new offences, particularly under clause 8, which provides that a person who, at any time after the Convention enters into force for Australia, commits an act of hostage-taking is guilty of an offence against the subsection, and hostage-taking is defined. The legislation also provides for offences for attempted hostage-taking and for participating as an accomplice in hostage-taking or attempted hostage-taking.

I understand that a number of the States-States in this instance being States within Australia-claim to have criminal legislation that could adequately deal with these matters. Nevertheless, the passing of this Bill would put that beyond any doubt and would also make clear to the world community that we in this country are prepared to put into place a statutory criminal regime to do our bit to reduce the abhorrent international behaviour of hostage-taking-something that is rare in this country. We hope that it will remain rare. This Parliament, by indicating in this legislative form that hostage-taking is intolerable behaviour under any circumstances, is taking one small step towards reducing the possibility of hostage-taking coming to Australia as, unfortunately, it has come to other parts of the world.

The Opposition supports the Bill, wishes it a speedy passage and looks forward to Australia acceding to the international convention and making further efforts in the years ahead to combat this practice in every reasonable way.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the release this morning of the consumer price index figures for the March quarter, which purport to show a rise of only one per cent in the CPI between the December quarter and the March quarter. I ask the Minister: first, is this one per cent figure a quite spurious measure of the actual rise in prices during the March quarter? Secondly, even on the basis of the new approach to measuring the effect on the CPI of mortgage interest charges, which, under pressure from the Treasurer, he has not introduced, does the Australian Statistician also indicate in his release that the CPI increase in the March quarter was actually 1.6 per cent, rather than the one per cent shown on the front page of the release? Thirdly, why has the Statistician not also published, for analytical purposes, comparable figures for the March quarter, on the basis which he has been using for the past two years? Finally, does the Minister agree that on that previous basis the increase in the March quarter would have been even higher than 1.6 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —To take the last two parts to the question first, I do not know why a hypothetical figure for the March quarter was not published on the methodology that has been employed for the previous two years. He then asked what that figure was. I do not know that either. As to the earlier parts to the question, no, one per cent is not a spurious figure. One per cent is the change, with the new methodology, on the previous CPI aggregate under the old methodology in the December quarter. I do not want to go into a great deal of detail about this, but of course the error, or the conceptual flaw, in the previous methodology-and I have been talking about this publicly for at least six months-is that when housing prices rose it was implicitly assumed, for CPI purposes, that the outstanding loans of everybody who had an outstanding loan had risen commensurate to the increase of housing prices, even though their loans, and therefore their interest payments, had not increased at all. It was a flawed methodology. I repeat that the figure of one per cent is not a spurious one. What the documentation represents is pretty clear. I wish to quote from the press release of the Acting Treasurer:

ANSWER.PARA: (The published quarterly CPI increase of 1.0 per cent reflects the one-off step down because of the change to the new system and is not a true indication of the underlying rate).

Far from there being an attempt by the Government to misrepresent the underlying reality, there is an explicit statement that the one per cent figure does not represent the underlying rate. The underlying rate is more accurately reflected on, I think, the second page of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) bulletin, which gives the figure of 1.6 per cent that Senator Stone mentioned. That is the quarterly figure that would apply if the present methodology had been in operation for 18 months or two years. Either way, and it is not entirely coincidental, I understand, the annual figure is either 6.8 or 6.9 per cent. That is the true indication of the underlying rate-significantly below what it has been recently.

This Government has earned, over many years, a reputation for the honest presentation and publication of statistics, unlike the previous Government, which, on the admission of the then Treasurer, fiddled the Budget figures in 1977, and unlike the last of the Liberal Treasurers who, in the week before the 1983 election, publicly asserted that the prospective Budget deficit for the next financial year was $6 billion when he already had advice from Senator Stone that it would be $10 billion. What did he do? He went out and fibbed to the public. This Government has earned a reputation for the honest presentation of statistics. It is not into figure fiddling, as was the previous Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for admitting that he does not know why the Statistician has seen fit not to publish for analytical purposes figures for the rise in prices in the March quarter on a comparable basis to that on which he had previously published figures. On that point, would the Minister not agree with me that there was not the slightest reason why such figures should not be published for analytical purposes? Would he therefore agree with me that the Statistician should be persuaded, by an apparently very persuasive Treasurer in these matters, to rectify the oversight that he has made on this occasion? Secondly the Minister, in his reply to me, said that the one per cent figure shown on the front page of the release is not a spurious figure. Does the Minister agree that the one per cent figure is arrived at by taking the rise in prices for the previous two or three quarters, as the case may be, calculated on the old basis-what I might call the `oranges' basis-and the rise in prices for that period plus the March quarter on the new basis, or what I might call the `lemons' basis, and subtracting one from the other? If he does not think that is spurious, I would be interested to know what other word might be applied to it. The Minister says that the release contains a statement that the one per cent figure is not a measure of the underlying inflation rate. Will the Minister point out to the Senate where that statement occurs?
—I hope you don't complain about not getting enough questions at question time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid I did not hear the last line of that question, as some of my colleagues were getting sick of listening to Senator Stone's speech. Regarding what he chose to call the `oranges and lemons' basis, I think that is correct. It is the last quarter on top of three previous quarters, with the last quarter being measured in a different way. But it is not spurious. It is quite clear, both in the ABS bulletin and in the Acting Treasurer's statement, that that is a figure which stands alone as a piece of accurate arithmetic but does not reflect accurately the underlying inflation rate. The Government has explicitly said so.

ANSWER.PARA: I will try to get from the Statistician an answer as to why the figure for the March quarter, compiled on the basis, of the previous two years, was not published. Whatever the answer may be-and I do not know; I have not thought much about whether it would have shown a higher or a lower figure than 1.6 per cent-the figure will suffer from precisely the same conceptual flaw that the method of compiling the CPI which has been used for the last couple of years has had all along.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade provide further information about the agreement reached last week on new arrangements which will help overcome problems arising out of Indonesian fishing activity in Australian fishing zones?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agreed with Foreign Minister Ali Alatas in March that officials of both countries should meet to discuss Indonesian fishing activity in the Australian fishing zone, which has for some time been a source of concern in our bilateral relationship. Officials accordingly met in Jakarta on 28 and 29 April last week and arrived at a number of new arrangements aimed at overcoming problems, first, in the operations of Indonesian traditional fishermen under the 1974 memorandum of understanding (MOU), and secondly in the illegal activities of Indonesian fishermen in other areas of the Australian fishing zone.

ANSWER.PARA: I take this opportunity to table the agreed minutes of that meeting and its annexes. These contain the practical guidelines for operations under the 1974 MOU and also a map which indicates the area in which Indonesian traditional fishermen can fish. New guidelines to the operation of that 1974 memorandum add certainty to the application of rules in the MOU area and confirm our understanding of what is covered by the reference to Indonesian traditional fishermen operating by traditional methods and using traditional fishing vessels.

We have also given access to traditional fishermen to a wider so-called box area in the Australian fishing zone and continental shelf. This will simplify our enforcement requirements by more clearly identifying the area in which fishing is permitted. Indonesia has also acknowledged the need for conservation measures which have been introduced in the Ashmore Reef nature reserve and for the protection of wildlife.

Indonesia also recognised that Australia would take necessary measures to prevent any illegal fishing in the Arafura Sea south of the provisional fisheries enforcement line and off the north west coast of Australia where incursions occurred in 1988 and earlier this year. Again, it was agreed that Australian and Indonesian officials will consider ways to develop alternative income projects for villages in eastern Indonesia which are dependent on fishing and which suffer from economic pressures which tend to lead villagers to enter Australian waters illegally. Officials will also consider the possible benefits of a reciprocal fishing agreement.

Officials of both countries have thus arrived at a package of measures which should, in my belief, go a very long way towards addressing the fisheries problems which have arisen in recent times. Earlier in the week they had made substantial further progress toward drawing up a comprehensive agreement on the zone of cooperation in the Timor Gap. The new arrangements in relation to Indonesian fishing activity in the Australian fishing zone, combined with the progress that has been achieved in the Timor Gap talks, are terribly important practical steps which, as I have already said publicly on a number of occasions, will give practical ballast to one of Australia's most manifestly important bilateral relationships.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of Mr Ben, the newly-elected Speaker of the Solomon Islands Parliament, accompanied by the Clerk of that Parliament. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate. I trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the closure in Adelaide of Australia's biggest agricultural machinery maker, John Shearer Ltd, which has cost 300 jobs and brought to an end that company's manufacturing activities after a period of 125 years. Is the Minister aware that the company, which was making very considerable losses that had, under new management, been turned around to a profit, said that the April economic statement decision to end the bounty on manufactured agricultural machinery and a two-week strike followed by an unsatisfactory Industrial Commission ruling were the reasons for the closure? Does the Minister agree that the decision to end the bounty 20 months ahead of its scheduled expiry was taken purely for cost-cutting purposes? Does he further agree that this unilateral action runs contrary to and makes a mockery of his often asserted need for predictability and certainty in industry policy? Will the Government agree to apply the bounty not just to stocks as at 12 April, but also to firm orders held by companies on the basis of prices quoted assuming the continuing bounty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of the question is no. The Government gave some consideration to whether the cessation of the bounty should apply in respect of stocks and it decided that stocks held on the floor, as it were, should continue to be subject to the bounty but that work in progress should not. There were very practical reasons for that which had been experienced before when bounties had been brought to an end. That was the reason for the decision.

ANSWER.PARA: Generally, I am fairly well aware of the history of John Shearer Ltd. The company has been under financial strain for some years. In the past three or four years it has lost some $15m. No dividend has been paid for three years. The press release issued by John Shearer-I do not have it with me-adverted particularly to the industrial relations problem to which Senator Chaney referred. No doubt that has been a problem for the company and I will refer to some other views on that in a minute.

The performance of the agricultural equipment industry in terms of, for example, exports, has been dismal. That is due partly to the very fragmented structure which that industry has inherited. Senator Chaney would be familiar with a company like Chamberlain John Deere Pty Ltd from his State which was supported by bounties for a long time. Nonetheless, in spite of that support it went out of business in terms of its tractor production and was not able to blame the Government at the time for that failure.

John Shearer has received substantial assistance from the Federal Government, however, in various ways. It received $70,000 under the heavy engineering development program. In the period in which it was making losses, it received $1.3m from the Industrial Research and Development Board for the redevelopment of a new product. It received $748,000 in bounty in 1987-88 and $1.1m in 1986-87. As I understand it, sales have declined further in 1987-88. I do not agree with the view which has been expressed that the cessation of the bounty was a major cause of Shearer's closure or even led to the decision to close.
As to the industrial relations issue, I draw the honourable senator's attention to a comment in today's Adelaide Advertiser. The editorial states:
The Industrial Relations Commission yesterday ordered the company to resume past practices while the issue-
of compulsory union membership-
was negotiated-
a basic move in any dispute. Whatever may be felt about closed shops, Mr White-
that is the manager-
should recognise that the unions behaved properly in resuming work.

As for the bounty, Shearer has known for four years that it would be removed. When in April the date was brought forward, Mr White sought exemptions from the Industry Minister, Senator Button, for existing orders. This was quite reasonable. But it takes patience for such a request to be studied.
Such a request has been studied, although Senator Chaney foreshadowed my response to Shearer in his question. I have indicated the position of the Government on that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are saying no?
—Yes. The editorial continues:

ANSWER.PARA: It seems that Shearer, or its parent company Arrowcrest, has another agenda. The key might be found in a recent announcement by Massey-Ferguson that it has made a prices `breakthrough' with a harvester made in its factory in Brazil.

The removal of the bounty is in line with the aim of making Australian manufacturers more efficient to fight off imports. If this means rationalisations, this industry is well placed for amalgamations, with the various firms having individual specialisations that could combine well.
It continues in that vein.

Senator Chaney also asked whether this was an example of what I meant by continuity in government practice. The answer, I regretfully say, is no. The decision was made on the basis of overall economic considerations. It was made in light of the view that the bounty had done very little to help this industry rationalise, to help it improve its export performance, to help in terms of the mergers that would take place and try to overcome the process of fragmentation. The Government has in mind to do some other things with this industry which might help with those processes which are a better form of intervention than the bounty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his reply and particularly for his frank admission at the end of the answer that the decision is not really consistent with industry policy as he has advocated. I ask the Minister: in light of the fact that the company concerned had been turned round, had been restored to a profitable situation, had, since takeover, gone from employing 190 people to employing 300 people and had $5m worth of orders on its books, placed on the basis that the bounty would be available, what assurance can he offer manufacturers in Australia, who enter into arrangements on the strength of plans and proposals put down by this Government, that the same unilateral action will not be taken in respect of bounties, tariffs and other industry plans?
—Every assurance, Mr President. As I have explained, in my view there were quite exceptional circumstances in relation to this industry.

—In directing my question to the Minister for Justice, I refer him to the call yesterday by Mr John Hatton, MP, an independent member of the New South Wales Parliament, for a royal commission into marijuana cultivation in southern New South Wales. I also remind the Minister of Mr Hatton's suggestion that any investigation should exclude investigators from either the New South Wales Police or the Australian Federal Police because of allegations of corruption against these forces. What is the Minister's response to Mr Hatton's call?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did notice Mr Hatton's call. I saw it on television and I read some excerpts in the press which were linked to an apparent desire on his part that there be a public inquiry into the circumstances surrounding Mr Col Winchester's death. I took Mr Hatton's remarks much more seriously than the remarks a week or so ago by Mr Ahern who also called for such a royal commission. Mr Ahern was clearly engaged in a diversionary tactic to distract attention from his own problems with his own police force and the report of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct which is about to be brought down. Might I say that inquiry was aided in its investigation phase by the Australian Federal Police (AFP). It was called upon by Mr Fitzgerald to assist. But that is by the bye. Mr Hatton, because of his many years of active campaigning on the question of organised crime, deservedly enjoys a much higher reputation than Mr Ahern and therefore deserves a much more considered response.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to his request that a royal commission be set up to investigate the various marijuana plantations that are alleged to have been established in New South Wales in collaboration between various members of the Italian community, it needs to be pointed out that the National Crime Authority already has a reference named Vigilantes which allows it to exercise the powers of a royal commission in regard to the matters of concern to Mr Hatton. Indeed, it was because the National Crime Authority had such extensive, extraordinary powers not available to ordinary law enforcement agencies in this country that certain committal proceedings were commenced at Queanbeyan and, indeed, I believe that four people have been committed for trial.

The fact is that those powers which would be available to a royal commission are available and can be exercised by the National Crime Authority in a way which, I believe, has been indicated by parliamentary vote, sanction and approval in this place, is the better way to go, namely, that an inquiry be conducted using those special powers in private, not in the full glare of publicity where accusations made may prove to be unfounded, in a way which allows the gathering of admissible evidence so that prosecutions may take place.

In answer to the question of a public inquiry into the circumstances surrounding Mr Winchester's killing, honourable senators will be aware that yesterday, I think it was, the Chief Magistrate of the Australian Capital Territory, Mr Ron Cahill, indicated that he will begin a formal inquest on 15 May and in that matter he will be assisted by Mr John Dee, QC, the Deputy Director of Public Prosecutions. This will be a most important forum for an examination of these matters. Because it is the task of the coroner to reach a conclusion as to the manner and cause of Mr Winchester's death, the conduct of the Australian Federal Police in conducting these investigations will be made public. He will have to examine all the various theories, speculations and courses of investigation that have been spoken about.

The decision by Mr Cahill to set that particular date has been, of course, a matter of discussion between the Director of Public Prosecutions, the Commissioner of the AFP and Mr Cahill. Mr Cahill has properly made that decision and I believe that it is in that forum that much will be revealed which will enable the community and indeed this chamber for that matter to come to a proper assessment of the very proper, exhaustive, extensive and excellent inquiries being undertaken by the Australian Federal Police.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Justice. I draw the Minister's attention to the 30 affidavits concerning bank fraud which I have tabled since December last and I ask the Minister: firstly, given the Minister's early assurances of interest and the interest of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) in bank fraud, how many of the allegations have been investigated by the AFP and what is the progress of those investigations? Secondly, is the Minister aware that, until two weeks ago, neither the AFP nor the banks involved had contacted any of the 26 providers of affidavits whom my office was able to contact concerning their allegations, and does he consider this to be indicative of the `thorough investigation' which Mr Don Sanders, the General Manager of the Commonwealth Bank, assures us has occurred or even of an adequate level of inquiry into those allegations? Thirdly, is the Minister aware that Mr Sanders has provided me with personal explanations of five cases and that, in at least four of them, there are serious contradictions between the information provided to me by Mr Sanders and information, substantiated by documentation, provided on the same cases by the alleged victims of the Commonwealth Bank? If so, will he ensure that, wherever serious contradiction is apparent, a thorough investigation is undertaken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second, third or fourth occasion on which Senator McLean has posed questions to me with an underlying suggestion that somehow there has been a deliberate attempt by me or by the Australian Federal Police to cover up or fail adequately or with sufficient vigour to pursue matters that he has brought to the attention of the Senate. I recall in a debate in this place a few weeks ago that he made the allegation that I had refused a briefing that he had sought from the Australian Federal Police on this matter. As far as I know Senator McLean is not a legal representative of any of the persons he describes as victims, nor does he have any legal responsibility for the conduct of the Australian Federal Police investigation or prosecution for possible breaches of Federal law. That is my responsibility.
—Just as well.

—As Senator Walsh interjected, it is just as well. Naturally, I adopt it. It is much better that Senator McLean be on the front page of the Bulletin and me be in charge of the Australian Federal Police than the other way round. I am quite prepared to accept his moment of glory as long as I discharge my duties correctly. Of the matters that Senator McLean has brought to our attention over the past several months, my office has forwarded to the AFP copies of all materials tabled by Senator McLean since December. I have been advised by the AFP that it has examined all of the documents and that investigations were conducted into one of the cases raised by Senator McLean. It was a matter that was already under investigation by the AFP before Senator McLean began his campaign. These investigations were completed by the AFP and no evidence was found to corroborate the allegations that Senator McLean put forward. The final page of the memorandum to me, which is dated 31 March and signed by P. J. Lamb, Assistant Commissioner Investigations, reads:

ANSWER.PARA: In summary, the AFP has examined the papers tabled by Senator McLean and forwarded by your senior private secretary in December 1988 and March 1989. Apart from the Poppet case, referred to above, which has been investigated we do not propose to investigate the other matters unless we receive evidence to support allegations that Commonwealth laws have been breached.

Of the matters which Senator McLean raised, many do not fall within the jurisdiction of the Australian Federal Police in that they do not, on the face of it, disclose any breach of Commonwealth law. Many of the matters to which he referred either fell within State jurisdictions or appeared to be matters for civil litigation. In fact, as we know, many of the matters are, indeed, before courts for civil judgment. The AFP cannot follow up matters which do not come within its jurisdiction.

With regard to Senator McLean's constant requests that matters be followed up, the AFP has the task of marshalling its resources in order to fight organised crime and deal with major fraud against the Commonwealth and other breaches of Commonwealth law. It cannot devote trained investigators to the time-consuming pursuit of allegations about which there is no sufficient evidence. I cannot direct the AFP to chase every rabbit into its hole in the way that Senator McLean might do if he were in charge of the Investigations Division of the Australian Federal Police. Unless further evidence of offences against federal laws is produced by Senator McLean, this matter cannot be advanced much further.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the Minister has previously acknowledged the seriousness of the allegations which I have advanced and will continue to advance, could he, as Minister for Justice, recommend to me and those who are using me to advance these allegations which courses are available to them to obtain justice?

—I have already indicated that some of these people are already seeking justice in the correct forum, which is to do with civil litigation. Breaches of fiduciary duty were alleged and I believe that they are being followed up in those proper forums. It is only in relation to alleged breaches of federal law that the Federal Police have a proper role to play. So far, whilst Senator McLean may have uncovered a certain amount of unhappiness and people with grave misgivings about the way in which they have been dealt with by banking institutions, no evidence has been brought forward which would enable the Australian Federal Police, for whom I take responsibility, to proceed, for example, to charge a person for breach of federal law. In that situation, unless Senator McLean, his constituents or their advisers can come forward with better material, the matter must rest there and be determined in the sorts of forums-judicial or political-to which they are taking this campaign.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I ask whether the Department of Defence is concerned about the dangers of constructing the proposed petrochemical refinery at Kwinana in Western Australia so close to the naval base on Cockburn Sound which is geared for substantial expansion in the years ahead. Does the Minister acknowledge that there are dangers from an accident at the plant, a collision in the narrow channels into the Sound from the open sea, or from a possible attack on the base or the refinery in the event of conflict? If the petrochemical plant goes ahead, will it affect defence plans for expansion at Stirling Naval Base?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Defence does not consider that the construction of a petrochemical refinery at Kwinana endangers the naval base at HMAS Stirling. So far as the scenario suggested in the latter part of the honourable senator's question are concerned, the Department does not consider that they pose a danger to HMAS Stirling either.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the Minister accept that the speech by Ambassador Wilenski to the United Nations General Assembly on 21 April was unbalanced? If so, when did the Minister come to that conclusion, and why did he not come to that conclusion before the speech was delivered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not a great deal that I want to add to the answer which the Prime Minister gave yesterday. On the other hand, I would not mind subtracting a few things. Let me make a few quick points in response to this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, the resolution addressed and condemned specific incidents of human rights abuse in the occupied territories which appeared to be manifestly in violation of internationally-accepted standards. It was adopted by a vote of 129 in favour, two against and one abstention. Neither the Prime Minister nor anybody else has suggested, publicly or privately, that Australia's vote in favour of that resolution was misdirected-nobody, that is, with the exception of the Leader of the Opposition who seems to believe that it was.

Secondly, Australia's vote on that resolution was not in any way a departure from our past policy or position on these issues. Similar resolutions were supported at the United Nations General Assemblies in 1987 and 1988. Mr Hawke wrote to Prime Minister Shamir in early 1988 on the question of Israeli human rights abuse, including deaths and beatings among the civilian population, and a number of representations have been made on individual cases and issues.

The third point that I make is that on the most controversial part of the resolution, that dealing with freedom of religion, the basic information on which Australia founded its response relating to restrictions imposed following an incident at the Al-Aqsa Mosque on 7 April at the beginning of Ramadan, does not, to the knowledge of our embassy in Tel Aviv, appear to have been subsequently challenged. I have spelled out in considerably more detail our understanding of those detailed circumstances in a letter that I will be sending today in reply to Jewish community leaders. I do not think I need to go into all that now.

The fourth point is that Dr Wilenski's statement, which was cleared across my desk-and I accept responsibility for it-contained at least three qualifying or balancing elements. It noted that we had not, at that stage, received definite accounts about some of the incidents which were referred to and the making of final judgments may be premature. I add to put it in context that such further accounts which we have heard have not altered our understanding of the situation. The ambassador's speech did note that Australia would continue to abhor the use of violence by all parties in the dispute. It also expressed Australia's firm commitment to Israel's right to exist within secure and recognised boundaries.

The fifth point that I make is that debates on United Nations General Assembly resolutions of this kind are not usually regarded as occasions for making comprehensive statements of national policy, and certainly was not so regarded on this occasion. The debate, as did the resolution to which it was responding, addressed specific incidents of human rights abuse in the occupied territories, as was referred to in that resolution. Nevertheless, having said that, I concede the importance of acknowledging the very harrowing environment that Israel has had to endure since its founding, which it continues to endure and which must always be understood as a significant element of the background against which these incidents of human rights abuse-if they can be so described-occur.

I acknowledge, as I acknowledged at the time when the issue was first brought to my attention in an amicable conversation which I had with the Prime Minister that, notwithstanding the points that I have just made and the elements of balance which were already in the speech, it would have been desirable to make some further reference to the security realities that Israel continues to face as it struggles to cope with the present situation. They are the continuing violence which Israel is experiencing within, but by no means confined to, the Occupied Territories; and the anxiety that country is constantly entitled to feel, small and vulnerable as it is and surrounded as it is by countries that have not in most instances been prepared even to acknowledge its existence. I have acknowledged to the Jewish community, and I do so now publicly, that considerations of this kind are appropriately recognised, or should be recognised in future statements of this kind by government spokesmen, to ensure that there is no misunderstanding of our position.

TALK.START.PARA: —My supplementary question is addressed to the speech, not the vote, nor to the underlying issue. I remind the Minister that at five past two the Prime Minister in another place said, `There was a lack of balance in terms which I regret', or words to that effect, which I tried to write down. Later in his answer he said, `There was a regrettable lack of balance'. It was a highly unqualified statement by the Prime Minister. Does the Minister agree with what the Prime Minister said?
—Of course I agree with the Prime Minister, just as, on occasion, he agrees with me.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen an article by Robert Garran headlined `Income Splitting Not Worth Cost' which appeared in the Age of 27 April 1989? Is the Minister aware that some sections of the community are attracted to proposals to allow families to split their incomes for taxation purposes? Has the Government considered the merits of such proposals? What has the Government concluded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article and the allegation in it that the Opposition is planning to make income splitting part of its tax policy for the forthcoming election. I do not know whether that is true or false. Indeed, I think it far more likely that no-one in the Opposition has any idea where it is going on tax policy-least of all, I suspect, Mr Peacock. This issue is one that crops up from time to time, and it is important to spell out a few of the facts.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, the Government examined this question in the 1985 widespread review of taxation, and chapter 6 of the draft White Paper published that year sets out the issues. I will draw attention to some of the major ones. The first, and probably the most important, is that permitting income splitting is very costly to the revenue if no other adjustments are made. The 1985 White Paper estimated that the cost of doing it at that time would be of the order of $2 billion. Obviously, it would now be very much higher-perhaps close to double that amount. Assuming that the opposition did not want the public service borrowing requirement (PSBR) to be increased by $3 billion or $4 billion, or whatever the figure would be today, it would have to cover the cost of that change, if it were to be made, either by increasing the tax paid by other people-single people, sole parents, married couples with two incomes-or by cutting expenditure by several billion dollars. I suppose that, if one is guided by the Opposition's record, it is more likely that it would just allow the deficit to balloon out, as happened when it was last in government.

The next important point is that, among the single-income couples group, the greatest gains from such a change would accrue to those on the highest incomes. If both husband and wife work in full time jobs, each on average weekly earnings, it seems to me a bit unfair to make them pay exactly the same amount of tax as another couple who have the same total income but only one of whom is employed. Income splitting also has the effect of raising the effective marginal tax rate faced by the lower income earner of a couple, and of reducing that for the higher earner in a somewhat arbitrary fashion, which some people believe would have implications for economic efficiency as well.

Finally, income splitting would add very substantially to the complexity of the taxation system-a matter which was emphasised in the recently published Social Security Review. I do not think I will bother to quote from that review, although there are some fairly extensive passages that could be quoted. The administrative complexities of such a move are set out in some detail in that publication.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Did any Minister or department, other than the Foreign Minister and his Department, have prior knowledge of Ambassador Wilenski's first United Nation speech on 21 April? Will Australia's future statements on the Middle East be subject to vetting by the Prime Minister himself?

—I believe that the proposed speech was cleared deep within the bowels of the Prime Minister's Department but that it did not ascend to the higher levels in order for this fine judgment to be made. Bearing in mind the nature of things-the speed with which these issues arise, the short turnaround time, often late at night, within which they arise and have to be cleared-it is impossible for any elaborate clearance procedure to be maintained. In this instance, a further complicating factor is that it was a joint statement with New Zealand. When I got it, it had already been cleared by the New Zealand minister, as I recall it, but I do not think that that should necessarily be regarded as decisive.
—Don't tell me you are going to blame the New Zealanders.

—I cheerfully acknowledge that it should not be regarded as a decisive consideration, and it was not. There is no question of future statements of this kind having to be cleared, or being cleared, by the Prime Minister. We operate, as always across this enormously diverse and variegated and rapidly evolving foreign affairs field, within certain policy paramaters that are agreed, but the detail is left to the relevant Ministers, and it will go on being so.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. A few minutes ago the Minister said that the speech had crossed his desk and that, therefore, he was prepared to take responsibility. Will he, for my benefit, distinguish that position from the speech reaching the Prime Minister's office or his Department? Why should he not take responsibility for that which passes his desk?

—Firstly, as I have described, it did not. Secondly, I am the Foreign Minister, and I accept the responsibility for what is done in Australia's name by our ambassadors abroad, particularly in circumstances where I have had an opportunity to look at the matter in issue, as was the case here.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. It relates to the recent heavy fighting in Beirut and the resulting danger which has arisen for civilians as well as for the armed forces involved. Under the current circumstances, is the Government planning any special arrangements for Lebanese visitors in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been very concerned at the recent upsurge in internecine warfare in Beirut. It has presented difficulties for Lebanese citizens in Australia who are about to return home. We have, of course, noted today's news that a ceasefire has been agreed between the fighting factions in Beirut. Notwithstanding this positive development, the Government is prepared to extend until 20 June 1989 temporary entry permits for Lebanese visitors in Australia. The extension will be available for those whose temporary entry permits expired after 5 March 1989, when the recent period of significant hostilities in Beirut began. Applications can be made to any regional office of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in Australia. It is expected that people whose temporary entry permits are extended would leave Australia by 20 June. The Government will, of course, continue to monitor the situation in Lebanon closely. Individual cases directly affected by any continuing serious fighting in Beirut will be subject to further review.

ANSWER.PARA: The existing special humanitarian entry arrangements for Lebanon remain in place. These arrangements apply to close relatives of Australian residents who have been seriously and directly affected by the conflict in the past three months, to the extent that they have little or no prospect of resuming their normal life in Lebanon, and for whom resettlement in Australia is the only appropriate course. There has been some concern at the inability of some Lebanese citizens to travel to Damascus to lodge migration applications. While normal processing will continue to be done in that city, I have agreed that my Department will place no impediment in the way of such applications being dealt with also in Cyprus or any other convenient location.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given that the Minister cleared the speech by Ambassador Wilenski to the United Nations General Assembly-the speech that he now accepts was not balanced-did he actually read it? If so, did he make, suggest or request changes when he read the draft? If not, will he once again plead the streaker's defence-that it seemed like a good idea at the time?

—I do not think there is anything really useful that I can add to that. Yes, I did read the speech and, no, I do not recall making any amendment to it. As I recall, my primary preoccupation was whether the vote itself was justified rather than concentrating in any extensive way upon the details of the explanatory speech that went with it. That is one's primary preoccupation on these occasions. I was satisfied, and I remain satisfied, that the vote itself was thoroughly justified by the particular factual circumstances to which it gave rise. I am confirmed in that judgment by the reponse of 128 other countries that voted with us in that respect and I have nothing further to add.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training: Is it correct that funding for the implementation of the national language policy is due to run out on 30 June 1990? Can the Minister inform the Senate as to the amount of funds proposed at this stage to be allocated to the implementation of the national language policy in the 1989-90 financial year? What is the Government's intention with regard to further funding of the implementation of the policy after 1990? Will funding be maintained, increased, decreased, or cut out? Are funds for the implementation of the national language policy intended to cover the funding of specialist training courses for interpreters and translators? If the answer is yes, can the Minister explain why specialist courses for interpreters and translators conducted by Perth Technical College are not funded from this source but are funded instead from mainstream technical education sources?

—As I recall it, that program was to run for three calendar years and, therefore, spread over four financial years which expire with the 1990-91 financial year. I will seek an answer on the other matters from Mr Dawkins.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Australian Government's view of the outcome of talks between the Prime Minister of the People's Republic of Kampuchea (PRK), Hun Sen and the Cambodian resistance leader, Prince Sihanouk, in Jakarta over the past two days? What implications will the outcome have for possible Australian involvement in a resolution of the Cambodian issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been encouraged-if I can speak for the Government-by reports that Prince Sihanouk and the PRK Prime Minister, Hun Sen, made progress in talks in Jakarta on 2 May. The areas of agreement include: changes to the name, the flag and the anthem of Cambodia and acceptance of Buddhism as the state religion; a cessation of external military assistance to each of the factions upon the final withdrawal of Vietnamese forces from Cambodia; changes to the Constitution but with acceptance by both parties of the need to consult further on specific differences of views-that is to say, among other things, over the multi-party system advocated by Prince Sihanouk-the broad composition and role of an international control mechanism but with many contentious details left for further discussion; agreement also on another Hun Sen-Sihanouk meeting to be held on 24 July followed by a round table meeting of all four factions in Paris the following day; agreement on the convening of an international conference with sessions to be held in Jakarta and Paris but with details still to be discussed; and a ceasefire to be put in place instead of Prince Sihanouk's former insistence on an interim quadripartite army.

ANSWER.PARA: However, notwithstanding all those extremely important areas of agreement, Prince Sihanouk and Hun Sen have failed so far to reach broad agreement on a number of what still remain major stumbling blocks, notably, the extent to which the PRK Government should be altered to accommodate the three other Cambodian factions in the interim period before elections, with Hun Sen resisting diminution of the status and the effective exercise of power by his Government. Again, with regard to the Khmer Rouge, Prince Sihanouk is continuing to insist on its inclusion in any interim arrangements which he continues to contend should be quadripartite in nature, while Hun Sen has rejected the idea of the Khmer Rouge taking part in an interim quadripartite coalition, Sihanouk arguing, as he has, that the only way to avoid a prolonged civil war is to include the Khmer Rouge forces in a national army. But that said, while Sihanouk is remaining apparently firm on a quadripartite government, he is also acknowledging that a tripartite government might well be viable if the Khmer Rouge refused to join. He also seems to be implicitly accepting that the interim administration of Cambodia would continue with the PRK authorities on the ground.

While it is the case overall that both of them have shown a welcome degree of flexibility, it is clear that key issues remain to be resolved, particularly regarding power-sharing arrangements among the four Khmer factions and not least, obviously, the role of the Khmer Rouge who were not represented in these talks.

As to Australia's specific reaction, we share the concern of others about the possibility of a civil war developing in Cambodia following Vietnam's troop withdrawal if the Khmer Rouge attempts to return to power. As we have said on innumerable occasions, we are categorically opposed to a return to power by Pol Pot and his senior associates.

A few weeks ago, on 6 March, in answer to a question by Senator Foreman, I indicated Australia's willingness to participate in our International Conference if it were invited to do so. Prince Sihanouk has previously indicated support for Australian participation in an international conference on Cambodia. He confirmed this to me personally when we met in Beijing in January and he did so again yesterday in conversation with our Ambassador in Jakarta, Philip Flood. As both the Prime Minister and I have said on a number of occasions, the Government is willing to consider any request that might be made for us to participate in an appropriate international control mechanism.

My colleague Kim Beazley, the Minister for Defence, is considering the possible logistic implications if Australia were invited to participate in such a mechanism. Obviously, the size of any possible Australian contingent would depend upon the nature of the peacekeeping or monitoring task envisaged. The Minister for Defence and I agree that the most desirable outcome would unquestionably be one whereby the commitment by the various parties to an internal settlement was such that only a very small external monitoring force was required.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security to a statement by the Minister for Finance earlier in Question Time and also to the Acting Treasurer's press release of today's date that today's official consumer price index (CPI) figure of one per cent does not reflect the true underlying rate of inflation in Australia which he said was really 1.6 per cent as calculated on the new basis. By how much money will the Hawke Government cheat and short-change pensioners and others in receipt of indexed incomes by adopting this new, fiddled CPI figure, which is a statutory one, rather than paying rises which reflect what Senator Walsh describes as the true underlying rate of inflation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The basic point that has to be established here is that, as the figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics have been published, those figures will be used. I need to make one point in respect of the June indexation increases that have already been announced. I am advised that the new method of calculation will not affect those figures because they are based on CPI figures for the six months to December 1988 and, as such, they will not be adjusted.

ANSWER.PARA: It should also be recognised that an overwhelming majority of pensioners either own their homes outright or are not buying them. The Government is concerned to ensure that this change will not affect their standards of living. Senator Baume may be concerned about the extent of the Government's commitment to pensioners-which seems to be an underlying part of his question-but I do not think I need at this time of the day to go through all the accomplishments of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't have time.

—As Senator Tate has said, I would not have time. It should be stated explicitly, so that the Opposition can understand, that this Government is committed to improving the incomes of elderly retired people. It has shown that commitment by its very proud record in the area. Since coming to office in March 1983, we have made substantial increases in pension payments. Without going through them all, I should say that in 1988-89 this Government will be spending $7.5 billion on age pensions compared to less than $5 billion spent in 1982-83. I could go on, but I would make a couple of minor points. The rate of single pension and married pension as a percentage of average weekly earnings is much higher than it was under previous governments. We have shown our commitment in that way. In respect of a whole host of incidental programs of assistance both in the area of fringe benefits, income free area, rental assistance and so on, this Government has a proud record of contributing a great degree of financial assistance to alleviate the position of pensioners. The June figures will not be affected and the Government is committed to improving the standard of pensioners' income and will continue to do so.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his assurance that pensioners will not be affected in any way and that their standard of living will not be reduced. I ask him, in order to give integrity to that claim, to please release the old basis of figures for the CPI so that the people of Australia can see by how much they will have been short changed, if they are to be, and if there is no short changing what reason does he possibly have for not revealing what the CPI would have been, as he claims that pensioners will not suffer as a result of the change in the CPI?

—I wish to make a couple of points. Some people in this place never seem to learn. I shall not respond to the underlying cynicism and degree of vin- dictiveness in Senator Baume's question. I will say that I have no reason and neither has the Government to dispute the integrity of the figures. Senator Baume, having had some experience in this place, should know that the release of the figures is totally outside my responsibility. He should know who the relevant Minister is and he should direct that question to him.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some time back Senator Sheil asked me a question concerning national diseases control program termination, and I am now in a position to add to my answer on that occasion. Ross River fever, while unpleasant, is not a fatal disease. It is mosquito borne and can be controlled by reducing mosquito numbers. Commonwealth support of the national diseases control program (NDCP) since 1974-75 had permitted the establishment of infrastructures and programs for the surveillance and control of mosquito borne diseases. With the cessation of the NDCP responsibility for the maintenance of these programs and infrastructures reverted to the States. I understand that the States are continuing to undertake satisfactory mosquito control activities during 1988-89. The Commonwealth continues to fund research into vector borne diseases. In 1988 Commonwealth funding for research in this area was $148,230, including National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) moneys and in 1987-88 national diseases control program research moneys. This increased to $163,490 allocated by the NHMRC in 1989.

ANSWER.PARA: Some concern has been expressed that Australia's scientists who are researching mosquito borne diseases need special consideration outside the NHMRC because they are uncompetitive against other medical research scientists. This is simply not the case. The NHMRC has already recognised the importance and quality of proposals in this area and has provided funding of $418,600 since 1986. Without of course pre-empting NHMRC recommendations, we can continue to expect that high quality proposals from the very capable researchers working on the problem of mosquito borne diseases will continue to attract support from the NHMRC.

DEBATE.TITLE: THE CORE CAPACITY OF AUSTRALIAN SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper extends the discussion which took place in the Senate the other day on a matter of public importance initiated by Senator Puplick. I stress again that we have in this country at present a Government which is anti-intellectual, anti-science and anti-research. The report contains a clear indication that the Committee of the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC), which framed this report, has been infected with the same rather narrow view of the role of science in society. It points to the inability because of core capacity to provide sufficient competence to support projected economic developments and to meet national responsibilities, whatever they are. Again, the emphasis is on economic developments.

As I pointed out the other day, one needs to take a much wider view of science than that. Indeed, there is a need to turn around the perception which the public has of the role of science in society and the role of research. The Government is doing nothing in that respect. It has, by running down the capacity of schools and universities to deliver a good science program, been running down the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and universities research programs. Clearly this has given the public the view that science is not an activity that is worth pursuing. One need only point to an earlier report of ASTEC to draw attention to the incredible divergence between the public's perception of the need to put more funding into the environmental area and the way in which this Government has run down the funding in that area. I point to the science and technology statement 1987-88 report in which it noted in the environment area that long term trends were minus 6.8 per cent per annum, and that short term trends were minus 16 per cent per annum. That contrasts very sharply with the public perception of a need to spend more money in this area.

We also observe as a result of this public perception generated by the Government a 40 per cent drift among the highest achieving students away from the area of science and into other areas of education. If we look at the Australian National University's matriculation marks for acceptance into science and arts and compare those with the situation that obtained only a few years ago where much higher marks were required to get into science-indeed many science courses were hard to enter-we now find at the Australian National University that only 270 marks are required to get into science while 281 marks are required to get into arts. In other words, there is a perception that a pursuit of arts is more profitable than a pursuit of science.

When we look at the post-graduate support scheme, we find that post-graduates-those who have ground their way through many years of tertiary education-can only get research awards amounting to $11,000 a year. This is at a time of life when many of these students are married and perhaps want to start a family. This is particularly relevant to women in post-doctoral positions. It is precisely the time in their lives when they want to move on in their careers and, if they are married, also to start a family. It would be useful if this report had made some recommendation regarding further support for married people in this very critical time in the development of their post-doctoral studies.

The report draws attention to the need for more private funding. Earlier reports have pointed to the lack of private funding in Australia for research. The report correctly draws attention to the fact that many of the major companies in Australia are trans- national and carry on research overseas. This Government and indeed the Opposition by their deregulatory programs are supporting the intrusion of more multinational companies into Australia. Therefore we are likely to see less research carried out in this country rather than more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak briefly to the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) report entitled The Core Capacity of Australian Science and Technology. I find right from the front page that it is a very disturbing report. It will be sufficient if I quote some of the early sentences:

SPEECH.PARA: It is imperative that Australia performs them-
that is, the scientific and technological factors listed in the report-

in such a way that they are able to contribute to that growth and to the quality of life. This involves the effective integration of scientific results and technology with economic developments and other natural responsibilities, as well as the production of a highly skilled workforce. There are worrying deficiencies in Australia's ability to pursue these activities at a proper level. Concerns have been expressed about the adequacy and sources of research and development funding, the deterioration of buildings and equipment, the adequacy of our scientific and engineering workforce, the paucity of good research management practices, the meagre attempts to increase selectivity and concentration of effort in research, and the consequent effects on research productivity.

What a start to a report! We know that this has been happening over a period of years. The situation has gone down and down. The calibre of the people involved is questionable in some cases. We now need to see what we can do to try to recover this situation amongst those involved in science, technology and research in Australia. It is a very difficult situation. We have to concentrate on reading the report's recommendations and thinking of what we will do about the increase in postgraduate award stipends, the increasing of research positions generally and the inclusion of a renewal of the 150 per cent taxation concession. All these sorts of matters have been raised in the report.

Facilities and equipment are a very big problem. It is very difficult indeed for capable students, researchers and scientists to do the research that is necessary for the next century with equipment that is half a century old, in many cases in buildings that are half a century old or more. It will not be possible to bring this recovery about in the short term. The Government has to come to grips with it. I do not mean having a dabble with it on Monday night with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) trying to score a few quick points with a minimum of money. The restoration of the standing of the scientists will be more important than just throwing a handful of money at the problem. We have to show people in Australia that the pursuit of science and technology, and research generally, is a matter of great importance. We have to show them that the brightest people in the community ought to consider a scientific future as a real option. But with the state of the stipend that goes with being a postgraduate student, it is virtually impossible for many of the people we need to be able to carry on on that basis.

The Government has to come to grips with this problem. It is not just a matter of throwing a handful of money at it on a Monday night and the Prime Minister being photographed with a big grin on his face and saying, `What a great job we have done'. Having starved science and technology in Australia for the entire period it has been in office, the Government has to remember that the decline has been in its period. It must accept responsibility for restoring it.

The report deserves a full study. I have not had time to read it all by any means. I suggest that everybody with an interest in the subject should read it and it should be made available for study generally. I am pleased that the report has been completed. I commend those members of ASTEC who were involved in its preparation. I trust that it is one of the ways by which we will be able to retrieve our position. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
