SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) made an announcement at the weekend relating to the 1987-88 annual report on the Australian bicentennial road development program. He announced that in 1989-90 major works on the Hume Highway, including the Goulburn, Yass and Mittagong bypasses and the Cullerin Range deviation, would commence. He said that the major expenditure would initially be targeted at the Goulburn bypass and the Cullerin Range deviation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: By the end of 1993-94 work is expected to have finished on the Mittagong, Goulburn and Yass bypasses.

The fact is that the Fraser Government entered into a commitment in 1982 that the Hume Highway would be a divided road in its entirety by the Bicentennial. That was one of its major commitments under the bicentennial road development program.

This Government, quite soon after it came to office, endorsed that program. Several of its members were pleased to go around electorates beating their breasts about what this Government was going to do. I say to honourable senators that it is a disgrace that Federal road money has been diverted from the essential work of completing the Hume Highway, the most trafficked highway in Australia, so that it is a two carriageway highway between the Victorian border and Sydney. Instead the money was put into a diversion of the highway to Newcastle on the western side of Lake Macquarie. Clearly there were parts of that Newcastle freeway which needed urgent attention because of the huge accident toll that was taking place there. But the fact is that in respect of the Hume Highway, which is a killer road where in the last few weeks we have seen repeated accidents, this Government's actions have resulted in money under the bicentennial road program which would have completed those works in 1988 as planned being deliberately diverted.

The Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support gets up now and makes a big fellow of himself and his Government by promising to complete this work by 1993-94, just five years too late. It will be five years too late for the victims in those accidents who have already suffered and who will inevitably suffer further in the next four years or so. It is a disgrace that this Minister is patting himself on the back for putting out a statement saying all the wonderful things he and his Government will do which should have been completed by last year. My old electorate, which is now, unfortunately, represented in part by Mr Hollis to the extent that Throsby covers part of it, has already suffered in the sense that under the Fraser Government's clearly stated program, agreed by the States, the towns of Mittagong and Berrima were to have been by-passed by 1988 but, instead, only half that work has been done.

This statement by Mr Brown is an absolute disgrace. We must get from the Government a full statement and a full explanation as to why this money was diverted from the Hume Highway to build a great and attractive concrete road west of Lake Macquarie, the traffic volumes on which would be a tiny fraction of that on the Hume Highway but which would serve the area represented by the then Federal Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, and the area of the present Minister for Transport, Mr Robert Brown. If ever there has been an occasion of local pork-barrelling, this is it, at the cost of Australia, at the cost of the main infrastructure link between Melbourne and Sydney and at the cost of all those lives lost on the Hume Highway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Michael Baume on bringing to the attention of the Senate the very real deficiencies in the Government's present road program. We know quite clearly on this side of the House, because we have been raising the issue time and time again here and in the House of Representatives, how the Government has misled the Australian people and failed to meet its obligations to keep road funding up at a reasonable level. We know that the road infrastructure right across the nation is suffering through the neglect of this Government and its failure to meet the obligations which were set for it by the former Fraser Government, particularly through the bicentennial road program.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention one other example of the way in which the Hawke Government, through the current Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) goes about misleading the Australian people as to what is really being done in the road area. We had a Budget announcement some months ago that the Government was proposing to spend $1,250m or thereabouts on roads in this current financial year. We subsequently heard from the Minister that that was such a wonderful amount of money that it would solve all the road problems. He then announced that over a five-year period something like $5 billion would be spent on the nation's roads, but when we came to analyse what the Minister was actually saying, we saw that he simply took this current year's figure, which represents a decline of something like $400m in real terms since this Government came to power, and multiplied it by four to get $5 billion. He then said, `This is some kind of initiative, this is a new move, some kind of promotion of road funding by the Government'. Of course, it is nothing more than just the use of numbers to make a somewhat larger number and confuse the public as to what is really going on.

But the daddy of them all was the misleading that Minister Brown initiated last weekend. Senator Michael Baume has drawn our attention to that. In fact, the Minister announced that out of the Australian centennial roads fund, his new development fund, he was going to spend some $2 1/2 billion on roads. This was presented as some new initiative with new projects in mind but, of course, all it amounted to upon analysis was, again, the use of the number that was set down in the Budget last year, that in itself representing a substantial fall from previous years under the Fraser Government, and multiplying it by two. He then set out to show that certain projects were to be paid for from that fund. He mentioned some of the things which Senator Michael Baume has drawn to our attention, but excluded others.

The point is that the Minister keeps recycling stories about road funding and quoting larger and larger numbers to the point where he is becoming an absolute farce in the eyes of those people who know something about road funding in this country. He is attempting to mislead the Australian people by creating the impression that, by using different numbers for road funding, somehow something extra is being done for roads. In fact, the opposite is true. The fact is, and the simple fact remains, that since the Hawke Government came to power in March 1983 we have seen a fall in road funding in real terms of $400m. That is reflected not only in poorer roads and the difficulty which local government has in keeping up the maintenance of those roads, but also in the very sad effect, which time and time again is reported in our newspapers and on our television screens, of road accidents that kill so many people.

Senator Baume drew our attention to the recent calamity on the Hume Highway. It is time that this Minister started doing things instead of parading before the Australian people trying to create the impression that something is being done when nothing at all has changed since the announcement in the Budget last August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief in responding to this matter. I want to make just one point in response to some of the comments that I have just heard on the bicentennial roads program. It is a constant theme that the condition of Australian roads is responsible-and according to some of the speakers who have involved themselves in this debate, wholly responsible-for serious road accidents, numerous tragic deaths and even, in some cases, perhaps even more horrible, disabling injuries that people carry for a lifetime.
—It is disgraceful.

—Indeed. As someone who has had many years of direct involvement in this area, I will make a point that has to be made in terms of quoting horrific road accidents as evidence of the conditions of the roads around this country. In all the road accidents that I attended-and I have lost count of how many there were, but there were hundreds-I can honestly say that in eight years as a divisional officer with St John Ambulance I cannot remember one single serious road accident resulting in death or serious injury in which alcohol was not involved.
—Have a look at the Hume Highway.

—Let me make it clear that I am not suggesting that the conditions of roads do not contribute to this. Of course they do. I am not suggesting that this is in any way a defence of a lack of road funding by any government, but I make the obvious point that if a person driving on a highway, particularly at a high risk time, particularly Easter weekends and Friday evenings on the way out of town and Sunday evenings on the way back-I personally solve the problem by not even being on the road at these times-with his family, particularly young children, inside the motor vehicle, does not adjust the manner in which he is driving at least to be reasonably consistent with the condition of a bad road, in my view he is behaving in a criminal fashion. The difficulty is that so many people continue to do so. I have no doubt that we can all give numerous examples of driving in bad weather conditions-one of the principal killers-such as fog or heavy rain, slowing down to adjust the speed of the vehicle consistent with those conditions and having vehicle after vehicle overtaking one at high speed. Serious road accidents in this country are still, in the main, caused by driver error, not the condition of the roads. This is also the case for light aircraft accidents. Eighty per cent of fatal light aircraft accidents are caused by pilot error and not air traffic control or the condition of runways.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that while Australians continue to think that they can drink alcohol and then drive, usually at a high speed and get away with it, there will continue to be the horrific road toll which we suffer in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no disagreement with that.

—Senator, I am sure that there will be no disagreement with me on my next point, which is consistent with my basic philosophy on life. I would not lose any sleep if the only people who were ever hurt were the people who were responsible for such behaviour. The great difficulty, of course, is that that is almost never the case. I know, as I am sure we all do, of tragic cases. I can think of one case in which the person responsible for condemning children to a lifetime of misery in a wheelchair got off scott free. The great difficulty is drinking and driving. I am not saying that the condition of the roads does not contribute to the problem but when finally Australians come to grips with driving responsibly there will be far fewer accidents and far less death and injury on our roads.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments. I have received a very disconcerting letter from one of my constituents. No doubt many other senators have received similar letters from pharmacists who are concerned about the Government's intention to reduce expenditure on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) by some $31m in 1989-90 and $96m in 1990-91. My pharmacist constituent understands, as do I, that the latest proposal is to reduce the wholesale mark-up on drugs to 10 per cent; to adopt a professional fee of $3.30, which is less than 25 per cent; and to pay an annual pharmacy practice allowance of $15,000. This pharmacist from New Town, Tasmania, estimates that this proposal, if accepted, will reduce his return by approximately 48c per prescription which amounts to nearly $15,000 per annum. Taken with the previous decision to double maximum quantities, this will result in a further reduction of $10,000 in a full year. He states also that his wholesaler charges of 5 per cent loading on the cost price quoted for pharmaceutical benefit items, plus the normal increases in award rates, plus a reduction in the working week from 40 hours to 38, plus the 3 per cent allowance superannuation contribution, plus an additional rent of some $4,000-which are all the norm these days-represent a total reduction in his income of about $35,000 per annum.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is happening to pharmacists around Australia it can only be described as a deliberate act of `pharmacy bashing' by this Government. I believe that the real problem, which is alluded to in the report, is the decision which was taken two years ago to include a range of very expensive new drugs in the pharmaceutical benefits list.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might check how much their incomes went up.

—A blind man could have seen that that was going to cause a blow-out. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) made it quite obvious that he was going to reduce the PBS by $300m over the next three years and this Government has tried different ways to do that. This latest attack is just another attempt to make the pharmacists the whipping boy and, of course, it is causing great discomfort.

SPEECH.PARA: Pharmacists, up until now, have had no real arguments with the Government but in my own State, pharmacists closed their doors for three hours. For honourable people to take action like that indicates to me that they are really being hurt. We can expect to see a lot more action by pharmacists around Australia if this sort of treatment continues. There is no doubt that we will see new attempts to reduce further outlays through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority. I am very interested to see what will be said in the annual report next year when it is presented to this Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always interested in keeping an eye on things to do with sport. I am very pleased to have the opportunity to comment on some matters contained in the Australian Institute of Sport annual report 1987-88.

SPEECH.PARA: This very interesting report relates to the period in which the Institute faced a Government recommendation that the Commonwealth Government sports assistance be streamlined by combining the Institute with the Australian Sports Commission. A fair amount of modification and adaptation has had to occur as a consequence of that proposal. In particular, there have been financial savings and benefits to sport expenditure. Also, there has been some rationalising of the use of the facilities. I believe, and I have heard no complaints to the contrary, that that amalgamation is proceeding successfully. I will be interested to read in the next annual report a description of how that amalgamation has proceeded. It is interesting to read about the sports which are promoted by the Institute and where they are located in line with the decentralisation of sport around this country.

I want to highlight a couple of the groups, or individuals, who have benefited from their association with the Australian Institute of Sport. One in particular who is referred to in this report is Kerry Saxby. Kerry Saxby is a largely unknown and unsung world record holder who is not able to compete in significant international events or Olympic events precisely because they do not include walking races for women. Still to this point, Kerry Saxby is not likely to win a gold medal in most of the events in which she participates and in which she holds world records, because those events are still not in the Olympic program.

Kerry Saxby has been extraordinarily successful. She holds records for the 5 kilometre, 10 kilometre and 20 kilometre walks. I think most honourable senators would know of her very recent success in Hungary the week before I visited that country. I would have loved to have been there to have cheered for her. She not only wins but she continues to break her own world record times. I am very pleased that Kerry has been able to benefit from assistance from the Australian Institute of Sport. I believe it is a hard business being a distance runner or a distance walker. I suspect that being a distance walker would be even harder than being a distance runner. Perhaps there is no way we can compare those two, but for people who are performing in those sorts of events and at that sort of level of excellence, something like the Australian Institute of Sport is very important for backup and encouragement, as well as assistance with coaching, assessment of health, provision of equipment and so on to keep people at that level of fitness and support. The Institute has an important role in contributing to some of our excellent performers. In particular, I cite here Kerry Saxby.

Another group of sportswomen that I would like to comment on who have taken a lot of assistance and support from the Institute is the women's hockey team. I am not quite sure what I could conclude here, seeing that the men have also benefited from the Institute. Can I conclude that the women benefited more and therefore won the gold medal, or is it unfair to make those kinds of comparisons? It is certainly true that the women's hockey team has had many of its members as scholarship holders at the Institute of Sport. Certainly we all enjoyed the game enormously. Many of us were in the same airport terminal watching the last 10 minutes of the Australian women's hockey game in which they won that gold medal. For once, honourable senators were completely unanimous in their decision. We were absolutely thrilled. I am also pleased to note that the women's hockey team, on returning to Australia, promptly lost its sponsorship, which seems to raise a question of what a team has to do to keep its sponsorship. However, I understand that in recent weeks or months Telecom Australia has come to the party and sponsored the women's hockey team with a very large sponsorship. That is also a matter for considerable celebration.

Finally, I would like to say that netball is a sport that has enjoyed assistance from the Institute of Sport. It is with great pleasure that I can say, following a letter I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that there is now a Prime Minister's Cup for Australian women's netball. The first time that will be presented and won will be at the Esso Super League competition next year. It may well be that the Australian Institute of Sport netball team will be able to take out the first Prime Minister's Cup.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I am speaking to the annual reports of the Australia-Japan Foundation and the Australian Heritage Commission together because I simply want to make a point very briefly about their tardiness. The Australia-Japan Foundation annual report first came before the Senate on 11 April 1989 and the Australian Heritage Commission annual report on 13 April 1989, covering the period to 30 June 1988. They provide further examples of disgracefully late reporting, reporting which would not be tolerated by the private sector, by the stock exchanges and so on where the public's money is involved. Here, public money is involved and this sort of late reporting cannot be justified.

What is particularly annoying about the Australia-Japan Foundation annual report is that the Chairman's letter to Senator Gareth Evans bears no date, so we have no idea when the report got presented to the Government. We have no idea why it is so late, particularly as it was audited, according to the Auditor-General's letter, on 22 December. In other words, there were no accounting problems delaying the presentation of this report.

I remind the Senate that ministerial approval has to be given to delay any report longer than its prescribed six-month period from the end of the financial year concerned. I wonder what justification was given, what excuse was made to the Minister and why he acceded to the request to table the report so late. I add in passing that I was interested to see that there was a 63 per cent increase in resources provided free of charge to the Australia-Japan Foundation, increasing from $286,000 to almost $480,000, meaning that the Foundation itself cost something like $2.3m of which only about $1m goes out in grants and so on to those bodies which benefit from this organisation. It seems to be a very large administrative cost to benefits received ratio.

The Chairman of the Australian Heritage Commission has failed to date his letter also, so we cannot tell whether the Government sat on the report or whether the Commission itself was dilatory in presenting it to the Government. This sort of thing has to stop. It is becoming a nonsense. Apparently, the Government has no control over the commissions, boards and bodies that it is supposed to supervise and it ought to smarten itself up. The Government should insist that these bodies behave in a proper and responsible way. Mr Galvin could perhaps get around to finding a date stamp and advise the Senate of the date that his covering note came.

I wonder also what excuse was given to the Minister to enable him to agree that the report should be brought down later than the statutory six months, as required. I note here that once again the Auditor's report was December 1988, so there is no financial justification for any delay. The Australian Heritage Commission owes the Senate an explanation about its dilatoriness in getting out this report. Nonetheless, at least it did better than the Australian Special Rural Research Council whose report was dealt with here the day before yesterday. It managed to have its covering letter dated November 1987; it related to the previous year's annual report. It had not got around to changing the covering letter. It said:
. . . the . . . Council submits its Annual Report for the period 1 July 1986 to 30 June 1987.

In fact, it was its annual report for the financial year 1987-88. This sort of clumsiness by the Research Council I hope does not extend to its handing out of funds. It certainly does not say much for the Government Minister involved, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr John Kerin, who paid such close attention to the annual report that he did not notice it had the wrong letter in it!
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 May, on motion by Senator Collins:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matters I wish to raise relate to an interview I heard this morning with my colleague the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Peter Dowding, a leading figure in the Australian Labor Party whom I hold in some respect. The interview related to the operations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody in Western Australia. I regretfully advise the Senate that I will be canvassing this issue at some length later this evening. I apologise to everyone for that. I am not a consistent speaker in the adjournment debate, but it is necessary that I do so this evening. I imagine that I will be speaking for the full half-hour tonight. The report on the death of Malcolm Charles Smith is one of the matters to which I will be referring tonight in relation to the comments made this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: It is absolutely essential for the expeditious conduct of the Commission so that it can report by the due date that an additional commission be appointed in Western Australia. The major reasons for that are that Western Australia, with 34 deaths, has by far the largest problem statistically. The problem is complicated even further by the fact that, regrettably, police officers and prison officers are refusing to cooperate with the Commission. Mr Justice Muirhead, the original Commissioner for Western Australia, had his responsibilities as national Commissioner as well, which meant that work has not been proceeding in Western Australia as expeditiously as it might.

Premier Dowding has some concerns, which I share, about the appointment of a second commissioner on the ground that the royal commission was simply going over ground that had already been covered by coronial inquiries. My concern was not dispelled until I had read from cover to cover the seven reports that have so far been tabled. That concern has now been completely dispelled. One of those reports is the report into the death of Malcolm Charles Smith. I regret to say that the perception that the Commission is simply covering the same ground covered by coronial inquiries is not correct. Unfortunately, not only is the Commission not doing that but also its work has revealed the most appalling problem with the standards of coronial inquiries throughout Australia.

One of the reports, among others, that indicates this is the very report that we are debating now. The coroner in this case found that Malcolm Charles Smith committed suicide. The Commission found that Malcolm Charles Smith did not. That is as substantive a difference as it is possible to get. Malcolm Charles Smith certainly took his own life and that was found by the Commission, but it was not suicide, and the evidence presented to the Commission, which would have been as readily available to the coronial inquiry, emphatically led to that conclusion. The decision of the coroner in the case was in fact wrong. On page 66 of this report we find these words:
I find that Malcolm Smith's death was caused by his own action in driving the paint brush into his eye with his own hand.
Further, the Commission said about this tragic and horrible death:
I find that Malcolm Smith did not intend to kill himself and accordingly that his death was not suicide.

The Commission goes on to point out that the coroner also made an error in finding that Malcolm Smith had made two previous suicide attempts. The evidence clearly points out that they were not suicide attempts at all but were driven by the biblical injunction to pluck out his own eye. They were caused by an overwhelming sense of guilt because of a life he had taken and two previous attempts to remove his eye, one of which resulted in the lens being lost from the eye and the eye being blinded.

In the brief time available to me I conclude by saying that it is clear that the Commission is not canvassing the same ground as the coronial inquiries. It is, however, in this extremely valuable exercise into the deaths themselves, revealing some very disturbing deficiencies in the standard of coronial inquiries in Australia which, I have no doubt, will lead to the very positive result of a set of recommendations at the end of this Commission's work, leading in turn to a far better standard of coronial inquiries round Australia from which everyone will benefit. As I said before, I will canvass these issues at greater length in the adjournment debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 May, on motion by Senator Michael Baume:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The financial statements of the Office of Defence Production are yet another example of tardy, inadequate, incompetent reporting. This annual report was tabled on 2 May and, as I look through the Auditor-General's reports on the various factories under the Office of Defence Production I find that generally they were audited by 24 November or early in December. Once again I wonder whether the Government would like to provide us with evidence of the justification claimed and the excuses given by the bodies involved as to why they should be given dispensation to present their reports late.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again we have an example of an inability to put a date on a letter. In his audited report on the Small Arms Factory, Lithgow, the Auditor-General has inserted no date, so it is impossible to tell whose fault it is that this report was not presented in time, although the statement by the general manager and the principal accounting officer is dated 24 November 1988, so it appears that there were no financial reasons why this report should have been delayed.

I mention in passing that the Small Arms Factory at Lithgow has managed to increase the value of its plant and machinery by 50 per cent during the year without bothering to make any mention of that in the written report. Apparently that is a matter of such little consequence as not to merit comment. The Auditor's report on the Maribyrnong Ordnance Factory is dated 2 December. Once again the Auditor has qualified the accounts, saying:

. . . the `work-in-progress' component of stock was not subject to adequate stocktake or other verification procedures during 1987-88. Consequently the closing balance of this item may not accurately reflect the true balance.

I might say that, throughout this report, the Auditor-General has noted some difficulties with the standard of financial reporting by the bodies involved. The next matter with which I have some concern is the report concerning Williamstown Dockyard. We have continual problems with this. The Auditor-General, on 20 December 1988, reported:
Stores stock and work-in-progress were not subject to stocktake or other verification procedures during the period.
He concluded:

Due to the lack of adequate supporting records the following items could not be satisfactorily verified-trade and other creditors, prepayments, trade debtors, accrued expenses, provision for annual leave, provision for long service leave, contingent liabilities, receipts from debtors, payments to creditors and payment of wages and redundancies.

That is a total condemnation of accounting practices involving multimillions of dollars of taxpayers's assets. Fortunately, the Williamstown Dockyard is being sold into another operation. I turn now to the Garden Island Dockyard, which has managed to make a loss of $1.9m on sales totalling $132m. The Auditor's report on this dockyard was dated 22 February. Clearly, there were financial problems in this respect. The Auditor-General reported:

. . . I am unable to ascertain whether the financial statements are in agreement with the accounts and records of the Dockyard and in my opinion, the statements are not based on proper accounts and records.

That is absolutely damning. The number of occasions on which we see organisations run by this Government on which Auditors' reports say that accounts are simply not kept is just unbelievable. Multimillion dollars of public money are involved. The Auditor-General continued:

Further, for the reasons set out below I am unable to form an opinion as to whether the statements show fairly the financial transactions for the Dockyard for the year ended 30 June 1988 and the state of affairs of the Dockyard as at that date.
The total amount of the discrepancy-
this relates to the balance in the trust account-
was not able to be quantified, although an opening balance discrepancy of $573,961 was identified.
The statement made by the Manager, Finance, of the Garden Island Dockyard says that the accounts:

. . . in our opinion show fairly the operations and state of affairs of the dockyard except for the amounts disclosed for debtors and trade and other creditors. These items are not satisfied reconciled to the General Ledger of the dockyard at balance date and are therefore considered to be materially inaccurate.
It is incredible that this sort of thing goes on. I suppose it is comforting that the statement then goes on to say:
There are reasonable grounds to believe that the dockyard will be able to pay its debts as and when they fall due.

I notice that this establishment, along with other government establishments, is to become part of a government-owned company entitled Australian Defence Industries. This organisational change came into effect from 1 April this year. This is an April Fool's joke. If this means that these bodies will no longer have to report directly to this Parliament so that we can scrutinise their incompetence and incapable financial accounting, this is an April Fool's joke in extremely bad taste.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 May, on motion by Senator Jenkins:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with the motion to take note of the annual report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission of Australia, I want to refer for the first time in the Senate, but not for the first time, to a very important issue arising here in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). The issue arises out of that section of the report which deals with the regional arrangement between the Human Rights Commission-if I might use that short title-and the various State governments to act in agency relationship on behalf of the commission, while also discharging their obligations under State equal opportunity legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I made a call some 12 months ago for the Human Rights Commission, as it then was, to establish an office here in Canberra, not as a national office-I still support the transfer of the national office to Sydney-so that there may be effective local access for those people who need the assistance of the Human Rights Commission here in Canberra without having to go to Sydney. For many of us, going to Sydney for access to public sector instrumentalities is a very straightforward matter. Apart from that, there is the capacity to make telephone contact. However, the very nature of the people who need the support of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is such that they are less likely to have the time during working hours to go to Sydney or, if they have the time, have the money to make the trip, and less able to make effective telephone communications, if they have the money for the call.

Canberra is the only capital city in Australia which has no representation concerning human rights of any sort. Of course, there are many States where there is an effective agency relationship, and there are other States which have regional offices of the Human Rights Commission. My first request was that there should be a regional office of the Human Rights Commission in Canberra. That is very difficult to achieve, is expensive and I understand the difficulties which the Commission has faced. But we are now in the situation where an ACT Government is to be formed next week, and I want to put firmly on its agenda, as a very high priority, that it should move to establish, in an agency relationship with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, a local anti-discrimination board which can deal with the relevant local legislation, some of which exists and some of which should very quickly be enacted. That authority could then act as the local agency to represent the Human Rights Commission dealing with the national aspect of the Race Relations Act, the Sex Discrimination Act and other human rights problems.

The nature of the demand for such representation is fairly easily discerned when one considers the nature of the groups which have come forward to support the calls that I and others have made to establish this Canberra office of the Human Rights Commission. I was gratified, in the first instance, to have the support of the Ethnic Communities Council of the ACT, because one of its concerns is that people who have difficulty with the English language, and who have recently entered this country, are disproportionately represented in their early years in the lower socio-economic groups of our society, and do not have the capacity to effectively liaise with a Sydney-based office, even if they are aware of its existence.

If we can get a one-stop shop here in Canberra, where they may not be sure whether they are dealing with ACT or Commonwealth legislation, they will know that if they have a question concerning discrimination it is to that office that they should go. That will substantially enhance such access to the rights of the citizens of Canberra, and the citizens in the regions of surrounding New South Wales. I hope that the New South Wales Government will see its way clear to make a contribution through the contribution it currently makes to the anti-discrimination board, and some of its work may be conducted here. Other groups, such as the Women's Electoral Lobby and the Council for the Rehabilitation of the Disabled, have also come forward, recognising the importance of access to this very important body, and they support the call.

I hope that this call today will be the first in what will be a very short and, hopefully, quickly successful campaign to put on the agenda of the newly-elected ACT Government the establishment of an agency which can deal with anti-discrimination matters here in Canberra and be the local agent of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission which, I hope, will be pleased to contribute to that agency relationship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, this is yet another annual report for the year to 30 June 1988 which has been presented to us in May 1989. Once again, it is unjustifiably late. Naturally I would like to know what excuse has been given for the Minister to give dispensation to allow this report to be more than six months late. It is supposed to be presented within six months of the balance date. The letter from the Secretary of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to the Deputy Prime Minister was dated 21 December 1988, and presumably this report has been sitting in his office doing nothing but gather dust for at least five months.

SPEECH.PARA: I say in passing that it is unfortunate when organisations like this end up being used to make political scoring points about individual State governments. I refer in particular to the way in which complaints launched under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 are dealt with on page 27, where it notes:
The overwhelming majority of complaints made by Aborigines were made in Queensland.

While I recognise that that is a valid point to make, I am intrigued that South Australia, which has almost the same volume of complaints lodged under the Racial Discrimination Act, is not mentioned. I wonder why Queensland is picked out and not South Australia where 40 of the 205 complaints launched come from. One would have thought that that merited some kind of recognition. If it is to pick out Queensland, how about talking about South Australia?

South Australia, under the Sex Discrimination Act, seems to be going for some kind of record. Naturally, there is no political point to be made by scoring off a Labor Government in South Australia but there are points to be made against a National Party Government in Queensland. In South Australia, complaints launched under the Sex Discrimination Act 1988 totalled 188 out of 440 throughout Australia. That is an absolutely incredible proportion-something like 45 per cent. In fact, complaints on the basis of sex totalled 91 in South Australia, as against 193 for the whole of Australia. So roughly half the total number of objections under the Sex Discrimination Act related to South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —A sign of a liberated State.

—Senator Cook says that this is because it is a liberated State. I hope that that was a whimsical interjection. If liberation means that one is subject to greater sexual harassment, maybe Senator Cook does not make a very good case for liberation.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, in New South Wales only 46 complaints were lodged, against, as I said, a total of 188 from South Australia. I simply wanted to draw to the attention of the Senate the different treatment of different States in this report, depending on the colour of their governments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on the annual report of the Human Rights Commission. I want to refer in particular to two areas of the Commission's brief. The report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission attempts to act as a catalyst in relation to human rights issues and concerns within the Australian community. By undertaking practical and targeted research the Commission is assisted in formulating realistic strategies and recommendations.
It also stated:
One of the key responsibilities of the Commission is to conduct programs of public or community education in order to promote awareness and understanding of human rights issues.

In the light of that brief, I should like to spend a couple of minutes on the question of the right to work, particularly as it applies to women, in the public and the private sectors. I intend, in due course, to write to the Human Rights Commission and draw its attention to the need to target research in this area and, ultimately, to create community awareness about two problems that I intend to raise.

The first problem concerns the question of the increasing number of women who are forced to do shift work or to go to and from work late at night, particularly in cities around Australia. In many areas where they work-whether hospitals, shops that open late at night, or other areas of employment-there seems to be a real problem in terms of security. I refer here to women who, for example, have to go to their cars or take trains or other forms of public transport. This is one area that I do not think has been considered particularly carefully by any number of organisations that have the responsibility to look at people's rights.

If we are talking about the right of women to involve themselves in the work force, and the fact that, these days, many women are forced to work unusual hours, it is important that the community recognise that we have to consider their safety, particularly in cities. That means that employers must look, for example, at car parks and at public transport. The authorities must look at public transport, to ensure that women have safe passage to and from work. Of course, this applies to men from time to time, but women are particularly vulnerable in this area. If one looks, for example, at the attacks that have been made against women, one finds that in many cases they happen around hospitals or other places where women are forced to work unusual hours-going to and from work at nine, 10 and 11 o'clock in the evening. Many of the institutions that employ those women have done very little about providing safety and security for them.

The second point that I wish to raise very briefly concerns the question of entry into the Public Service, at both State and Federal levels. Again, if women's right to work is important, if their right to earn a reasonable living is important, it is time that we examined some of the recruitment and assessment procedures that prevail in the Public Service, at both Commonwealth and State levels. For example, if one looks at the sorts of qualifications that are required and the salaries that are offered, one finds that there are generally two groups of people which broadly represent the type of women who come into the Public Service at a certain level. The first consists of graduates who, generally speaking, do fairly well. They enter at a higher level of remuneration, conditions and promotable positions than others do. There is another group-young women who come in at a very low level of remuneration and of grading. Then there is a third group, and these are the ones about whom I wish particularly to talk; I particularly want the Human Rights Commission to have a look at their cases.

These are the women who, for example, have qualifications that may not be at a tertiary level, are probably in their middle thirties, forties or early fifties, and are looking for employment for various reasons-maybe marriage breakdown, or maybe because the family is poor or the husband is out of work. There are various factors. Those women do not have the ease of access to the Public Service that they should have and, in particular, they do not have the level of remuneration that may be necessary for them to support a family.

Those are the two issues that I shall be raising with the Human Rights Commission, in the hope not only that it will investigate this area but also that, at the conclusion of its investigations, it will be able to carry out community salesmanship in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

—In talking to the human rights report I would like to take the opportunity, first of all, of paying tribute to the Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, for his report into homeless children in Australia. I think that that report has been mentioned in this place previously. This much-needed and very comprehensive report draws Australia's attention to an area of tragedy that should not happen and, hopefully, will not happen in the foreseeable future. I wish to take the opportunity also of acknowledging the appointment of Mr Kevin O'Connor as a privacy commissioner. He is not mentioned in this report, but--

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. As I have indicated, my Bill does two things: firstly, it reduces the violence allowed in videos; and, secondly, it abolishes X-rated videos.
