SPEECH.PARA: All States expressed opposition to the introduction of the new `Non Violent Erotica' category as discussed by the Joint Select Committee in its recommendations. They also indicated that the present `X' classification would not be introduced to the States. The Federal Attorney-General indicated that he would take the matter back to the Government for consideration and the future of `X' rated material in the Australian Capital Territory would depend upon what the Government decides.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would know, Caucus decided against the advice of all the Attorneys-General throughout Australia. This Government is responsible for refusing to carry out the advice of all the Attorneys-General and the wishes of all the States. I was disappointed in Senator Macklin's speech. He spoke only about that part of my Bill that related to X-rated videos. I believe that excessively violent videos are of great concern to the community. I am sorry that Senator Macklin did not seem to think that that part of my Bill was worthy of mention. His major concern was that, if X-rated videos were abolished, it might send them underground. He likened this to the fact that making drugs illegal does not stop their being abused in our community.

I would ask Senator Macklin if he were present whether he believes that child pornography, which is presently illegal in this country, should be legalised simply because some of it is available underground. I sincerely hope that he would not. There is no doubt that, if some X-rated videos and excessively violent videos were banned, they might go underground. But with child pornography all those young people growing up who will not seek the underground illegal market will have that material available to them at the shop next to the supermarket if my Bill is not passed. This material is being condoned by being freely available legally.

As Senator Hill pointed out in his speech, all the women's organisations in this country are virtually unanimous on this issue. Only one women's organisation, the Women in Science Enquiry Network Incorporated, opposed my Bill. But even that organisation believed that perhaps my Bill should attack the education side of this matter. I would like, once again, to quote what those women's organisations had to say. The Women's Electoral Lobby (ACT) Inc. said:

WEL ACT endorses the intent of your Bill to ban X-rated videos in the ACT. We believe that it is inappropriate for the ACT to continue to distribute X-rated videos in the face of the contrary decisions of the Attorneys-General in all States.
The Catholic Women's League says that it is:
. . . angered at the lack of action on the part of the Federal ALP Caucus on the matter of X-rated videos.
It was unanimous in wanting them abolished. The Country Women's Association of New South Wales urgently requested the Federal Government to:
. . . ban importation, production, sale and hire of XER rated video tapes within Australia.

That organisation was very much in support of my Bill. The National Association of Community Based Children's Services was also very much in favour of the Bill. The National Status of Women Committee said:

The Committee unanimously resolved to inform you that it supports your belief that the unanimous recommendation of all State Attorneys-General that X-rated videos be banned in all states and the ACT should be implemented.
The National President of the Women's Action Alliance (Australia) wrote:
Women's Action Alliance is pleased to hear that the Opposition is taking this action, as we were most disappointed that the Labor caucus saw fit to vote as it did.
The Labor member for Forde, Ms Crawford, said:
Children's innocence is to be prized and their introduction to sex should not be through a fifth-rate pornographic video.
The Social Responsibility Department of the Mother's Union in Australia-it has members in 24 dioceses of the Anglican Church-said:

We also believe that it is illogical for the Government to support such projects as `Fair Go for Women' and `Affirmative Action' which seek to improve the status of women in the community while allowing the free availability of material which depict women as mere objects for male sexual gratification.

The Australian Church Women came out very strongly in favour of my Bill. The Society of Women Writers Australia supported my Bill. The War Widows' Guild of Australia also supported my Bill. The Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women Inc. support my Bill. The list goes on. This Government, which believes that it can ignore all the women's organisations throughout Australia, has a lot to learn. Women are concerned. Women feel very vulnerable. Yet members of the Australian Labor Party sitting opposite today are just not concerned at all. They show no concern in the matter. I felt quite sorry for Senator Zakharov. She had to resort to the Office of the Status of Women to get some support. She quoted it as saying:

The Office is satisfied that the guidelines, as they now stand, will operate in such a way as to prohibit such material as is likely to cause direct or indirect physical or psychological harm to women, while maintaining the rights of individuals to develop their own view of life, without direction from the state or the majority.

Senator Zakharov could find only one group-the Office of the Status of Women which is attached to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet-to support her view. Let us look at the evidence that that office gave before the Joint Select Committee on Video Material as it throws a totally different light on it. I would like to quote from some of the evidence that the Office the Status of Women gave. Early in its evidence I asked Ms Kelly:
Have you seen any X-rated videos?
She said no. Ms Knight said:
It is not the practice of the Office of the Status of Women to require personnel to view X-rated videos.
Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you! I asked her:
Can you tell me then how you have come to the decision that you are happy about it?

Those people had not viewed the material but their advice to the responsible Minister was that they were happy about it. I asked, `If you have not seen that material how did you come to the view that you were happy about it?'. Ms Kelly said:

I think the Office of the Status of Women is required to advise on a range of things with which we may not have personal experience, such as domestic violence, et cetera. We do advise on these things, taking into account all the information available to us.
My response to that was:
I can assure you that I had no idea until I saw the stuff, and before that I would probably have given the same response as you.

Those people said that, when they were dealing with the old X-rated violent videos, they had put in a previous submission and that that first submission showed concern when violence was depicted. They went on to say:

However, that is not to say that we as an office have not had concerns in particular about videos which relate to subordination and exploitation both in violence and other forms, but given that the expression of `violence' was our major concern, we have said that since violence was repealed we are happier with the new guidelines because they omit violence as an acceptable vehicle.

I asked, `What do you mean by ``happier''?, and Ms Knight said, `Well, that is relative'. I said, `Would you like to see any changes made?'. Bearing in mind that they had not seen it but they knew that it exploited women and made women subordinate, the reply was:

As I have indicated, we do have concern that any medium which gives expression to the depiction of women in a subordinate and exploitative situation, particularly in the sexual context, is an impediment to the status of women.

I do not think anyone in this chamber has any doubt that we have not at one time or another realised that we have become desensitised to the use of unacceptable language or to the viewing of violence either in the news or in films. We all know that today, when we hear on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation broadcasts certain expletives in conversations that were previously considered unacceptable, we no longer turn a hair. We all know that this is fact. We do become desensitised. Yet there seems to be a lack of acceptance of this by Labor senators opposite. They do not believe that regular viewing of violence, and indeed sexual violence, so readily found in all these videos, leads to the desensitisation of the viewer, even though so many experts have brought this evidence to our Committee. This is just not acceptable. We must not allow, or even run the risk of allowing, these videos to desensitise our population. The cost is too great.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said that now that the Australian Capital Territory has self-government, he will pass the buck of legislation for the legalisation or otherwise of X-rated videos in the Territory. Obviously he is unaware of the fact, or has not taken the interest or the time to find out, that the jurisdiction for the importation of X-rated videos rests solely with the Federal Government-it rests with this Government and this Government alone. The Australian Capital Territory has no control over the importation of X-rated videos. Evidence given by the Attorney-General to our Committee made it very clear that virtually all the X-rated videos were imported, mainly from the United States of America. It is not the Australian Capital Territory Government that has control in this area; it is the Federal Government, and it is no use the Prime Minister trying to pass the buck.

Last month the Prime Minister launched Domestic Violence Awareness Month. I ask: How sincere is he? The Prime Minister should understand, although I am sure he does not, that domestic violence is not only physical violence but also emotional and psychological violence. Many women are fully aware of the degrading way in which emotional violence works. How can the Prime Minister profess to show concern for women victims in these situations yet condone videos which degrade women in an unbelievable way? The women's organisations, particularly the Mothers Union of Australia, have put the matter very well. I would like to reread the following pages:

We believe it is illogical for the Government to support such projects as `fair go to women' and affirmative action which seek to improve the status of women in the community while allowing the free availability of material which depicts women as mere objects for male sexual gratification.

I can only say, `How true'. We cannot try to improve the status of women at the same time as allowing our sex to be so degraded. Senator Jenkins in her speech referred to the fact that I had limited the ban or importation of videos to X-rated videos. As I understood her concern, it was that she felt that I had not extended it to the importation of extra violent videos. The X-rated videos are imported. We have been told that none are produced in Australia. They are easily identified. As for the reduction of violence, the type of violence to which I have referred, I believe that the Film Censorship Review Board can deal with that type of video, making its interpretation of the words I suggest, whether the videos are made in Australia or imported.

Senator Zakharov in her speech showed what little work she had done on the Bill. I quote from her speech to underline her lack of credibility in this area. She had not even read my Bill. Senator Zakharov said:
I think it is notable that Senator Walters's private member's Bill does not address the question of the portrayal of violence yet this is something that is of great concern to the community . . .
What rubbish! My Bill does two things. It downgrades violence in videos and it bans X-rated videos. Senator Zakharov went on:
To save the time of the Senate, I have not addressed the details and wording of Senator Walters's Bill.
She did not even address it by reading it. She ignored that part of my Bill and then claimed that it did not exist. So credibility for Senator Zakharov in this debate just does not exist.

A recent report was put out following research undertaken by Check and Sommers in the United States of America involving 44 women who suffered severe battering by their male partners. They were compared with a control group of women who had not had any battering-no domestic violence. It was found that the partners of the battered women were high consumers of pornography, in the form of both videos and magazines, while the partners of the control group were not. I foreshadow amendments to my Bill to carry out my original intention to allow:
. . . depictions of matters of such educational, cultural, scientific, historical or cinematographic significance that is in the public interest for it to be classified.
As the Bill stands, these exceptions relate only to videos depicting excessive violence. However, I also meant it to apply to X-rated videos. The amendments that I foreshadow read as follows:
(1) Page 4, subclause 5 (3), line 23, after ``subsection (2)'', insert: ``and subject to subsection (5)''.
(2) Page 5, subclause 5 (5), line 7, leave out ``Subsection (4) does not'', insert: ``Subsections (2), (3) and (4) do not''.
Finally, I make an appeal to all those honourable senators who intend to vote on this Bill. I appeal, as the bishops have done, to the Labor Party to allow its senators a conscience vote--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity they did not allow women bishops.

—I make my appeal to them, to honourable senators in this chamber and to those who are about to come into the chamber-and I pick up Senator Collins's smart alec comment. I say to him and all senators who are to vote: Would you be happy for your young daughter or your young son to view X-rated videos as an introduction to sex? Does the honourable senator believe that their viewing of that sort of material would lead to a happy healthy relationship in their future life? It is no use saying that they cannot see them. It is no use saying that parents would have control over whether they would see them. We have had too much anecdotal evidence which says that the children view these videos at their friends' homes while their parents are out, that older brothers and sisters hire them, that they set up video clubs and vie with each other to see who can get the worst of the films.
—Good anecdotal evidence.
—Senator Collins was not on the Committee when this evidence was given. Senator Collins is a very new member of the Committee and he did not hear the evidence that was given to us.
—I read every page of the transcipt.
—Order! Senator Walters, address your remarks through the Chair please. Senator Collins, Senator Walters has the floor.

—As I said, Senator Collins was not present when that evidence was given to us. So, it is of no use saying that these films are not viewed by children. I have had people whom I know well say to me how horrified they were that their young child in going to a birthday party, unsupervised by the child's parents, had viewed this material. When asked, `Why didn't you walk out?', the child said, `Oh Mum' All my friends were there. How could I do that?'.
—Where were the parents?

—Senator Aulich just interjected, `Where were the parents?'. He did not listen. I said that the parents were out. There is no way that any parent, or even Senator Aulich, could possibly mollycoddle his children so much as to know where they are every minute of the day and night. There is no possible way that it is healthy for Senator Aulich to mollycoddle his children to that extent. Parents have to allow the child some freedom. There are occasions when a parent cannot possibly stop the viewing of this material by their children.

SPEECH.PARA: If this Senate is serious in holding the view that the status of women in Australia should be improved, that women have a right to feel secure both in their homes and on the streets of Australia, in line with all of the views of those women's organisations that I have quoted this afternoon, I seek its support for my Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clause 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may be best for consideration of this amendment to be postponed, as it is consequential upon an amendment that I will be moving later. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: That consideration of clause 4 be postponed until a later hour.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Clause 5 (Classification standards).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, subclause 5 (3), line 23, after ``subsection (2)'', insert: ``and subject to subsection (5)''.
(2) Page 5, subclause 5 (5), line 7, leave out ``Subsection (4) does not'', insert ``Subsections (2), (3) and (4) do not''.

Amendment No. (1) seeks to carry out my original intention that matters depicting education, cultural, scientific, historical and cinematographic significance of public interest will be classified. Amendment No. (2) also seeks to carry out the original intention of my Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw it to the Committee's attention that the second amendment moved by Senator Walters is in fact exactly the same as my second amendment.
—That is correct, but I gave Senator Walters priority. It was her Bill.
—You probably will support them.
—Of course. That particular amendment is the same. But I also have an amendment to clause 4.
—Leave was granted for Senator Walters to move her two amendments together. I will come back to Senator Jenkins as soon as I have dealt with Senator Walters's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, subclause 5 (3), line 27, leave out ``, whether or not the material'', insert ``and''.

If agreed to this amendment will, of course, dramatically change the tenor of Senator Walters's Bill. It is very important that I draw that matter to the Committee's attention. I state at this point that there are other amendments put forward by Senator Harradine and me which relate-they are relevant to this clause-to the control of video material which in Senator Walters's Bill would be classified under clause 5 (1) (g) on page 4, which states:
video material is not be to be sold, let on hire or delivered to a person under the age of 18 years other than by a parent or guardian of the person.

That classification relates, as matters stand, to both R-rated and X-rated videos. This amendment comes right to the crux of what the Committee is debating, that is, whether videos currently classified under an X-classification which show explicit sexual acts involving no suggestions of coercion and no consent of any kind should be able to be viewed by adults in the community. That has been flagged in the second reading stage debate. I am very appreciative of the difference in those second reading remarks. I am very appreciative also of the remarks that Senator Walters made previously in her summing up speech.

Senator Walters said quite correctly-I am sure there would be no dissent from her remark-that no-one would want to see or condone matters such as child pornography. Of course, we are all making judgments here. But on some matters there is general agreement. The dissent being expressed in this chamber and the differences of opinion are reflected out in the community. We can look at what is shown on video and on film. Murders are shown but murder is illegal. We do not say that we will ban all videos and films that show murder. Sex between consenting adults is legal and that is what we are now seeking to ban. This matter does not need further consideration. And I want to ask Senator Walters questions with regard to her definition in clause 4 of the Bill of depictions of explicit sexual acts. Perhaps Senator Walters will address that matter latter. I may go back to that at a later time.

Prostitution is illegal in some States; it is certainly illegal in my home State of Western Australia, but it is condoned by the police. We have a system known as `containment', which means that the police decide how many brothels there shall be in Western Australia, who will run them, how often they will be raided, and who will be warned about this so that they will not be charged. I am very glad that it has come to the point where we really discuss these matters because I think that they need discussion. We all know what happened in the Joint Select Committee on Video Material: there was a lot of dissent and there were two reports. I would like to quote briefly from one portion of the report of the Committee because I think it sums up very well the dilemma that we find ourselves in. The report states:
Almost all witnesses and submissions addressed this issue on the basis of personal or professional experience, common-sense and intelligent assessment, or on the basis of behavioural science studies.

In other words, there was a whole range of tone of submission to the Committee. It is, of course, a very emotional issue in itself because we are talking about human sexuality, which touches all of us very closely. It is a matter which does concern every adult. We are talking about censorship and how far we should go with censorship; we are also talking about people's rights and how far we take people's rights. I hope that when we discuss my amendment all these matters will be brought out properly and thoroughly. I hope that the issues will be canvassed properly before there is any vote on my amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of issues have been raised which I think Senator Walters may be able to explain to us. Perhaps Senator Walters could give an explanation. For instance, why has she chosen that particular age grouping in clause 5 (1) (d), (e), (f) and (g), knowing that a 15-year-old today is sometimes very difficult to distinguish from an 18-year-old? The difficulties arise in terms of not so much the parents but the video dealers themselves or people who are expected, at some stage, to understand the classification system and particularly understand the logic behind that system. I am not talking about the dealer in the shop. Obviously that is a question further down the line. I am talking about the community understanding why Senator Walters chose to adopt that sort of age classification.

—I can certainly answer that. It is in line with the present Film Censorship Board. I am aware that Senator Aulich has not been following this debate in detail and that he was not on the Committee. I have not altered that at all. At present the Film Censorship Board has set those age limits. They were not of my choosing.

—I raised that matter because I considered this to be a new Bill with a new and important philosophy. I have been following this issue very closely indeed. I am very strongly against the artistic relationship between pornography and violence. I believe that some of the views Senator Walters has been espousing are appropriate and that we need to do something about this matter. I am asking Senator Walters why she put this age arrangement in the legislation when she simply indicated to me before that she has taken it from the existing standards. The existing standards are not justified philosophically in this Bill. I ask Senator Walters again: is it philosophically and practically justified to have this sort of breakdown of age classifications simply because the current arrangements happen to be that way? Senator Walters said that she put it in because it happens to be what exists at the moment. She is presumably embarking on a new approach to this whole issue, one with which I have a great deal of sympathy. But I am not going to come into this chamber as a senator and listen to Senator Walters say, in respect of a Bill that she had prepared, `There is no basic justification for this; it is here because it is the current arrangement'. The current arrangement in the Australian Capital Territory is not acceptable to me or, I should imagine, to Senator Walters. But she has got to go further than that. Did she pluck the arbitrary ages of 15 and 18 out of the blue simply because they happen to be the existing age classifications, or is there some deeper justification, some practical and philosophical justification, which will encourage me to say, `Yes, I will support not only this particular clause, but the whole Bill.'?

—I do not know whether Senator Aulich was in the chamber when the debate first started. He could not have been, because if he was here and had listened to my speech, he would have known the answer. He would not have bothered looking so serious and would not have asked such a stupid question. If Senator Aulich had bothered to listen he would know that my Bill did two things only, both of which are in line with the unanimous decision of Attorneys-General throughout Australia. I made it very clear that my Bill took up the concerns of the Attorneys-General of all the States in two areas. They expressed concern and the majority of members of our Committee expressed the same concern. The majority of members of our Committee recommended that violence in videos be downgraded and that X-rated videos be abolished. The Attorneys-General from all over Australia said exactly the same thing. If Senator Aulich had been listening to my speech, he would have heard me say that my Bill simply did those two things. He is trying to be smart. If he is very concerned about the present age grouping and the present situation in the Australian Capital Territory, he should put up an amendment and we will see whether we agree with it. I challenge Senator Aulich to be sincere-not to waffle, not to carry on and not to tell me, following the Caucus decision not to support my Bill, that he is concerned about the decision in the Australian Capital Territory. He should put up his amendment and I will see whether I and members of the Opposition agree with it. I challenge him to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed that a senator could come into this chamber, put up these particular clauses in this Bill and then challenge us on this side of the chamber to put up an amendment because she cannot explain the reasoning behind a very significant clause in her own Bill. Senator Walters says that it is because it is the existing situation. This is a Bill which can have an effect on the future of our children. Senator Walters has stood up and has said that I am not sincere. I am very sincere about this issue. If I am to put my vote in this chamber towards this Bill I want some proper explanation from the person who brought this Bill in. It is not good enough to say, `Because it is so. You put up your amendment. Ya! ya!'. I never heard anything so stupid. It is making a mockery of this chamber. We are serious about this issue. I gather that most people in the chamber here today care a great deal about this issue. We would not be sitting here listening to you if that were not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask you again, before I support this particular clause, this vital classification--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Aulich, address your remarks through the Chair.

—Yes, I will address Senator Walters through you, Mr Chairman. I am asking Senator Walters, through you, Mr Chairman, for an explanation of why that category should not be the age categorisation which we will use in the future. If the honourable senator wants to break with the past, if she wants to establish a new situation with a Bill like this, then she must explain one of the principal clauses in that Bill. It is not good enough for her to come into this chamber and to stand up and abuse people who ask questions. I will ask one question in relation to this issue: how can Senator Walters tell the difference between a 16-year-old and a 15-year-old if they are both in the same high school? How can she ask anyone in the community to make a decision about a classification which draws such a fine line between a 15-year-old and a 16-year-old? If she can, she is a better judge of children or young people than I am. I ask again: can she try to justify the reasoning behind this age classification? Can she please do that? If she can do that I will certainly consider supporting her legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can provide the answer to Senator Aulich's remarks and I hope it will convince him to cross the floor on this particular matter.
—I am sorry Senator Walters could not; it is her Bill.
—Though it is her Bill, I will listen to you.

—Having been brought into the chamber, it is legislation belonging to all of us. We all have our entitlements to discuss it. I think Senator Aulich's points suggests that there is a change of philosophy in this legislation from that which has governed the classification of video materials thus far. As I understand it, that is the burden of his particular question to Senator Walters and to the chamber. The answer is to be found in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. The Joint Select Committee indicated, in respect of the classification system, in respect of the establishment of a Film Censorship Board, and in respect of the various classifications of G, PG, M and R, that, for the most part, those particular arrangements were suitable for the balance of the rights of individuals to see and view the material they wished and for the protection of society.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, it was agreed that there should be some kind of censorship. The majority found that that philosophy extended to everything except material which was explicitly sexual. That material was exempted from those general classification principles. That is what the majority held. Senator Aulich's question about the classification systems and the age limits to those classification systems does not really come into the question of philosophy, because the Committee considered that those were the appropriate classifications.

This Bill enshrines the guidelines which were put in place at the time by the Film Censorship Board relating to classification M; that is, video material not recommended for viewing by persons under the age of 15. Since then, the Film Censorship Board has changed slightly that particular classification or denomination for M. It now says that the M classification is recommended for mature audiences, 15 years of age and over.

I agree with Senator Aulich that it is not for us to recommend that certain material be suitable, or be recommended, for audiences 15 years or over. Are all persons of 15 years of age mature? This new classification, or identification, just recently introduced by the Film Censorship Board without our say so and without our having brought it before the Committee, is rather disconcerting. It is only a minor point, but I think it is desirable to stick with the wording which existed previously. There is no change in philosophy. There is an acceptance of the need for a Film Censorship Board to balance the competing demands of citizens in respect of this very major question.

The only thing this Bill attempts is to require censorship to be applied to material for which censorship is not now currently applied. It comes down to the question of a policy which has been developed over a considerable period. That policy was developed from the days of the late Lionel Murphy and was at last introduced into this Parliament by way of regulation in 1984. That policy, in effect, did not require the tests which would be required for other types of material to be applied to this type of material. Persons can import any material relating to sex, provided it is not physically violent. That could include, and does include, material which promotes acquired immune deficiency syndrome, high-risk behaviour, group sex, anal sex and the like. Anybody can bring the material in and, provided nobody actually twists somebody's arm, the material is automatically registered.

The majority of the Committee believed that that should not be the case and strongly opposed the view expressed by the minority of the Committee that there should be a new non-violent erotica proposal, because that proposal would entrench X-rated hard-core pornography into the community and into the home video entertainment system. It is important for everybody to understand what we are talking about. We are talking about the home video entertainment system. The Government is entrenching that material in that system. We have the opportunity today, by voting for Senator Walters's Bill, to take that material out of the home video entertainment market and refuse its importation into Australia.

Senator Jenkins's proposal guts Senator Walters's Bill. It would enable X-rated video materials to be introduced and brought into this country. Providing there is no physical twisting of arms-there is a lot of psychological twisting of arms-anything goes. That question must be determined by this chamber today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a question about some of the other subclauses of clause 5, but I would like first to come in on the question of children's ages. I do not know whether I have written it down correctly, but I understood Senator Walters to say in her second reading summing up that children now have this material freely available. I do not know whether she was talking about children over 15 or about those under 15. I suspect she was talking about the latter. Senator Aulich referred to the great difficulty that retailers, in particular, have in knowing how old children are. When I was teaching I would often see children at places such as hotels who to me were clearly under age, but people who are not used to that age group find it very hard to tell, particularly when some of the young people are made up.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure Senator Walters remembers the case of Mrs Cains, who actually set up one of her children and tried to set up another one in order to pass them off as older to entrap a retailer. It is rather inconsistent to uphold Senator Walters's classifications. It seems that if Senator Walters wants to be consistent she should say that nothing should be available over the present classification of `G', which, I think, is `D' in her classification; in other words, video material suitable for all ages. Otherwise we will have the problem of video retailers, the people responsible, not necessarily deliberately breaking the law, but doing so because children frequently pass themselves off as older than they are, even without the assistance of their mothers.
The matter I wanted to address next was subclause (4) relating to violence. Senator Walters just had a go at what I said during debate on the second reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. We have not yet reached that point. Are we debating the Democrats' amendment?

—The subject before the Chair is clause 5 and Senator Jenkins's amendment to it. I thought Senator Zakharov was speaking to subclause (4) of clause 5. In that case, she is in order. She cannot discuss any other clause than clause 5 or Senator Jenkins's amendment thereto.

—I am addressing subclause 4 of clause 5, which is totally in order. As I started to say, Senator Walters had a go at me for what I said in my speech on the second reading. I should have been more careful in what I said. I do not have a copy of my speech here, but according to Senator Walters-I have no reason to doubt her-I said that she did not address the portrayal of violence. I should have spelt it out more clearly, but I meant that her Bill did not address the portrayal of violence any more effectively than does the present legislation; in other words, the clause adds nothing to the present situation. The clause has no force as something new. A lot of what is in the Bill is not really new. It echoes what has gone before. I will read out what is presently banned. `Violence' covers detailed and gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty and explicit or gratuitous depictions of sexual violence against non-consenting persons. The only word added to that in Senator Walters's subclause is `relished'. In the Joint Select Committee on Video Material there was a great deal of discussion about use of the words `relished' and `gratuitous'. My view is that both of them are in the eye of the observer. I have problems with material being described as `gratuitous' because anyone can construct a video so as to justify something as not being gratuitous; someone can write a story so that a particular action is not gratuitous and get around that. The question of the word `relished' is to my mind a purely subjective one. It adds nothing to say `relished'. What `relished' means to me I am sure is not what it means to Senator Walters. What I consider to be meant by `relished' may not be seen in the same way by anybody else in the chamber. Similarly, what Senator Walters regards as the meaning of `relished' may not be so regarded by anybody else in this chamber. It is a matter of taste, and we cannot legislate for taste except in a very broad fashion. I ask Senator Walters in what way she feels that this subclause in her Bill adds to the provision which is already in the legislation. I say this in the context of knowing that the community in general-that would include at least some of the Attorneys-General, as shown by their remarks made at and after their meetings-does not understand the present situation.
—That's in writing.

—It is in writing. I wonder whether, as Senator Walters seems to be claiming, the Attorneys-General expressed a view that the word `relished' should be added. As I understand it, Senator Walters claimed just now that she was only attempting to put into legislation the wishes of that meeting of State Attorneys-General and police Ministers. I would like to know what she thinks the word `relished' adds to the situation. Does she believe it is in accordance with the stated wishes of the Attorneys-General? If so, I would like to hear the evidence. If she cannot provide any explanation of why `relished' adds to the legislation, what is the point of this subclause?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In order to save the time of the Committee, I was not going to canvass this issue. I wanted to cover a number of other aspects of the Bill, but if Senator Walters has the hide to have the carriage of a piece of legislation through this chamber and in response to a very substantive question in which I am also very interested, having been a very active member of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, and simply retain her place and decline to answer, I intend to canvass the same issue. If any Minister on the front bench on this side of the chamber behaved in that fashion--
—You have three of them.
—I have not seen it yet in a committee stage. I have sat in this chamber through hours of committee debates on extremely complex legislation.
—Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. I respectfully ask that you direct Senator Collins to address his comments to the clause we are debating and not to Senator Walters.
—I allowed Senator Collins a preamble to his question, but I think he should now work his way around to the clause.
—Mr Chairman, I accept the ruling, of course, but I think I am entitled to respond to that outrageous behaviour. If a Government Minister failed--

—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. Senator Collins has been standing in line with Senator Zakharov. As you know, both stood to speak. I presumed that Senator Collins also had a question along similar lines, but I am very happy to answer Senator Zakharov's question. Senator Collins obviously misunderstood my reasons for remaining seated. I thought that it would be quicker if he were able to put his question also so then I could answer both.
—Order! There is no point of order. Honourable senators are called as they stand. If Senator Walters does not stand, she will not be called.

—In reply to the question that Senator Zakharov has canvassed, I point out that it is a substantive issue because it does change the existing classification, not just in respect of X-classified material but also in respect of R-classified material. We should all be aware of this and people should understand it.
—Senator Walters made that clear from the word go. She told us that is why she was bringing the Bill in.
—People need to understand the change that is being made. That is the point that I am making.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Zakharov introduced an extremely relevant point into this debate when she said that, at the meeting of Attorneys, considerable confusion was expressed by the Attorneys about the current classifications. Indeed, it was in relation to that expressed confusion that the Caucus moved in the way it did to try to alleviate that confusion. As we know, that motion has been overtaken by events since then. But there is still continuing confusion at the highest levels about the classifications. We canvassed this issue at length on the Committee, as Senator Walters well knows. I guarantee that, excluding Ministers who are specifically responsible for the portfolio area, 50 out of 50 members of Parliament who would be happy to speak in debates would not be able to outline even the broad classifications involved in the currently accepted classifications that this legislation proposes to alter. That is a matter of fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —You tell us what they are.

—If the Senator will be patient, I will tell him. There is widespread confusion, not only among the Attorneys but also in the community at large, about what is M, PG, G, R, and X. Senator Walters has quoted, in the committee stage of this debate, a ream of women's bodies throughout Australia that object to X-rated material. It is something like the answers in an opinion poll. It is necessary to look at the questions that have been asked. I have no doubt that, because of the connections he has, Senator Harradine will respond to this. It is a matter of fact that a number of major organisations in Australia representing very large groups of women, such as the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association (SDAEA) and the Federated Clerks Union, lodged similar objections.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Harradine knows-and I invite him to address this matter-the national secretary of the SDAEA, in respect of the classifications that clause 5 is changing, made a number of public statements about his abhorrence and the abhorrence of his members to X-rated videos. As I am sure Senator Harradine knows full well, the national secretary went on to say that his members were outraged by the continuing display and sale of gratuitous sexual violence in X-rated material. I have a copy of the transcript of the interview that the secretary of the SDAEA gave on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't misinterpret what he said.
—In response to that interjection, let me say that I could hardly misinterpret it because I have the entire interview from start to finish.
—Have you got his letter?

—I also have the secretary's letter which he wrote to me, along with a number of others. He exhibited the total confusion about classifications that is being espoused this afternoon in the debate by Senator Walters. Since 1984, X-rated material has contained no explicit violence. That has been totally banned.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the confusion in the community at large on this issue, I refer to an editorial. Senator Harradine knows that I could produce another half a dozen similar editorial comments. About the time that the secretary of the SDAEA was demonstrating his total confusion about what it was he wanted to ban-if that is not relevant to this debate I do not know what is-an editorial in the West Australian newspaper responded to a foreshadowed move by the Western Australian Government to make the possession of X-rated material a criminal offence under the laws of Western Australia. The members of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material will be able to attest to the fact that I alone among the Labor members of that Committee-in fact, I suffered some friction because of it-moved to reserve the right for State governments to set their own standards on this matter. I have to plead guilty to that. It is my background. Coming from the Northern Territory, I am a little more sensitive than others to the total devolution of democratic rights to a Canberra government. Senator Zakharov can correct me if I am wrong, but I think I am correct in saying that I did stand out for the rights of Western Australia. This is reflected in the recommendations. There is a recommendation in the majority report, which I inserted on my motion, to allow the States to continue to exercise their own jurisdiction in these areas. As much as I might have objected to what the Western Australian Government did with that law-I thought it was a pointless exercise-I respected its right to do it. It was entitled to be answerable to the people of Western Australia in the same way as the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory are entitled to respond to laws passed by the new Government of the Australian Capital Territory. This was very much reflected in the recommendations, as Senator Walters should know, of the Commission on Obscenity and Pornography, which was headed by Mr Meese and which inquired into X-rated pornographic material in the United States of America.

The reality is that this confusion exists. The West Australian editorial to which I referred said that although it had reservations about such draconian legislation making possession a serious offence, it would be a relief to see child pornography and bestiality taken off the shelves of Western Australian video shops. That was the leader in the major newspaper in Western Australia. No doubt it was written by someone who saw himself as a moulder of public opinion. That type of journalism really annoys me. I rarely get annoyed about journalism because one of the great bastions of democratic society is the freedom of the press. I do get annoyed when journalists, particularly if they are editorial writers, do not do their homework. But that confusion exists.

Of course, there is in fact no bestiality, no child pornography and no violence in X-rated material. Interestingly enough, X-rated material is the only category that contains no violence of any description. Even G-rated videos contain violence and are allowed to contain violence. X explicitly contains no violence at all. This confusion is not a perceived confusion. It is real and exists at the highest levels of journalism, public opinion and political opinion, and it is about time the confusion was resolved.

John Dickie, the censor, would tell the honourable senator that the difficulty is, and the honourable senator knows it, that the more words such as `relished' which are inserted-which is what Senator Walters wants and which is what Senator Zakharov covered very well-to try to define the job for the censors, the more difficult their job becomes. It is a difficult enough job now because, as the honourable senator knows, it becomes more and more subjective the more descriptions are put in. The simpler the classifications the easier it is for the censors to do what is, in fact, an extremely difficult job. In closing I ask Senator Walters to explain what her interpretation of `relished' is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pity it is that Senator Collins and Senator Zakharov do not do their homework. What a shame they are not aware that the Film Censorship Board has just put out additional guidelines picking up my recommendation of the use of the word `relished'. No doubt Senator Collins will pretend that he knew this all the time; Senator Zakharov, no doubt, will also pretend that they were aware of this. Yet they have both asked, `What is this word ``relished''?'. Senator Collins went even further and said that Mr Dickie said that the more words that were put in the more confused it became. A fortnight ago the Film Censorship Board, in its latest document, picked up my recommendation and used the word `relished'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Select Committee on Video Material had before it evidence that `relished' meant enjoying committing violence. Let me explain to those two honourable senators opposite, who were on that Committee and were present when that evidence was given, that `relished' means depicting people enjoying committing violence. If my Bill is passed it will rule out all depictions of people enjoying committing violence. It will rule out torture. There are so many extremely violent videos that depict people enjoying committing violence. The two honourable senators opposite who show their ignorance in this place by asking, `What on earth does ``relished'' mean?' are ignoring the evidence that was given to our Committee. They are ignoring the fact that the Film Censorship Board has, since my Bill was drafted, picked up the word `relished'. Indeed as a result of what the Attorneys-General have said the Board has downgraded violence in the R classification by adding the word `relished'. If that fact does not deflate Senator Collins, nothing in this world ever will. It underlines his complete ignorance of the fact that the Film Censorship Board has underlined the--

TALK.START.PARA: —You really know how to get people on side!

—There is no way I would want Senator Collins on side. Senator Zakharov talked about how difficult it is to tell how old someone is. Yes, it is difficult. We discussed that in the Committee and Senator Zakharov did not at any stage come up with any recommendations that the age ought to be altered. Indeed, age was part of the recommendations of the Senate Committee. Nobody on that Committee suggested that it should be altered.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to Senator Jenkins's amendment because at least, unlike honourable senators opposite, she was trying to debate this Bill properly. I can only presume, Mr Chairman, that we are going to have an election. Honourable senators opposite do not want to vote on this Bill. I predict we are going to have an election pretty soon because--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I assume that Senator Walters is about to leave this topic so I will not raise a point of order. I thought she was going to speak at length on the election, but I have just had a last minute indication that she is going back to the subject matter.
—There is no point of order.

—Government members do not want to vote on this Bill. They voted on the second reading of my Bill but do not want to knock out the Bill yet because they know there will be a political backlash against them. They want to knock this Bill out after the election, not before, so they are going to talk this debate out. Otherwise, we would not have had this deliberate stupid nonsense about age from Senator Aulich.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us return to Senator Jenkins, who at least is being honest about this. Senator Jenkins's amendment does absolutely nothing except bring back X-rated videos. All it does is say that X-rated videos ought to be allowed in. She acknowledged that it makes large alterations to my Bill, and she is quite right because it allows for X-rated videos. Senator Jenkins said that she does not see why the depiction of sexual acts between consenting adults should be made illegal viewing in the home when the viewing of videos depicting murder, which is illegal, is allowed in the home. The way Senator Jenkins talks anybody would think these videos are just love stories. Senator Jenkins is wrong to put that impression across. It is incorrect. It is deceiving. They are not love stories. Such videos do not depict a love scene between adults. That is the worst sort of nonsense that one can imagine.

I ask Senator Jenkins whether she is serious in saying that films which the Film Censorship Board believes are too bad to be shown in the cinemas around this country, except to those over 18, are all right for home entertainment. Does Senator Jenkins really believe that she can pretend to the community that they are merely love stories-sex between consenting adults? I can assure her they are far from that. They are not just blue movies. They are degrading to women. Even Robbie Swan, the man who is really pushing X-rated videos and who is the X-rated video lobbyist, says that between 20 and 30 per cent of them are degrading to women. He is the man whom this Government is supporting-the spokesman for the multi-million dollar adult video lobby. That is who Senator Bob Collins is supporting.

But Robbie Swan himself says that between 20 per cent and 30 per cent of these X-rated videos are degrading to women. Well, it is not just 20 per cent to 30 per cent-it is 100 per cent. They are degrading to women. Of course, Senator Collins, who is a man, would not understand that and I do not expect him to understand it. But let me explain to Senator Collins that, while he is a man and does not understand that attitude, all the women out there in Australia do, because all the women's organisations-every single one of them-have written to us and expressed their concern. They have told us that they want us to ban and that they want my Bill to be supported.

I can repeat the names of the women's organisations: the Women's Electoral Lobby (ACT) Inc., the National Status of Women Committee, the Country Women's Association of New South Wales, the Catholic Women's League, the Mothers Union in Australia, the Australian Church Women, the War Widows Guild, the Society of Women Writers Australia and the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women Inc. Every single one of those organisations, except one-and that was only the Women in Science Enquiry Network Incorporated, the ones--

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you ask them what was in the X-rated videos? Did they know?

—For the benefit of Bob Collins and Senator Zakharov, let me read from Hansard in the minute that I have left. When Senator Hill was quoting the Mothers Union in Australia, Senator Zakharov interjected:

SPEECH.PARA: They lack an understanding of the issue.
That is what she is saying again today: they lack an understanding of the issue. In reply, Senator Hill said:
Senator Zakharov ought to listen to this.
Senator Hill then quoted the Mothers Union:

Along with many other people in the community we have been campaigning for the ban on X-rated Videos in the A.C.T. and the N.T. and the consequent end of the mail order trade which now flows into the States, where a ban already exists.

Our reasons are that X-rated Videos contain depictions of behaviour which, if imitated, may lead to the spread of Sexually Transmitted Diseases, including A.I.D.S. It is our contention that it is illogical for the Government to be spending millions of dollars on the education of the public about the dangers of certain sexual practices while at the same time condoning the sale and hire of videos which are sending the message that these very practices are normal, acceptable and presumably risk free.

We also believe that it is illogical for the Government to support such projects as `Fair Go for Women' and `Affirmative Action' which seek to improve the status of women in the community while allowing the free availability of material which depicts women as mere objects for male sexual gratification.

She did not at any stage mention violence. They understand very well what those videos are about, and it is of no use Senator Zakharov and Bob Collins trying to hide their heads and pretend that they do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Collins must be addressed by his correct title.
—I have listened to that five consecutive times, and I have had enough of it.
—Order!
—It was not five times in a row but if it is good enough to address every one else as senator, Senator Walters can address me the same way.

—He cannot take it. Let us be very clear that all these women's organisations are well aware of what X-rated videos are all about. Every single one of those organisations has appealed to the Government to support my Bill, and it is of no use Senator Jenkins moving an amendment that will gut my Bill completely, as Senator Harradine says. The Government supported the second reading, but I do not for a moment doubt that its little act in not voting against the Bill then was to support Senator Jenkins's amendment, which guts my Bill completely and will allow X-rated videos in.

SPEECH.PARA: The last time we were debating this matter, Senator Jenkins, when the amendments were put up, told me that it was a mistake that the amendments were under the heading `Australian Democrats'. I am not sure whether that mistake has been made again because her amendments are under the heading `Australian Democrats'. Could the honourable senator please let me know whether they are the amendments of the Australian Democrats or just her own.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disappointing that Senator Walters has not addressed herself to the two questions that my colleagues asked. Instead, she sought to bluster away in a fairly loud voice. The first question was that of age. It is difficult in those circumstances. I always thought that Senator Walters was between 35 and 38, but my colleagues behind me say that I am wrong. Judging age is not easy. They sought the honourable senator's definition of `relish', not a definition existing somewhere else and so on. Senator Walters has not answered that either. When I am on the question of definition, I am more interested in clause 5 (5), which says that an exception can be made on the basis of `educational, cultural, scientific, historical and cinematographic significance'. I really wonder what this refers to.
—Order! Under sessional order, the time for consideration of General Business has expired. I shall report progress.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
COPYRIGHT AMENDMENT BILL 1988

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering clause 13 of the Copyright Amendment Bill, and amendments Nos 13, 14 and 15 which were moved together, by leave, by Senator Hill.

—We are dealing with the amendments moved by Senator Hill-amendments Nos 13 and 14. I spoke earlier in regard to some amendments that I wanted to move to clause 13. Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch we were discussing the matter of external students. As I understood it, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) was going to make a number of comments in response to other matters that had been raised but wished to have some time to consider them. The Minister might care to respond to those matters before we proceed to a vote on this issue.
—Can you remind me of exactly what you are proposing?

—We are dealing with Senator Hill's amendments Nos 13 and 14 with regard to external students to which I had indicated that I would be moving an alternative amendment. It was my understanding that the Minister was also looking at an alternative method of dealing with these matters-by way of regulation. I do not know whether that has progressed or whether the Minister had a firmer proposal to put in regard to that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has not moved from its position. It believes that this can best be done by way of regulation. The Copyright Tribunal, after all, is a most expert body. It has the capacity to set rates and to take relevant information into account, probably by doing sampling surveys of the institutions concerned, which vary as to the external studies programs which they offer to students who undertake courses from a point so far removed from the campus concerned that they cannot be given normal class room tutorial assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: The idea was that that Tribunal, with that expertise and carrying out those surveys, would be able to take into account a rate for external students that would enable it to discount the royalty rate payable by institutions to the extent that the copying could be described as an equivalent to fair copying. Some assessment of that has to take place to prevent any abuse of the copying, which would be the case if there were an outright exemption. Accordingly, we believe that institutions such as those that have a large external studies program will pay no more for copying for external students than they probably do at present when it is all boiled down. The fact is that this will be in the hands of the Tribunal concerned rather than the Parliament attempting to do it by some waving of the wand. In short, we still believe that our system remains the best of the three alternatives that have been put before the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is probably highly disorderly, but I wonder whether the Minister might give us a hint as to which of the two options he would prefer if he had the choice. As Senator Macklin indicated prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch the chances are that the Minister will have the choice. For the reasons that we expressed earlier, neither of us is particularly convinced by the argument the Minister has just put concerning this regulatory procedure. It seems obvious to us that students within cities with access to libraries would have access to all the material. I for one cannot understand, therefore, what the Tribunal has to address. I do not know whether the Minister is buying time. Perhaps we might get some guidance.

—Let me put it this way: Miss Vick was the last person in my office. I hope that that is not misunderstood in the cold light of Hansard. If we have to make a choice we will choose the amendment of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the good spirit in which this matter is being resolved it would probably be better if I sought leave to withdraw the Opposition's amendments. I indicate that in due course we will support the Australian Democrats' amendment in this regard. I might say in doing so that we still have a preference for the form of words in our amendments, which has the blessing of the vice-chancellors, the principals, the administrators and the directors of institutions of advanced learning in this country. Nevertheless, this will be a difficult debate which will require a bit of give and take on all sides to reach a satisfactory conclusion. In principal, there is not a lot of difference in the amendments the Democrats are seeking and those that we have put forward. As I have said, although we would prefer our amendments I seek leave to withdraw amendments (13), (14) and (15) and I indicate our support in due course for the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments-by leave-withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that I will circulate in the chamber shortly a slightly revised amendment. It is just that a word is misspelled in the amendment and it is also in the wrong spot in the Bill.
—Otherwise it is all right.
—Otherwise it is fine. I hope that that amendment will be circulated now so that, rather than going backwards, we will deal with that amendment at a later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause postponed.
Clause 14.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our amendment to clause 14 deals with the prescribed organisations in the blank tape regime.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, you have put the question that clause 13 stand as printed. Senator Macklin's amendment is to clause 13, is it not? I know that he now says that he wants to put that in a different place.

—I do not have the revised item, but I think the Minister is correct. I apologise for this but it is really out of my control. Changing the spelling of one word and changing the position of the amendment is taking an inordinately long time.
—Senator Macklin, would the problem be solved if we recommit clause 13 and postpone consideration until you have your amendment before you?
—Yes, that would suit me. I think it is better to get it correct rather than simply to do it on the run.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Page 31, clause 14, proposed section 135zzj, after definition of `exemption number' insert the following definition:
`` `prescribed organisation, means
(a) an educational institution;
(b) an institution assisting handicapped readers;
(c) an institution assisting intellectually handicapped persons;
(d) an institution assisting the blind or the visually impaired;
(e) an institution assisting the deaf or the hearing impaired;
(f) an organisation engaged in broadcasting;
(g) an organisation engaged in the production of sound recordings; or
(h) such other organisation as is prescribed;''.
(17) Page 35, clause 14, after proposed subsection 135zzw (1), insert the following new subsection:

``(1a) The Attorney-General shall cause a copy of the report sent to the Attorney-General under subsection (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the receipt of the report by the Attorney-General.''.
I take it from the debate this morning that the Government is now likely to support amendment No. 17, which is to provide for the tabling of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of the collecting society.

—Of the collecting society that deals with the blank tape regime. That seems consistent with the Minister's willingness this morning to table reports of other collecting societies. If that is the case, I shall not spend time developing an argument to that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: I am unsure of the Government's attitude on amendment 16. As we made clear in our speeches during the second reading debate, we believe that the prescribed organisations should be defined within the legislation and that there should be the capacity for additional organisations to be added to the list. These bodies have an important responsibility. They are to be exempted from an obligation in regard to payment. As I understand it, the bodies that we have listed in amendment 16 are the types of bodies which the Government was of a mind to include within its regulatory mechanism. They include educational institutions assisting handicapped readers, institutions assisting intellectually handicapped people, institutions assisting the blind or the visually impaired, institutions assisting the deaf or the hearing impaired, organisations engaged in broadcasting and organisations engaged in the production of sound recordings. If we are correct in believing that there would be no objection in the Committee to these groups being at least some of those which will ultimately be exempted, we can see no argument why they should not be set out in this legislation. This would give Parliament the opportunity to vote upon them, and in this instance to vote for their specific reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it Senator Hill's wish that they be dealt with together?
—I suspect that the Minister may prefer them to be voted upon. I do not yet know the Government's attitude to the first amendment. We know that it has indicated support for the second.

—The Australian Democrats support the proposition contained in amendment 17. In regard to amendment 16, I am still unaware of what the Government intends by way of `prescribed organisation'. In other words, does the Government seek to prescribe a specific and named organisation, or does it intend by way of regulation to have a more general classification? There is a difficulty in Senator Hill's proposition. Having said what a prescribed organisation means-for example, an institution assisting handicapped readers in paragraph (b)-we are then not much clearer whether that particular institution, whatever it is, is of the nature of an institution assisting handicapped readers as set out under the Act. I wonder whether the Minister would explain the intent in prescribing by regulation a centre that goes by a specific name-for example, the Endeavour Foundation in Queensland. Would it be named as one of those prescribed organisations, or would it merely be lumped under a regulation which said that all institutions assisting intellectually handicapped persons or whatever else would be exempt?

—On the whole, while the sorts of categories which Senator Hill has indicated might qualify as a prescribed organisation are in the correct area, it is the Government's intention in many instances to list the organisations which are actually within that category. This is to try to prevent abuse. The definition in amendment 16 of `an organisation engaged in broadcasting' is very broad. One would not want persons to take advantage of that category. We want any listing to be as precise as possible. I am not saying that in some instances a description by category would not be sufficient. There may be many instances where one would want to list the actual organisations concerned, and that is the Government's intention.
—Is it Senator Hill's wish that the questions on the two amendments be put together or separately?
—Separately.
—If there is no objection, it is so ordered. The question is that amendment 16 be agreed to.
—The question now is that Opposition amendment 17 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 14 deals with the administration of the whole regime of blank tape levies. I understand that clause 13 has not yet been put and passed but has been deferred.
—Yes.

—I would be grateful for the Minister's consideration in relation to clause 13 of inserting in proposed section 135zzd a paragraph (7), akin to the paragraph (7) which the Minister kindly inserted in proposed section 135r, to ensure that the collecting societies referred to in that section shall also have their annual reports presented to the Parliament. Perhaps when clause 13 comes back for discussion, the Minister might take that initiative.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to Opposition amendment 17, which I understand the Government is prepared to accept-and I thank the Minister for his assistance in that matter-the whole question of the levy on blank tapes has a long history which I had the opportunity to recount in my speech during the second reading debate. I pay tribute to the way in which the Australian Record Industry Association over many years has pursued with real vigour and vigilance the introduction of a blank tape levy. This matter goes back to November 1983, having been accepted in principle by the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans. I believe that the proper diversion of money which will occur from the levy on these blank tapes will be used in a very proper fashion to support the operations of contemporary music and to support the work which is being undertaken with the support of State governments and the Commonwealth government to promote the contemporary music industry in this country.

As you know, recent announcements have been made by the State Government of Victoria regarding the establishment in support of the Victorian Rock Foundation. Recently, at the annual Australian Record Industry Association (ARIA) awards, Mr Peter Collins, the Minister for Arts in New South Wales, made an announcement about support which that Liberal State government was going to give to export promotional activities for popular music originating in that State. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:
