This amendment relates to one of the definitions of exempt recording from the new performer's protection provisions which are to be inserted as part 11a of the legislation. As the provision stands in the Government's Bill-I refer to paragraph (f)-an `exempt recording' means:

A direct or indirect sound recording or cinematograph film of a short extract of a performance made solely for the purpose of reporting news by means of broadcasting or in cinematograph film, or for the purpose of criticism or review;

The scheme of that provision is clear. There is to be an exemption for direct or indirect recordings of news matters. It has been put by the industry that the definition of news might be too narrow for what we presume all parties are seeking to achieve. I understand that news can be defined in a particularly limited form, whereas we would have presumed that surrounding type information or information that might be communicated through what is commonly referred to as current affairs programs should be equally exempt. I think that is a good argument. I hope that that sigh is because the Minister is tired and it is not because he does not accept the argument. We have therefore brought forward this amendment which is to replace the wording of paragraph (f), which I have just read, with new wording which would provide that an exempt recording will be a direct or indirect sound recording or cinematograph film of a performance made for the purpose of, or associated with, the reporting of news or current affairs or for the purpose of criticism or review. In other words, I believe that what we are putting is in accordance with the scheme that the Government has promoted. It is slightly broadening the definition we think in a way that is constructive and will, therefore, better enable material to be communicated through current affairs programs without the risk of an action under the new performers protection provisions. I do not think I need to say any more on that. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept this amendment. The exemption, speaking about reporting news in our proposal, is deliberately narrow. The idea is not to try to undermine the rights of performers to get reasonable remuneration for the use made of a performance or a recording of a performance by those who themselves are in the business of generating income-those operating a commercial television station, for example. They would certainly gather taxpayer support by getting good ratings if it is the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or the Special Broadcasting Service. The fact is that an exemption in favour of news reporting is justified because of the time pressures which go into the compiling of a news segment on television, radio news, or whatever it might be.

SPEECH.PARA: Current affairs programs do not really suffer quite the same pressure and in fact some, as we know, are compiled over many months. I know that there are some that just fall in between, but the fact is that I think a fair distinction can be drawn between those situations where it would be quite impossible and impracticable to get the permission of copyright owners. The pressure of the news broadcasts is quite different from the sorts of pressures that apply in relation to current affairs programs. I believe that if recorded performances are to be used in the current affairs program, then they ought not to be exempted from the provisions of the Bill. The Rome Convention for the Protection of Performers speaks of the use of short excerpts in connection with reporting of current events.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not news, current events.

—That is true; nevertheless, short excerpts in connection with the reporting of current events. Within the Australian context, what that more clearly equates to is the use of a smaller segment of a performance in relation to a news item rather than the more lengthy, or even short for that matter, use of a performance in a current affairs program, whereas as I say there ought to be time for those compiling the program to obtain the permission of the copyright owner or of the performer concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Australian Democrats will support Senator Hill's amendment. Indeed, in the amendments which I circulated previously there was to have been a third amendment, but because of the new technologies we are talking about it went off into some electronic limbo and actually did not appear on the paper from the printer.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the point that the Minister for Justice raises is somewhat at odds with what I understood the actual purpose to be. Indeed, it does not seem to me to be terribly important whether the time pressure is there or not in terms of broadcasting. In other words, we exempt news because we cannot get round in time to get the copyright out of the people. I would have thought rather that we exempt news because, by its very nature, it is reporting something that is not, as it were, paid performance and only peripherally does one find the people there; for example, something may have happened to the performers. The news is not actually reporting the performance in as much as an accident or some other event that took place.

However, the Minister is correct in saying that there is a distinction with current affairs. In the Australian context, current affairs has slightly blurred edges. By and large current affairs snippets are not all that much longer than the news snippets. I do not know whether the Minister, who is a polished performer, is able to insert the history of the Western world into some of the small segments that one manages to get on current affairs, but they are incredibly short. On the other hand, very often current affairs do cover matters that are not covered by the news; for example, current affairs may often cover an upcoming cultural event such as a new ballet or something like that. I think that that is a bit rough.

The reason that current affairs are covering the ballet is for advertising purposes. If the owner of the copyright and the performers are willing to engage in that activity, then it would appear there. News tends to be taken without too many people asking what is going on; current affairs are a slightly more leisurely exercise, as the Minister has indicated, but again taken with permission, particularly those items covering the cultural events where one is likely to find performers. On balance, the argument must be that the news falls under the exempt exercise in terms of a film or performance. I believe that it would otherwise be too much of a stricture particularly because an attempt at the definition of `news' has not been undertaken.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are being very logical again.

—I would not have a run at the definition of news. I realise why the Minister's advisers decided not to have a run at it either. In the Australian context we have an informal definition of news which seems to suggest that such service which is provided during the news half-hour segment or hour segment-the extra half-hour which has slightly longer items is called current affairs-is such a woolly exercise that I really do believe it would be far better to adopt what I understand to be the international agreement; that is, short exposure of current events. That normally is our definition of current affairs; it is not our definition of news. If one really wants to define news, it is basically about the latest car smash. The news in the morning is about the car smashes of yesterday. I think that current affairs tend to be much closer to that international definition, that is, short exposures of current events. I do not think we are running foul of the international agreement. I had a feeling during the Minister's comments which suggested that this amendment might, but I do not believe it is. If the Minister has a stronger argument I would certainly like to hear it, but it does seem to me not to violate that international agreement. I would have thought that Senator Hill's amendment will allow what we normally call news and current affairs. It is interesting that we have that terminology in Australia. We hold them very close together and we see them to be of the same type. I believe that this would not run into those areas where there is an extended performance being screened. I think that that would certainly violate performers' rights. Under the circumstances, I indicate that we support the amendment unless the Minister has a stronger argument on the international agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit extreme.

—I wish to support the remarks which my colleague, Senator Hill has made in this regard. TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will now proceed to the amendments foreshadowed by the Australian Democrats, consideration of which was deferred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise again to the Committee for the lateness of the revised edition of my proposed amendment. The way that we have had to put these amendments together means that we have run into the same problem that Senator Hill had with the first set of amendments, which is that amendments to the same clause end up dealing with two of the matters which we have already discussed in part. That concerns the exercise regarding external students. It appears in my amendments at page 2 and reads: A fair dealing with literary work (other than lecture notes) does not constitute an infringement of the copyright in the work if it is for the purpose of, or associated with, an approved course of study or research by an enrolled external student of an educational institution.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to mislead the Committee. This is in far narrower terms than that proposed originally by the Opposition. It is tightly worded but, we believe, strikes a reasonable balance between the demands, rights and requirements of the authors of the work and enables those people who are in an approved course of study and are enrolled external students to be able to make use, through the mechanism of asking somebody to make their copies for them, of fair dealing for this purpose. It does not give everything that the institutions originally wanted but, again, does strike that balance.

I seek the guidance of the Chair as to how the Committee wishes to deal with this stage of my amendments. I could move both amendments and we could discuss parts of them, because we have discussed some of them already. I propose to move Nos. 1 and 2 together, because the only other item with which they deal is media monitoring. This has meant that it appears in two sections. The first part appears in the first amendment, dealing with literary works, and the second part is in the second amendment dealing with, essentially, recordings.

As far as media monitoring is concerned, we have again sought a balance. It certainly does not provide everything that everybody sought but it is, essentially, a statutory licence mechanism which would mean that those people who wished to engage commercially in the monitoring of media would be able to enter into an agreement with the owner of that copyright; and, if such an agreement was unable to be reached, one could be achieved by use of the mechanism of the Copyright Tribunal. The other requirement, after the agreement for the payment had been determined by either of those two methods, would be that sufficient acknowledgment of the work would be made. This is not an onerous exercise because the correct designation of where a work comes from and where it was broadcast is an essential element within the business of monitoring the media anyhow. Hence, a sufficient acknowledgment is already made in all the media monitoring activities that take place in Australia.

Parts 3 and 4 come in because it may be, and often is, the case that the owner of the copyright to a work-and this is much more likely to be the case, I am informed, in the electronic media-finds a use for the monitoring services themselves. In the press world, it is well known that the monitoring of newspapers is a very well-developed industry in this country, and many media organisations themselves actually own the companies which provide those types of services. The monitoring of the electronic media is a relatively new field in Australia but probably, I suggest, adds weight to the reason why we should seek to provide a regime under which it can operate fairly and reasonably.

Newspapers are a continuing source of information; so a newspaper published today can be readily available to almost every citizen over a reasonable period throughout the rest of this year. Hence if one's attention is drawn to a particular article in a newspaper, there is no difficulty in getting a copy of it. By the ephemeral nature of broadcasting, when one's attention is drawn to a program, one does not normally have access to it. But I would remind senators in this place that they, in fact, do have access to broadcasts. They can find a copy of a news item or a current affairs item in our own library in this building. I am sure that every senator in this place has availed himself or herself of that monitoring facility carried out by our own library. I find it a bit odd that we should condone the exercise within our own premises, yet not seek to regularise it in the wider world.

Many citizens seek this facility. I will give the Minister an example which probably he will find interesting, both ideologically and factually. The Queensland Teachers Union, in my own State, has been running a very long and rigorous campaign with regard to class sizes. The union has a contract with an electronic monitoring service to provide it with instances when the issue of class sizes is debated, whether or not the Queensland Teachers Union is linked to such debate. In other words, if the Minister is broadcast on radio and makes claims about class sizes, the Queensland Teachers Union wants to know as part of its ongoing campaign to try to get the Government to lower the high numbers in many classes. That seems to me to be a perfectly reasonable means to use. After all, people who speak on radio or television, which are broadcast to everybody, cannot have any objection to the fact that what they say may be repeated. They have said it to everybody to start off with, and I fail to see why sensitivity should exist to their remarks being repeated. I find the Opposition's amendment far too broad. It does not recognise the countervailing pressure, which is that the owners of the copyright still own it and that one should not, as it were, be allowed with impunity, to copy, and make money out of, somebody else's property.

Seeking a balance-having freedom of information and the provision of information generally in the community, while trying to retain proper notions of copyright and ownership-led us to the notion, which, of course, is already partly embedded in other areas within these amendments, of a statutory licence. I know that it does not meet the position that the Opposition is mounting and that it does not meet the Government's position. However, I hope that it might be seen as an attempted rational and reasonable compromise, given the fact that the industries do exist-I refer to the electronic area and the press area-that they should exist because they offer a service, and that, indeed, the points that I have made are not made simply by me. I draw the Minister's attention to a speech made by the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, in March 1987. It is entitled `Keeping up with Copyright'. Amongst other things regarding this matter, the Attorney-General said:

I can give you one example from my own personal experience. Like most people in public life, I need to know what other people are saying about me and about the policies I am responsible for. As well as the ideas and opinions, I need to know the words used and the context of the comment. And I want to know quickly, while an issue is current.

If someone is able to monitor the media for me, at a reasonable price, they're providing a service which no broadcaster, for example, currently wants to provide. Yet, I understand, there is concern by some that these services breach copyright because they cannot obtain licences from relevant copyright owners.

The owners' reticence is hard to understand, particularly as it seems the services are used by broadcasting stations to monitor one another. I urge copyright owners to look hard at the private licensing route. If this is not feasible, a simple, narrowly drafted, free exemption for monitoring may be necessary, or a statutory licence.

In this Bill, which the Attorney-General brought in, the Government failed to go either of those ways. The Opposition, I think, has sought to take the route of free exemption for monitoring, while we have sought to go by the route of a statutory licence. Whichever method is chosen, some method should be chosen. I believe that if the statutory licence is not available, the words of the Attorney make it sufficiently clear that the Opposition's amendment, which goes the way of the `narrowly drafted free exemption for monitoring' unfortunately will be the only other avenue. I do not think that it is the best. I believe that the statutory licence is the moderate form, and it probably meets the objections of most of the people in the area, while not necessarily satisfying everybody.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the honourable senator moving his amendments 1 and 2?
—I seek leave to move Nos. 1 and 2 together, unless the Committee objects. They deal with the same matter.
—So the honourable senator is seeking leave?

—I am sorry, but I do not quite understand. Perhaps I have the wrong copy in front of me, but it seems to me that No. 2 embraces two different topics-external students, and media monitoring of what might be called the new technology.

—I indicated at the beginning of my remarks that the first new clause does, indeed, do that, but that the second embraces half of what the first one is about, though in the alternative area of the electronic media. The unfortunate thing is that, as both amendments refer to a section in the principal Act, the drafting was necessitated. I am happy, however, if the Committee so wishes, to split them in such a way that the first amendment deals only with media monitoring, stopping before clause 5b, which then becomes a separate amendment. In view of the distress that the Minister seems to be showing, that might be a reasonable way of going. Therefore, I seek to move amendment No. 1, excluding that part dealing with the new clause 5b, and amendment No. 2.
—I suggest that, of the honourable senator's amendment No. 1, it would be convenient to take that part dealing with new clause 5a, and all of his amendment No. 2. Is that correct?
—No. The situation is that new clause 5b deals with the external student problem, which we have already discussed.
—Why do we not get that out of the way?

—Why do we not deal with that as a separate amendment? I am happy to do that. In terms of drafting, it would probably have been easier if we had done it that way, but the suggested amendment is to the principal Act. The Opposition had the same difficulty with one of its amendments. In that case, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, after clause 5, insert the following new clause:
``5b. After subsection 40 (1) of the Principal Act the following new subsections are inserted:

`(1a) A fair dealing with a literary work (other than lecture notes) does not constitute an infringement of the copyright in the work if it is for the purpose of, or associated with, an approved course of study or research by an enrolled external student of an educational institution.

(1b) In subsection (1a) the expression `lecture notes' means any literary work produced for the purpose of the course of study or research by a person lecturing or teaching in or in connection with the course of study or research.'.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated earlier that we would support that, though not as our preferred option. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) indicated earlier that if the Government were forced to choose between the two of us, it would prefer the Democrats' amendment. We, in turn, prefer the Democrats' amendment to the Government's regulatory suggestion. On that basis, the Opposition will support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record, I indicate that I shall be opposing this proposal. I understand that it will be carried because of the concurrence of Senator Hill in the proposition. However, I want to put it on the record that we still believe that our proposal-that the Copyright Tribunal devise a scheme, using its expertise and knowledge of institutions, sampling techniques, and so on, to discount the royalty rate that would be paid in respect of a body of external students being provided with education by one of these institutions-is the preferred course. Nevertheless, I can see the logic of the argument.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed new clause agreed to.
Proposed new clauses 5a and 10b.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, after clause 5, insert the following new clause:
``5a. After section 47a of the Principal Act, the following new section is inserted:
Copyright in literary work monitoring news

`47b. (1) Subject to this section, the copyright in a literary work is not infringed by the making of copies of the whole or a part of the work for the purposes of the monitoring of news, advertisements or current affairs.
`(2) Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to a copy of a work unless:

(a) the person making the copy has paid to the owner of the copyright in the work such amount as they agree, and on such terms as are agreed, or, in default of agreement, has given an undertaking in writing to the owner to pay to him or her such amount, and on such terms, as is determined by the Copyright Tribunal, on the application of either of them, to be equitable remuneration to the owner for the making of the copy; and
(b) sufficient acknowledgement of the work is made.

`(3) Where the Copyright Tribunal has under subsection (2) determined the amount of equitable remuneration payable by a person to the owner of a copyright in a work, the owner of the copyright may recover that amount from the person in a court of competent jurisdiction as a debt due to the owner of the copyright.

`(4) Nothing in this section affects the right of the owner of the copyright in a literary work to grant a licence authorizing a person to make a copy for the purposes of the monitoring of news or current affairs without infringement of that copyright.'.
(2) Page 5, after clause 10a, insert the following new clause:
``10b. After section 110b of the Principal Act, the following new section is inserted:

`110c. (1) Subject to this section the copyright in sound recordings, cinematograph films, sound broadcasts or television broadcasts (in this section referred to as an `item' or `such an item') is not infringed by the making of copies of the whole or a part of such an item for the purposes of the monitoring of news, advertisements or current affairs.
`(2) Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to a copy of such an item unless:

(a) the person making the copy has paid to the owner of the copyright in the work such amount as they agree, and on such terms as are agreed, or, in default of agreement, has given an undertaking in writing to the owner to pay to him or her such amount, and on such terms, as is determined by the Copyright Tribunal, on the application of either of them, to be equitable remuneration to the owner for the making of the copy; and
(b) sufficient acknowledgement of the item is made.

`(3) Where the Copyright Tribunal has under subsection (2) determined the amount of equitable remuneration payable by a person to the owner of a copyright in an item, the owner of the copyright may recover that amount from the person in a court of competent jurisdiction as a debt due to the owner of the copyright.

`(4) Nothing in this section affects the right of the owner of the copyright in such an item to grant a licence authorizing a person to make a copy for the purposes of the monitoring of news or current affairs without infringement of that copyright.'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is a lot more to be said, except that we believe that there has been confusion in the argument-although I do not say that there has been confusion from the lips of Senator Macklin on this occasion. There is no question of the refusal by copyright owners to acknowledge the part played by media monitors in distributing further particular material so that the public, or a particular organisation such as the Queensland Teachers Union, can become aware of matters of interest and concern to them that have been reported, whether in print, or in some form of the electronic media.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin spoke about ideology a moment ago. I believe that this matter should be left to the consultations, the negotiations-tortuous though they are-between copyright owners and media monitors which, at this moment, are being determined partly by an attempt to come to a voluntary licensing arrangement between them. It is something which they can work out. After all, I think it is worth recalling that we are talking about business enterprises. Senator Macklin said, for example, that the Queensland Teachers Union enters into a contract with the media monitors and pays them a sum of money for the performance of a monitoring service. As I see it, there is no reason why the contract could not include a sum of money-obviously the media monitor would make sure that it is passed on to the consumer; in this case, the Queensland Teachers Union-to be paid to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Reuters, Channel 9, or whoever it is who provides the original news item broadcast on television, radio, or whatever it may be. It seems to me that something could be worked out.

As honourable senators know, at the moment quite protracted legal proceedings are being engaged in. Between those legal proceedings and the sort of pressure which is being brought to bear, a voluntary arrangement would be far better than a statutory one. In other words, if one is speaking ideologically-and this is what surprises me about Senator Hill's and the Opposition's stance in this matter-I would have thought that in this case, where one is dealing with arrangements which ought to be in place between business enterprises, it would be best to leave them to try to work it out in terms of the law of contract and a voluntary arrangement rather than imposing on them a statutory regime. For that reason the Government remains opposed to this proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment which is before the chamber now is very different from what was included in our amendments. I am not too sure whether I actually moved our two amendments earlier in the day or whether I just foreshadowed them.
—You foreshadowed them.

—I would like to have on the record our amendment No. 4, excluding the latter part which dealt with fair dealing in audiovisual material, which part of the amendment was agreed to. As I am not able to move those amendments I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard our proposed changes to proposed new sections 103c and 103d which were contained in the first two parts of amendment No. 4 so that we will all know what we are talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
4. Page 5, new clause 10a, before proposed section 103e, insert the following new sections:
Fair dealing with sound or television broadcasts

`` `103c. A dealing by way of the copying of the whole or part of a sound broadcast or television broadcast does not constitute an infringement of copyright in the broadcast or in any work or other audio-visual item included in the broadcast if it is for the purpose of, or is associated with, the monitoring and reporting of news or other broadcast material to persons or organizations mentioned in or affected by the broadcast, and a sufficient acknowledgement of the broadcast is made.
Fair dealing with certain print material

`103d (1) A dealing by way of the copying of a cutting or other extract from a newspaper, magazine or journal does not constitute an infringement of copyright if it is for the purpose of, or is associated with, the monitoring and reporting of news or opinion to persons or organizations mentioned in or affected by the cutting or other extract, and a sufficient acknowledgement of the source of the cutting or extract is made.
`(2) This section applies only to a dealing occurring after the commencement of this section.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. Our approach was quite clear. As far as we were concerned, we were dealing with the dissemination of information which we think is a laudable objective and one to be supported. We are all aware of the extent of the development of media monitoring in this country. It serves a very useful purpose for all of us. Basically, an organisation collects news or information from the media which will be of benefit to the selective interest of that organisation's clients.
—Don't you think it somewhat parasitical if no payment is made?

—I know what the Minister is saying. But I liken it very much to the position in which I find myself in this building. If I visit the Parliamentary Library and have an hour to spare I can go through each of 12 daily newspapers and find the relevant bits of news or information that come under the headings, `justice', `status of women', or `the Australian Capital Territory'. Alternatively, I can make use of the services of a media monitoring unit which will take from those 12 newspapers each of the bits of information under those headings and send it to me.
—And you will pay them.

—But the newspapers are already in the Library. Using this personal example, the end result is that the same number of newspapers are being purchased; it is just that the information gets to me in a more efficient way. I am giving an example as one parliamentarian. I guess that I am somewhat privileged because, as a parliamentarian, I am excluded from the provisions of the Act in any event. There is already an exclusion for the type of work that we do. Obviously, a myriad of people in various industries wish to have the information that is published in newspapers-and I am dealing only with newspapers at the moment. A similar argument applies in relation to electronic information which, in many ways, is a more important argument because unless it is copied at that time it tends to be lost forever. People see benefit in engaging someone to take information from existing published material and communicate that information to the client.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Tate in his example was referring to someone who copies that information but, as Senator Tate would know, some of these services simply cut out the relevant parts from already purchased newspapers. It seems that this argument is not as simple as that which Senator Tate is attempting to communicate. I see that there are arguments on both sides. In balancing these arguments we thought there was greater benefit in getting the broadest possible communication of information in the most specified form. It seems to us that this can only be of benefit to the whole community.

We were going to move-and I have now had incorporated in Hansard-our two proposed amendments, the first of which deals with the question of monitoring news or other broadcast material and the second of which deals with the copying of a cutting or other extract from a newspaper, magazine or journal. The Australian Democrats have gone down a different path. One of the amendments that they moved set up a form of licence. I see some immediate difficulties, and I regret that I am having to take this on the run. The first of the Democrats' amendments deals with the printed word. The amendment states that the person making the copy has to pay to the owner of the copyright in such work such amount as they agree. Presuming that the law, when it is finally settled, is that the ownership of the property remains with the journalist, that seems to me to indicate that there would have to be an agreement between the monitoring company and each and every journalist. As part of the objective of these monitoring schemes is to get the information quickly to the party that can make use of it, I am somewhat concerned that what is being set up is an impossible barrier. That is one concern that immediately comes to me when I look for the first time at this amendment. I regret that I have not had an opportunity to study in any detail the language used in Senator Macklin's amendment in relation to copying of electronic media information.

I would like to confer with Senator Macklin and with a couple of my colleagues on this matter. Would the Minister be prepared to facilitate that? I shall require only a few minutes. In the meantime, although it is jumping the order, the Committee might be prepared to deal with the amendment that the Minister agreed with Senator Puplick earlier in the day and which no doubt he can now handle. It provides for the tabling of an annual report by one of the associations and is an amendment to clause 13, on page 29 of the Bill. That would give me a couple of minutes to seek some advice.
Further consideration of proposed new clauses postponed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The suggestion I was making was that in proposed new section 135zzd an amendment be moved to insert a new subsection (7) which would be parallel to the amendment which the Minister for Justice accepted to clause 135r. This was to provide that the collecting society which is referred to in this proposed new section should prepare an annual report as it is required to do under the other provisions of 135zzd and that that annual report should be presented to the Parliament through the Attorney-General in the same way as we have already established in 135r and in 135zzw. The Minister has agreed to incorporate in 135r, the form of words used in 135zzw. Therefore I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 28, clause 13, after proposed subsection 13522d (1), insert the following new subsection:

``(1a) The Attorney-General shall cause a copy of the report sent to the Attorney-General under subsection (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the receipt of the report by the Attorney-General.''.

As I understand it the Minister has no objection in principle to ensuring that these annual reports are presented to Parliament. We will have three sets of collecting societies. One is dealt with in clause 135r which operates in relation to part Va of the Bill, `Copying of television broadcasts by educational and other institutions'. We will have the same annual report structures inserted in 135zzw which relate to part Vc of the Bill, which relates to the use of blank tapes for private and domestic copying. This will ensure that those parts of the Bill which are established under part Vb `Copying of works etc. by educational and other institutions' will also have precisely the same regime imposed in regard to annual reports.

Therefore, we have three sets of collecting societies established under the three parts of part V. In each there will be a requirement not only that they report to the Attorney-General, that they keep their accounts and records correctly, that they enable people to have access to them, that they are properly audited, that members have access to them, and that they comply with any obligations which are established under the law of each State or Territory where the collecting society may be an incorporating body, but also that the Parliament is provided with the information which has been provided to the Attorney-General and to the corporate affairs commissions and whatever it happens to be. Therefore, the Opposition seeks the Minister's cooperation to facilitate that amendment in line with things that have already been inserted into other parts of part V of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to indicate that the very great eloquence of Senator Puplick has struck a responsive chord because he, as I think is proper in this chamber, has a real appreciation of the part that Parliament should play in putting under scrutiny the work of those organisations which are put into a position of some prominence and which exercise some power within our society. It is only fitting in relation to annual reports of such societies as the collecting societies, for example, whose functions are outlined in proposed new section 135r, that such a society upon which such responsibilities are placed shall keep accounting records correctly recording and explaining the transactions of the society, including any transactions as trustee and the financial position of the society. It is also a requirement that the accounting records be kept in such a manner as will enable true and fair accounts of the society to be prepared from time to time and for those accounts to be conveniently and properly audited.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for Parliament to make that requirement and impose that responsibility and obligation on the collecting society, but for the Parliament then to walk away from any scrutiny or supervision of the implementation of that requirement or to see whether that obligation has been discharged properly and adequately is, if not a dereliction of duty, something that can be so easily remedied by having the collecting society report to the Parliament and one should take advantage of that opportunity. Indeed, the Attorney-General is to receive a copy of the accounts as so audited. Although it is true that the members of the society can have access to that report and all audited accounts provided under the provision to which I refer, it is perhaps also a good thing that those members of parliament who are concerned to see that the collecting society operates in a way which is in proper discharge of its obligations should have an opportunity to put that under scrutiny.

I believe that in accepting the sorts of parliamentary scrutiny that are outlined by the simple matter of putting an annual report into the Parliament provides an occasion for debate, and perhaps for wider circulation of the report than would be the case if members simply had access to the collecting society's report and to the various audited accounts. I believe that it is essential that Parliament exercise this particular supervisory role, to ensure not only that we as senators are satisfied with the role that we have given to this collecting society, but also that a wider public has access to and knowledge of and is satisfied about the fact that the collecting society is properly discharging its obligation. It is very fitting and not unexpected that this sort of amendment is put forward in this chamber, which of course has a proud record of being concerned to ensure that not merely the Executive is the repository of such reports so that proper general supervision of these sorts of organisations by the elected representatives of the people can take place. For that reason the Government will accept the amendment.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Postponed new clauses 5a and 10b.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to the media monitoring provisions and the amendments of Senator Macklin. We, having given this matter consideration in the short time available, have decided that we should not support them at this time. It has become clear to us that the majority in this place, that is, the Government and the Australian Democrats, are not prepared to accept our position in relation to media monitoring, although we think there are good arguments for it. It seems from reading the letters of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that he thought there were good arguments for it as well. Nevertheless, the Government is the Government and has now overridden-that word may be a bit strong-the Attorney-General. It has taken a position which is opposed to legislating to allow free use of materials, either broadcast or printed, for the purpose of media monitoring organisations. The Australian Democrats have made clear that they are opposed to that position as well and, therefore, I guess the lesson that is now on the record is that this Parliament will not legislate in the form that we have been advocating.

SPEECH.PARA: That really takes us to the next stage of the debate, that is, whether there should be some form of licence. It is clear on all sides of the chamber that there should be access to the materials in order that information be disseminated as widely as possible. It is the view of the majority in this chamber that it should be information that the media monitors have paid for.

The detail of such a proposed licensing system is something we think should be given careful consideration in an environment that is not rushed. In fact, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), if I correctly understand his presentation tonight, thinks that a better course of action might be to allow the parties further time to see whether they can reach some form of voluntary licensing arrangement. I guess they will be aided by the debate tonight because they now clearly appreciate where the majority view in this Parliament lies.

Short of some voluntary arrangement, there would appear to be no sensible alternative but to move to a regulatory licensing regime. That is something that would have to be considered in due course. I presume that the Government will take the matter on board and will in the not too distant future advise the Parliament where it proposes to go in relation to media monitoring, because an unsatisfactory state of affairs seems to exist at the moment. It is unsatisfactory not only because there is current litigation but also because these organisations, which we believe are fulfilling a particularly worthwhile public service, have felt it necessary to press for amendments to clarify their rights in legislative form.

I am not indicating that we will forever oppose the licensing system but the merits of the licensing system require further consideration from our point of view. Obviously, if we get past the question of principle, the detail requires careful and considered application. We are therefore not prepared to accept the Democrats' amendments at this time. I have indicated accordingly to Senator Macklin. Because Senator Macklin's amendments will now be defeated, I have indicated to him that I see it as pointless and contrary to the spirit in which we have conducted this debate to seek to persist with our amendments. Rather, we will simply leave them in Hansard as an indication of our preferred approach in this difficult area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is somewhat disappointing. One would have hoped that we may have been able to come to some resolution of this matter because it is obviously important, affecting quite a number of companies and the services provided to a very large range of people. It is probably appropriate, given the lack of support for the scheme that I have proposed, that I now withdraw my amendments. I too would hope that in withdrawing those amendments the Government will move with speed to rectify the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has already referred to the Federal Court case that involves a dispute between members of the Australian Journalists Association and a media monitoring service. I do not believe that the outcome of that particular case should necessarily set the way in which we should go. It was embedded within a previous approach to copyright. I believe that I am expressing views very similar to those expressed in the speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to which I have referred that this is one item that needs to be resolved in recognition of the fact that we are moving into a new and more complex context with regard to copyright. If we do not come to grips with these types of items very early on, all we will do is induce people to seek remedy at law in a very expensive way or to operate on the margins of the law not knowing whether what they are doing is legally correct.

I do not believe that it assists the respect that is due to the law if we simply allow this matter to meander until the judges make some decision in the absence of the Parliament managing to get its act together and making a decision in this area. The fact that it is difficult and that there are conflicting rights and obligations is nothing new in the parliamentary context. It is something with which we have to deal every day. I believe a decision should be made. We should operate on that and then review it. It is most ill advised for this matter just simply to be left up in the air for another couple of years. I hope that the Government will use whatever powers it has available-it does have some powers available under regulations with regard to this legislation-to seek to do what it can do to regularise the situation so that all those people concerned will know precisely where they stand. Although they may not be happy with the outcome, at least it will be very clear where they stand. The only assurance given in this context is that the media monitoring services must remain, will remain and are an essential service that people require. I think on that basis we should seek to make sure that they can remain. They will do so only if they remain as profitable organisations. So the fees which are set, if any, cannot be of a kind which would drive these companies out of business. With those comments, I withdraw the two amendments that I have moved with regard to the media monitoring service and hope that the Government will move with speed to rectify the situation.
Amendments-by leave-withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just comment very briefly on the situation as it has developed and simply say that this is an extremely complex area. I think it is correct to say that the meandering, if that is the term which Senator Macklin used, in relation to this matter has to come to an end at some stage. Whether it will require parliamentary intervention and the imposition of a statutory scheme on what really are two business enterprises-media monitors contracting their services to those who wish to be informed of particular items of interest or concern to them, and the owners of copyright in the print media or in the electronic media-or whether some voluntary agreement can be worked out will depend at least in part on the outcome of the case before the Federal Court between the Australian Journalists Association and media monitors. That may give some guidance and provide some impetus or pressure for a coming together of the parties so that a nationwide voluntary scheme can be arrived at. If we do not have to get involved, then so much the better, but if indeed it proves the case that the media monitors and the various organisations which have copyright in various broadcast material or published material cannot get together, then Senator Hill and Senator Macklin have quite correctly indicated that the matter would need to be returned to the Parliament for our decision. To make a decision in this area would not be easy, but I do think that, as always, the sort of balance that must be achieved between the two parties is something with which we are familiar as parliamentarians and a decision will be forth- coming. All I can do is give an undertaking to the Senate chamber that on the bringing down of the decision by the Federal Court we will all be in a much better position to understand what the next step ought to be.

SPEECH.PARA: Postponed clause 12, as amended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats argued that our amendment No. 7 was drawn too widely. What we were talking about-the request of the vice-chancellors, principals and directors of colleges of advanced education-was extending the new provisions in the Bill which cover copying of television to include copying of radio and other existing audiovisual material. The Australian Democrats have indicated that they would not support the last part of that proposal and therefore would be prepared to accept our amendment only in a more restricted form. I have circulated an amendment, which I hope honourable senators have received, headed `Revised' at the top. It is an amendment to be moved by the Opposition in Committee of the whole in substitution for Opposition amendment No. 7 which is intended to limit our original amendment to the question of copying radio broadcasts.
—Senator Hill, would you first seek leave to withdraw the original amendment No. 7.
—No, I do not want to do that because this is an amendment to our amendment.
—The circulated paper says that it is an amendment to be moved in substitution for Opposition amendment No. 7.

—I know it says that, but I do not think that is quite right. This will all be overcome because I will now seek leave to withdraw our amendment and replace it with drafting that has been done by the parliamentary counsel, the Government having been sufficiently wise to realise that if an amendment of this nature is to pass, then it should perhaps be passed in language that the parliamentary counsel believes is most suited to the task which it seeks to address. I therefore seek leave to withdraw my amendment No. 7.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 5, clause 12, heading to proposed Part Va, line 31, leave out ``TELEVISION''.
(2) Pages 5 to 15, clause 12, proposed Part Va (other than proposed section 135B), line 33 (page 5) to line 20 (page 15), leave out ``television'' (wherever occurring).
(3) Page 5, clause 12, proposed section 135A, after the definition of ``, administering body'', insert the following new definition:
`` `broadcast' means a sound broadcast or a television broadcast;''.
(4) Page 6, clause 12, proposed section 135B, lines 21 to 27, leave out the proposed section, insert the following section:
Copies of broadcasts
``135B. In this Part:
(a) a reference to a copy of a broadcast is a reference to a record embodying a sound recording of the broadcast or a copy of a cinematograph film of the broadcast; and
(b) a reference to the making of a copy of a broadcast is a reference to the making of a copy of the whole or a part of the broadcast.''.
5. Page 6, clause 12, heading to proposed Division 2, line 39, leave out ``television''.

The argument has been put. I do not think that we need to waste further time of the Committee on that. The argument for radio broadcasts was convincingly put with due modesty earlier in the day. The only matter that I think should go on the record because I am just a little worried about it is that, as I understand it, this provision will not in any way limit the existing section 200 of the Act which, as the Minister points out, provides that educational material which is broadcast is exempted from the provisions of the Act. What we are providing here is a licensing regime for radio broadcasts that are copied by educational institutions for use for educational purposes which is in addition to the existing provisions that are included in section 200, not in substitution thereof. I understand that the Government advises that that is the correct interpretation and I certainly want that to be so. On that basis I do not wish to add anything further at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the purpose of the record and for the readers of the Hansard, I might just confirm that my advice is that section 200 which deals with educational broadcasts is not affected by this provision and stands supplemented by this provision rather than displaced by it.

-I indicate that we support the redraft. As Senator Hill indicated, we felt that the original proposition was far too broad. The redraft that the Government has provided is certainly a more elegant one for achieving Senator Hill's original intention-that sound broadcasts should also be able to be included under this context. May I just say that I have appreciated the debate in Committee. I think that while it may have seemed to observers-if anybody has managed to observe all of what has been said-to be somewhat a difficult task, it reflects only in small measure the enormous problems the Government has had in getting this Bill drafted and the problems which we have had and, which Senator Hill would probably acknowledge, in trying to come to grips with the complexities and, more importantly, in trying to come to grips with the conflicting principles involved in this area of copyright. I think it is useful that we have been able to have this type of debate in this area--
—You would never have had it in the House of Representatives.

—No, it is certainly something, as Senator Hill suggests, which the House of Representatives would have been incapable of doing. The debate that we have had probably exemplifies the best of what this place is capable of doing during the Committee stage. My only regret is that we are not able to deal with legislation in such detail more often.
—I would like the Government to confirm that matter I raised in respect of section 200.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did. I got to my feet and said that it was my understanding and advice that this provision supplements section 200 and in no way displaces or modifies it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a third time.

I also thank those senators who have contributed to a most complex debate. It may have looked fragmented and disjointed from the outside, but it always had a certain momentum and flow which those of us in the chamber understood. It has been extremely complex. I wish to thank those honourable senators who contributed. I thank the occupants of the chair and the advisers who provided constant advice and succour to me and to Opposition and Democrat senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 April, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted on 7 April I was talking about Senator Puplick's suggestion that the Opposition was going to move an amendment to require the Electoral Commission to take account of the voting intentions in an election to ensure that 50 per cent plus one of the popular vote represented the majority in the number of seats won.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said at the time, this is a proposition which has been tried before by the Liberal Party of Australia. I remember in 1976 in South Australia when the one vote one value Bill was first accepted and introduced in South Australia by the Dunstan Labor Government. The Liberal Party tried to convince the then Independent Electoral Commission in South Australia that it should draw electoral boundaries taking account of voting results per polling booth, as this was a way of defining community of interest. If one had taken it that way, one would have ended up with the most extraordinary electoral boundaries. One would have probably ended up with seats which would have never changed hands at election time. One would have had seats, by definition, that were overwhelmingly Liberal or overwhelmingly Labor.

It is technically not a feasible proposition. It will not work. It has not worked anywhere else in the world where there is a single constituency system. If Senator Puplick wants that proposal to work he will have to go and adopt the whole hog approach of a proportional representation system on a list voting system that applies in particular in a number of Western European countries. It cannot be done, however, in a single constituency system in Australia.

I also note that he and other Liberal Party spokespeople have complained bitterly about the Western Australian election result earlier this year in that in the two-party preferred result the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia got over 50 per cent of the vote and the Australian Labor Party (ALP) got less than 50 per cent. I do not dispute that. That is clear from a mathematical analysis of all the votes counted. It is true that on a two-party preferred basis, the Liberal Party would have won the election. It did not win the election because it refused to support the introduction of one vote one value in Western Australia when that proposal was put forward by the Burke Labor Government two or three years ago. It wanted to keep the bias in favour of rural electorates; to have larger enrolments in the city and lower enrolments in the rural areas.

The irony is that it is probable that if they had supported the Burke Government proposal for one vote one value, they would be the government of Western Australia today. I think it is one of the great and deliciously sweet ironies of Australian politics that the parties which opposed the introduction of one vote one value-which has been ALP national policy for over 20 years-paid the penalty, in a short-sighted way, in supporting a rural gerrymander, because that was all the Burke Government could get at the time. What happened to them, much to their chagrin, was that the Labor Party did very well in the small rural electorates of northern Western Australia. I understand that the whole of outback Western Australia is now represented by Labor Party electorates; they are much smaller in terms of enrolment, but that is what the Liberal party insisted upon two or three years ago.

Senator Chaney and Senator Puplick cry out now about how unfair it is. It is unfair, but that is what they wanted. I suggest to them that they contact the Western Australian State Liberal Party and suggest that it introduce and support a Labor Party policy for one vote one value in Western Australia. That might mean that the Liberal Party might win a future election. But the Labor Party's view is very well known on this matter.

Senator Puplick suggested that we should be holding up this Bill until we get the report from the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on its review of the 1987 Federal election, because these proposals come from the review of the 1984 Federal election. As a member of that Joint Standing Committee, I would have to say to Senator Puplick that I do not believe we would have those recommendations ready in time to be dealt with by the end of this year. We would then be getting very close to the next Federal election. One thing that we are dealing with which has created some controversy and which I hope this chamber will be able to debate some time before the next election is the question of election advertising on television and radio. The Joint Standing Committee is receiving evidence from television stations and from other witnesses about the high cost for all political parties of election advertising on television and radio, but television in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —Think how much would be saved if we banned it outright on television.

—On recent figures, it would save at least $5m or $6m. The television stations and networks have been saying that if we ban paid political advertising on television and radio we will infringe people's political rights to free expression. That is a very hollow suggestion. If we do not have large amounts of money, we cannot advertise on television. Senator Haines suggests that the Australian Democrats are short of a quid now and again. Even the Australian Labor Party is short of a quid more than now and again and I suggest that the Liberal Party is short of a quid to pay for the level of television advertising it would like.
—Are you saying we should ban it?

—The way the evidence is going-we have not completed the hearings-there is a growing case to say that we should restrict or ban paid television and radio advertising and make it a requirement under the public function of commercial broadcasters that there is a limited amount of free time available on a proportionate basis to all political parties.

SPEECH.PARA: We could also look at an option which has been raised in Committee hearings. In 1976 the Australian Government banned outright all tobacco advertising on television. The television stations did not like it. It cost them a lot of revenue. They did not go broke; they are still in operation. Maybe we should just ban full stop paid advertising on television and radio and just allow television and radio to carry out the editorial function of providing election coverage in current affairs and news services. I suspect a majority of viewers and listeners in Australia would not be upset with the proposition that for four weeks of a federal election campaign they would not be bombarded with a saturation coverage of political advertising.

There are fundamental issues about access and equity in running election campaigns. The Parliament and the Australian community must come to grips with what the high costs of television and radio advertising, particularly television costs, are doing to the operation of democracy in Australia. In the end, it will mean that the two major political parties will have to beggar themselves to those who make the major contributions.

I can say openly that in the last 10 or 15 years the Labor Party, like the Liberal Party, has overwhelmingly relied on corporate donations to pay for its election expenses-its television costs. I do not believe it is healthy for the Labor Party, the Liberal Party, or even the Queensland National Party, to have to rely on donations from one sector of the community alone to pay for advertising to conduct their election campaigns. In the end, it means that it will bend and twist the function of political parties. Irrespective of our political backgrounds and our other political differences, it is incumbent upon all political parties to ensure that into the next century party political activity in Australia and parliamentary democracy can operate openly without the destructive impact of the high cost of election campaigning.

I look forward to participating further in discussions with the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters as it deals with this issue. Without prejudging what the Committee may recommend, I certainly hope that it comes forward with a constructive suggestion to put before the Parliament to overcome this pressing problem in the operation of democracy in Australia. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Debate on the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1988 has been on again, off again for some considerable time. The Bill was first introduced into the Parliament something like 12 months ago, so it has been lying around for a considerable time. That has caused various problems of a nature which would warrant the Government's withdrawing the Bill for the time being and waiting on the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, to which Senator Schacht referred. The Committee will be reporting to the Parliament, it is hoped, by the end of this session.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems odd to me that we are now debating a Bill which is about to become outdated, or at least overtaken. The Bill before us contains various amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act and to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act, but the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters is winding up its report on changes to the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act in light of the experience of the 1988 referendums and the 1987 general federal election.

As a member of the Joint Standing Committee, I, like Senator Schacht, am constrained in what I can say on it at this stage, but it is quite clear that the very broad-ranging nature of the reference before the Joint Standing Committee means that it will make a wide range of recommendations, some of which will be quite fundamental. It would seem to be no more than commonsense to delay the finalisation of this Bill-indeed, to withdraw this Bill-until such time as the Parliament can look at what is proposed in it along with the very wide range of recommendations which will be forthcoming. My first point is that it is unfortunate that we are debating the Bill at all at this time, because it should be deferred pending the Joint Standing Committee's report.

The Bill is designed to give legislative effect to the remaining acceptable recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform that reported in 1984 and again in 1986. The recommendations that are in those reports of what was then the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, which are swept up into this Bill, have been around for some considerable time. Indeed, because they have been around for some considerable time, I am very surprised indeed that the Bill in several respects is very shoddy in its drafting. Perhaps I should not be surprised at that because we have seen increasing evidence in recent times of a very dangerous shoddiness of drafting in legislation coming before the Parliament. It has been of such a nature that the legislation has required an enormous number of amendments. In many cases, I guess we have not picked up the faults that have been in the legislation before us and so have enacted faulty legislation.

For example, in the second reading speech it is said that the Bill is to provide a fixed formula for the representation of Territories and new States in the Federal Parliament. That is not correct. The Bill is not able to provide formulae for the representation of new States in the Federal Parliament. That matter will have to be looked at quite separately. Such is the nature of the drafting of the Bill and the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) that that was not picked up.

The recommendations in the Bill are numerous and in the committee stage we will propose various amendments to the Bill as it is presently drafted. I will not go into those tonight because they will be the subject of a committee debate. However, I foreshadow, as did Senator Puplick on the Opposition's behalf, that we will oppose several of the amendments contained in the Bill. What I wish to do tonight in the second reading is raise several points concerning the whole area of electoral matters, including the question of just how easy we have made the electoral system over recent years to be subject to fraud. The integrity of the electoral system is an important issue for the confidence of the electorate, for the confidence of the nation. To say that we really have a democratic system is as important as anything else that we can do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought Bishop was the expert on fraud. She is the biggest fraud of the lot.
—Order! Senator Walsh, you must withdraw that statement.
—I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President.

—I will not rise too much to Senator Walsh's bait except to say that we do not have to scratch his Party too hard when we are considering fraud in electoral matters and many other matters as well. All we need to do is look at the interim report on Rothwells Ltd that was tabled and debated in this place yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Returning to the question of fraud in the electoral system, I repeat what I said: if voters lose confidence in the integrity of our rolls, our voting systems and our voting procedures, we have put a very large dent in our democratic process. I do not necessarily point the finger at this Government but what has happened to a very marked extent under this Government in recent years has resulted in the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the electoral process in this country being made far too easy to manipulate. That statement has been echoed by many people around the country. Indeed, the Report of the Inquiry into the Operations and Processes for the Conduct of State Elections, which was released a couple of months ago in New South Wales, made a very similar point. The commissioners of that inquiry were very expert people in this area. They were the New South Wales State Electoral Commissioner for the period 1974 to 1982, who was appointed by the Askin Government, and Mr Dickson, who is present State Electoral Commissioner for New South Wales, who was appointed by the Wran Government. So it would be difficult to say that that committee was biased in any way. That committee, which reported a couple of months ago, said:

That the electoral system as it presently exists is open to manipulation is beyond question but the deliberate perpetration of electoral fraud on a major scale is much less certain. Nevertheless the possibility exists that it could occur and consequently steps should be taken to ensure that it does not. To be more precise, loopholes are evident in both the areas of enrolment and voting.
The Committee said further:
The Committee believes that there are mechanisms available to the electoral administration to virtually eliminate fraudulent voting.

Some of the voting that the Committee referred to in the report was votes being cast in the names of deceased electors, called cemetery voting. That can have different connotations. Indeed, in a roll cleanse in one of the New South Wales electorates near Canberra for the last State election the address found on the electoral roll against some names was the cemetery. If people had gone to do a habitation review, they would have ended up in the cemetery.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were honest.

—They were perhaps more honest than some of the other cemetery voters. The committee reported that cemetery voting was hard to quantify but that it is a problem. A bigger problem is multiple voting. It occurs with much greater regularity. This is where more than one vote is recorded at an election beside the name of a particular enrollee.
—Not necessarily by that person.
—Not necessarily by that person. The old Labor Party adage was vote early, vote often. That is pretty much to the fore when it comes to multiple voting.
—That was Fred Daly's suggestion.

—Yes. I think he picked it up from the Australian Labor Party, though. It may well have been before Senator Schacht's time but it was his Party, nevertheless. Multiple voting is a problem and an issue. In all Federal elections and in recent State elections, multiple voting has been a problem. On investigation, it is said not to have been a sufficient enough problem to have caused a false result in any electorate. I accept that point but the fact that it can and does arise-and the evidence I have suggests that it is on the increase-makes me increasingly worried about where the electoral system is going. We have become too user friendly in terms of what we have done to the electoral system and that is something we should be looking at very carefully.
—He could have been user hostile.

—A balance has to be struck. The sysem must not be made so user friendly that it is susceptible to fraud. Certainly on this side of politics we want it wiped out. When this side of politics does become the Government following the next election I would be absolutely amazed if we do not take steps to change the system so as to make it much more difficult for the electoral rolls and the electoral process to be manipulated. The Bill does not touch at all on the question of electoral fraud and the ease with which it can be perpetrated. If we are really serious about doing something about the electoral system that is something that we should take into account when discussing important pieces of legislation such as this one.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to the question of the cleanliness of the electoral rolls. Every member of this Parliament knows, because of our day to day contact with constituents, including new enrollees, that the electoral rolls are in a very unclean state. I am sure that all senators send communications to people who have newly come onto the electoral roll. We are advised about the people who have come onto the electoral roll within a couple of weeks of their registering. The proportion of new enrollee letters that are returned to our offices is very high indeed. I cannot understand how we can have a return rate of other than minuscule proportions of new enrollee letters because the address to which the letters are sent should not be more than a couple of weeks or a month or so old. Therefore, there should be virtually a nil return of letters from those addresses, but in fact we get a not insignificant proportion. The Commonwealth Electoral Commission admitted that, as of 31 December 1987, only five months after a Federal election, in my State of Victoria alone there were 60,000 people on the electoral roll who should not have been there. They were only identified after the election had occurred. Had that roll been clean, in the sense of being accurate, the result of the 1987 election in some of the key marginal seats in Victoria-because that was probably the State, more than any other, where the election was lost for the Liberal Party and National Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Queensland? They lost four seats.

—Yes, Queensland as well. Had the roll been accurate, the results in some of those marginal electorates could well have been different. We will never know whether the results would have been different, but the fact remains that 60,000 people were identified as being on the roll who should not have been. That must open up the possibility that the election results, particularly in close electorates, may well have been different had the roll been more accurate.

SPEECH.PARA: What I have never understood in our system is that the state of the roll is not a valid reason for challenging the outcome of an election result. In the seat of Ballarat South in my own State of Victoria, which the Liberal Party lost at the last Victorian State election by 103 votes-that is 52 voters-1,506 names on the roll were identified as not being legitimately on the roll. Despite that, that fact was not allowable as a reason for disputing the result of the election. That is crazy. It is something which we ought to look at on a bipartisan basis. It is not a matter of necessarily favouring one party rather than another. Certainly the situation of the roll and its cleanliness is something which we ought to look at much more closely than we have. That raises such fundamental questions, which are not addressed in this Bill, as to whether there could be an earlier cut-off date than now exists for the closing of the roll after the calling of an election.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Fraser did in 1983-just three hours. There is a lot of democracy in that.

—The senator should calm down. That is a matter which we ought to, and should, be able to discuss sensibly. It is something which the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, of which Senator Schacht and I are members, should address. Those matters are not addressed in this Bill. We need to look at them. I do not make a judgment at this stage as to what my view would be as to the appropriate time for the closing of the roll. All I am saying is that it is an important issue which we should look at, and which this Bill does not address.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing that concerns me is that there is no guarantee that members of parliament or members of the public will have available to them a printed electoral roll in time for consideration at an election. There has not been a printed electoral roll in this country since 1984. The last hard copy of an electoral roll that was generally available was printed in 1984. That is patently a totally unsatisfactory situation. We need to consider whether a printed roll should be available a certain time prior to a Federal election.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a matter that the Committee is looking at, I believe.

—It is a matter which the Committee is considering, and we should make recommendations on it. This Bill does not address that matter, which adds weight to my initial point. I am not sure whether Senator Schacht was here when I said that this Bill should be withdrawn and reconsidered only after our Committee has reported, along with other recommendations that might flow from that Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Another aspect about our electoral system which concerns me very much at the moment is the operation of the Australian Electoral Commission. I have been very disturbed over the last couple of years at the performance, some of the actions and, particularly, some of the comments of senior members of the Australian Electoral Commission. I will give a couple of examples. The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, as I mentioned earlier, is considering the Commonwealth Electoral Act in the light of the 1987 election. It called for submissions and received a wide range, including some from my own Party, the Liberal Party. Several months later the Australian Electoral Commission gratuitously responded to that submission by the Liberal Party. In relation to the Liberal Party's suggestion it made such comments as this:
Unless the submission's authors are totally ignorant of the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act--

The phrase on which the Liberal Party was reporting presumably means a particular definition, and is not relevant one way or the other. My point is that it is totally insulting and gratuitous to have a statement from the Electoral Commission, sanctioned by the Electoral Commissioner, describing the authors of a responsible submission as being totally ignorant of the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act because, of course, they were not. The Electoral Commissioner's final comment in response to the Liberal Party's submission was:

The submission's contribution to the perception in the minds of many voters that the administration of the electoral process is not adequate by repeating such an extraordinary collection of quarter truths and total fabrications devalues its protestations of concern about the consequences to the vanishing point.
They are highly unprofessional statements by the Commonwealth Electoral Commissioner and are indicative of some of the statements that he has been making in recent times.

Another example, not concerning criticism of my own Party, may be seen in a document submitted to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters by the Electoral Commissioner in relation to comments on a document that had been produced by other authors on the question of electoral integrity. The Electoral Commissioner said:
The authors of the document are both non-entities and the assertions it contains are irrational or unsupported by evidence or both.

Those are very unprofessional, denigrating and snide comments which do no credit to the Electoral Commission and damage the electoral process.
