There is no doubt at all that there are difficulties at the moment within the Commonwealth Electoral Commission. The Joint Standing Committee has received many comments from divisional returning officers expressing their views in response to a request from the Committee as to the operation of the 1987 election process and the 1988 referendum process. Those comments, by and large, were very damaging and demonstrate a considerable lack of morale within the Electoral Commission, particularly on the coalface where it all happens and where the validity and integrity of the electoral process really begins and ends; that is, out in the divisional returning offices.

Finally, I want to say a couple of things about the conduct of the Australian Electoral Commission in relation to the referendum campaigns last year. The Electoral Commission was responsible for the publication of the Yes and No cases pamphlet. As we all now know, the general feeling throughout the community was that the document that was produced was highly biased. The printing obviously favoured enormously the Yes case-that is, the Government's case-and the Electoral Commission, having given some responses as to why that happened, has absolved itself of blame. I do not believe that that is good enough, and I do not believe that the Australian people believe that it is good enough. Indeed, it was a tribute to the perspicacity of the Australian electorate that it so overwhelmingly rejected those referendum proposals of the Government last year and, thereby, appeared not to be overly influenced by the pamphlets it had received, which were so heavily biased in favour of the Yes case.

This is a matter that has to be addressed and looked at very seriously indeed. Of course, it is not addressed at all in this Bill. Nor are many other significant matters in respect of referendums. For example, the Senate rejected two or three Bills that had been put up last year by the coalition in an attempt to ensure that the questions put to the electorate in referendums reflect accurately the content of a proposed change to the Constitution. I refer, for example, to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) (Fair Questions) Amendment Bill, which I had the privilege of introducing in this chamber on behalf of the coalition. That Bill was thrown out by the Government. We did not receive support from the Democrats either, regardless of the purity of the Bill. That is another matter that requires addressing because it is patently clear that the legislative provisions relating to the wording of referendum questions in Australia are not satisfactory. As happened last year, there can be put to the Australian people questions relating to changes in the Constitution that give no accurate or adequate reflection of the fundamental nature of the changes being proposed.

We had the ludicrous situation-which has still not been resolved-whereby the electorate was confused as to whether a tick was a valid vote in a referendum, and whether certain combinations of ticks and crosses were valid. The result of that, of course, was massive confusion and, again, considerable bias in favour of the Yes case. Fortunately, that was rejected by the people. So, in the electoral system there are many matters of grave concern which we all ought to be addressing very carefully indeed. I believe that those matters are not dealt with in any measure of this Bill, and I urge the Government to withdraw it. Let us have another look at it in the light of all the further changes that may well be proposed as a result of the report currently being finalised by the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last comment of Senator Short certainly has merit. It seems to me that the fact that this Bill has languished so long on the Notice Paper brings it into the area where it could very well be superseded by a further report from the committee that has been looking at the last election. It might be advisable for the Government to consider whether any of those arguments could be put in legislation form. Undoubtedly, there will be only one run at such a Bill before the next election. The history of the exercise so far is that the reports from the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters have been accepted by the Parliament. The vast bulk of the recommendations have been unanimous and have found their way into legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only the majority reports that have found their way into legislation; some minority reports also have. I served as a member of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, as it was then, from its formation in 1983 until last year. I appreciate the Committee's workload. I was most impressed by the depth of analysis of the various items that came before the Committee. Unlike Senator Short, I think that Australian federal electoral law is one of the best electoral laws anywhere in the world. It is one of the very few laws to have been scrutinised rigorously by a parliamentary committee. The Joint Committee has recommended changes which have been accepted by Parliament. Those changes have been re-examined in terms of how they may have operated in an actual election context and the report has resulted in further changes which, again, have been adopted by Parliament. The Committee is now in the process of looking again at the changes that were made as a result of its second major report-not the second report, but the second major report-on electoral matters to see how they worked. So I cannot accept the litany of criticism made by Senator Short with regard to the electoral law.

Electoral Acts can always be improved-there is no doubt about that-but members of all political parties in this place have a lot to be proud of in respect of the electoral laws at Federal level in terms of the extent of the franchise that we have been able to achieve. Indeed, some people have been critical of the fact that we have gone to extraordinary lengths to ensure that all Australian citizens are able to register and to vote. I refer, for example, to citizens who work in the Antarctic, who used to be deprived of the vote but now get it; to itinerant workers, who used to be deprived of the vote by the nature of their occupation, but no longer are; and to women who, after leaving home with their children because they were bashed by their husbands, did not go on the electoral roll because they might be able to be traced, but who are now able to go on a silent electoral roll.

It is pretty easy to criticise, but let us look at the state of the Act before all this activity took place. I urge Senator Short, if he is not aware of the massive contrast, to read the first report of the Committee with regard to the basic electoral law. I think that he, like me, indeed, like all members of the Committee-will be stunned by the corruption of that system that crept in over a myriad of years. I am referring not to corruption of individuals but to corruption of the system. On one occasion we found that public servants had decided that they did not like the way in which, under the Act, women were not required, when they married, to change their maiden name on the roll unless they wished to do so. Whether the name was changed on the roll was entirely at their discretion. The bureaucrats decided that they did not like that and they made the women re-enrol under their married names, or knocked them off the roll if they did not. That was entirely contrary to the Act, even as it operated, having been passed by this Parliament in the 1940s. That had nothing to do with the new found position. Quite rightly the Parliament said that, under the Electoral Act, it was not a matter of dictate that that should occur. But obviously, in practice, it did not carry the day.

I would like at least to register my appreciation of the work that has been done by the Committee over the years and the work that has been done by the Parliament in improving that Act. I believe that, while changes can be made, we have gone a long way. I think one of the items that will stand to the credit of this Government is that it was willing to take on the task of reforming the electoral laws and to give that its best run. That time, energy and effort was not put in by previous governments for a long time.

One of the minority recommendations that I made, which appears in this Bill, was a dissenting report to the first report of the Joint Committee in September 1983, in which I urged that those citizens who had already been deprived of their liberty because of a prison sentence were suffering a double penalty under the current legislation because they were not allowed to vote. At the time I noted:

Having established a duty to vote with a penalty for non-compliance it is odd for the Committee to exempt certain citizens from that obligation and that penalty because they are serving prison sentences. The removal of political rights because of civil or criminal offence was entirely inappropriate for a democracy.

I stand by that statement. One of the things that was often held against the Soviet Union was the fact that it deprived people of political rights by using other methods. It seems to me highly incongruous that, while that type of criticism was being made of the Soviet Union at that time, people were happy to condone it in Australia. The Government has picked up that matter in this legislation. I am pleased to see it because, as the Minister has said, we now have a more rational and consistent approach to the recognition of voting rights and responsibilities. I argued this matter very strongly at the beginning of this Committee and I am pleased to see that it has now infused the whole of this Bill.

Political rights stem from citizenship. I know that, at that time, this was a ticklish problem. I argued very strongly that, ticklish or not, we should grasp the nettle and say that the right to vote was a right that flowed from citizenship in this country. People should be entitled to vote not because they happen to live here but because they are citizens. Some residents of this country are still entitled to vote but no new residents are able to be added to the roll. So, in a short space of time, our electoral rolls will be made up-as they should have been for a long period-entirely of citizens. If one is a citizen one is entitled to vote, whether or not one is in gaol. As I have said, one's voting rights stem from one's citizenship, not from one's situation in terms of civil or criminal law.

I have submitted other dissenting reports. In fact, I was able to join later with Senator Collins, operating in his previous capacity as a member representing the Northern Territory at a constitutional convention, on a vote against quite a number of his colleagues on the question of the Northern Territory becoming a State and whether it should be on a par with the original States. I saw no justification whatsoever for the argument in the majority report at that time-which was signed by all members of the Australian Labour Party, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia-that if the Northern Territory became a State it should be treated in a way other than the original States that were represented in this chamber. I am still very much of that view because I believe that the philosophy of the exercise is impeccable.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I know that you have a very strong views on this matter also. When you were a Minister I remember you telling me of those views at around 2.00 or 3.00 one morning when we were waiting for a Bill to come back from the House of Representatives. Nevertheless, although you were persuasive as always, I still hold to my view-although it might not be shared by many-that ultimately, the only way for the constitutional principle upon which the Senate is founded to be able to operate is for every State to be represented in this chamber on an equal basis. I made a dissenting report in December 1986 on other matters which are pertinent to this Bill. The recommendation of the Committee was:
The surname, given names, address, occupation, sex and date of birth of each elector should be available on the electoral roll and on the publicly available microfiche of the electoral roll.

I dissented from that recommendation and I will continue to argue that we should eliminate all unnecessary details from the electoral roll. The Government, after due consideration, picked up my dissenting report as it desired at that stage to reintroduce the words `sex' and `occupation' on the electoral roll. The issue of sex is a non-issue because unless two people are living in the same house and they both have the same surnames there could not possibly be any confusion. But even worse is the notion of occupation. I have no idea what occupation has to do with the right to vote. It may be useful for political parties. We do not establish the roles for political parties; we establish them to determine the right to vote. I believe that the minimum of information ought to appear on the electoral roll and that information should be used only for the purposes for which it is gathered.

I look forward to a stimulating debate in the committee stage of this Bill, whenever we manage to get to it. The way in which this Bill has been meandering through the Senate that should be some time next year. I look forward to a stimulating debate on why we should collect information from citizens for the purpose of the electoral roll, operate a private enterprise exercise, and tout that information around to the highest bidder. I am totally opposed to that and I will be seeking to move an amendment with regard to that matter in the committee stage. I will also be seeking to move amendments with regard to a number of other matters-most notably what I have entitled `the licence to lie' that is provided for political parties in the Electoral Act. I assume that, as has happened in the past, we will do nothing about that. I know ultimately we will have to do something about that as there is pressure from the electorate. I hope that, at least in the committee stage, people will be able to bring forward some slightly more rational and reasonable arguments as to why they believe companies in Australia should tell the truth when they advertise but political parties should have absolutely no obligation to do anything about the truth when they advertise. I look forward to debating in the committee stage that and other matters.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal Deaths in Custody-Antarctica-Uranium Review Committee-Mr Michael Davis-Assassination of Jean-Marie Tjibaou and Yeweine Yeweine

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a great deal of debate over the past year or so on the progress of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I have been involved in this debate and I know that honourable senators who have followed this issue may recall the observations that I made on Commissioner Muirhead's interim report which, among other things, canvassed the fact that Aboriginal people do not die in prison at a greater rate in terms of their percentage of the prison population than non-Aboriginal prisoners, but are imprisoned at an appal- lingly higher rate than non-Aboriginal prisoners.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been widespread and legitimate public concern about the cost of the Commission, the time it is taking to complete its job and its potential benefit to both the Aboriginal and wider Australian community. Much of that concern relates to the widespread impression in the community that the Commission is simply covering old ground already canvassed by coronial inquiries. That is a concern that I have felt myself. However, now that I have had the opportunity to read Commissioner Muirhead's interim report, the seven individual reports on deaths so far published, and in addition evidence taken by the Commission, particularly in the Northern Territory, that concern has been completely removed and replaced with a far greater concern for the standard of the coronial processes into deaths in custody in this country.

I wish to address this issue tonight for a particular reason. In response to a question from me in Question Time the Minister for Justice, Senator Michael Tate, advised the Senate that a number of refinements have been made to the operations of the Commission by setting a cut off date for new investigations, by procedures to reduce the time and cost of the individual inquiries, consistent with maintaining the high standard of those inquiries and other important matters. The Commissioners, I know, along with many others with an interest in this issue, want the Commission to present its final report by December 1990. Consistent with this desire it is essential to complete the majority of the individual hearings by the end of this year. In order to achieve this end it is imperative that an additional commissioner be appointed in Western Australia to replace Commissioner Muirhead. Western Australia has the greatest number of deaths to investigate, currently standing at 34. Statistically that State has the greatest problem in this area, which is further regrettably complicated by the refusal of the Western Australian police and prison officers to cooperate with the Commission-a matter which I assure the Senate is of great regret to at least some of their interstate colleagues. Indeed, I would ask the two bodies in Western Australia that I have just mentioned in their own interests and in the interests of justice to rethink their position on this.

My remarks this evening are therefore particularly directed, with respect, to my colleague the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Peter Dowding. Mr Dowding said recently that he would not support the appointment of a second commissioner until the Commission had, to quote him, `a change of direction' and he went on to say that the Commission was `simply rehashing old coronial inquiries'. As well as being a Labor colleague of mine, Mr Dowding is a prominent figure in the Australian Labor Party and one for whom I have considerable respect. I did share the same concerns about this matter as he does, but I do hope that when he gives further consideration to this issue his concerns will be allayed as mine have been, and that he will support the appointment of an additional commissioner in Western Australia. I note that he is to meet soon with Commissioner Elliot Johnson to discuss this and I hope that the meeting will be productive.

As I said before, one of the issues that has been raised again and again is that the Commission is simply going over the ground of coronial inquiries. Were this the case, it is clear from reading the interim report that Commissioner Muirhead himself would question the role of the Commission. A careful examination of the case by case reports however completely dispels this criticism. To quote from the interim report at page 58, after Commissioner Muirhead canvasses what should be done in a coronial inquiry, he says:

If this degree of thoroughness, the implementation of such expertise, had been current in Australia over past years, it is arguable that the necessity for the establishment of this Royal Commission would not have arisen.

Having read the reports, I can only agree with that conclusion. Of the seven reports already published all raise grave concerns about the standard of post-death investigations revealed by the work of the Commission. It is fair to say that in many of the cases reported on the standards have been so deficient as to make the findings of the investigations completely unreliable. The failings and inadequacies of the coronial processes have in some cases been gross and have involved failures in all stages of the process-in the police investigation, the pathology investigation and the coronial inquiries and findings themselves. The failures have involved errors of both commission and omission.

The concerns that I raise now in detail are not exhaustive-and I stress that, but I cannot do this in the time available-but they will serve to demonstrate the extent to which this concern is justified. Without at this point going into any detail about specific cases in Queensland, I would note that in seven of the 24 cases being investigated of deaths in custody in Queensland, no inquest was held into these deaths at all. In a situation where a person is held in custody and the custody of that person involves the deprivation of their liberty by the State, there is a very special responsibility by the State towards the care of that person. There should be no circumstances whatever, no matter how obvious or prejudged the death might be in terms of its cause-and this clearly is a feature in a lot of these cases-in which a death in custody ought not to involve a coronial process.

I turn specifically to the death of Kingsley Richard Dixon. The coroner held that Kingsley Dixon had been strip searched in a lawful manner. The Commission, however, found that the strip search was conducted in absolute contravention of the prison manager's directions. This is outlined on page 24 of the report. The Commission further found that a deliberate agreement between the prison officers occurred to falsify their reports to cover up this breach. It was known by the coroner that Kingsley Dixon was profoundly affected by drugs and that his condition led to his being strip searched by the prison officers. Despite this, the coroner made no finding on the management of Kingsley Dixon in his drug affected state. The Commission, in contrast, found that the prison management rules which are set out in the report had been `totally ignored'. I refer to pages 29 and 30 where specific management rules laid down for drug affected prisoners had not been implemented. Even more disturbing, the Commission went on to find-and I quote from the findings of the Commission at pages 65 and 66 of the report:
1. Kingsley Dixon was substantially and obviously under the influence of a drug or drugs when he was initially searched and when he died.

2. He was strip searched in `A' Wing, his cell was searched in his absence and was left in an untidy state. No effort was made to obtain a medical assessment. Relevant prison regulations appear to have been ignored.
4. The officers who placed Kingsley in his cell and secured it, have not been frank as to what then occurred.
I then refer to the following findings:
8. An initial attempt was made to conceal the fact that he was searched in `A' Wing.
9. He was not treated with the care his obvious condition required.
Most disturbing was finding 3:
If such regulations had been followed it is unlikely that Kingsley would have died that day.

The coroner made no criticism at all of the treatment of Kingsley Dixon by prison officers. In contrast, Commissioner Muirhead found at page 65 that the prison officers had contravened the very regulations that were designed to be applied in the case of drug affected prisoners such as Kingsley Dixon.

Finally, the Commissioner made a finding as to the cause of death which was substantially different from that of the coroner. The coroner found that Kingsley Dixon committed suicide. Commissioner Muirhead, however, found at finding 7 on page 66:

It is unlikely that Kingsley intended to take his own life; his actions probably influenced by drugs consumed were in the form of a protest but death ensued rapidly in a manner he did not contemplate.

The disturbing thing about this finding is that it was made on the basis of a body of compelling evidence set out in the report that was readily provided to the Commission and would just as easily have been available to the coroner had it been sought.

In the case of Edward James Murray there were a number of unsatisfactory matters found by Commissioner Muirhead in relation to the procedures carried out in this highly controversial death. These included matters such as those set out on page 133 of the report. However, the most important differences in the two inquiries-that is, the coronial inquiry and the Commission's inquiry-relate once again to the ultimate findings as to the cause of death. The coroner returned an `open finding' on the cause of death-in other words, he left the question of foul play open. Commissioner Muirhead, however, rejected that finding. Once again, a substantial body of evidence was adduced by the Commission which could have been called by the coroner but was not called. This led to the rejection by Commissioner Muirhead of the coroner's finding. Commissioner Muirhead was able to reach a concluded view that the death of Edward James Murray was not murder. This is made clear in the body of the report itself dealing with the hypothesis that foul play had occurred and in the findings of Commissioner Muirhead. I quote from findings 5 and 17 at page 131 of the report. Finding 5 is as follows:

He was placed in the cell by Moseley and Parker. I am concerned that the officers have not been frank about what took place at this time but there is no evidence to justify a finding of a physical assault, let alone an assault capable of producing unconsciousness or death.
Finding 17 reads:

On the whole of the evidence and material now before me it is more probable than not that death resulted by Eddie's own actions. This does not justify a finding of suicide for reasons set out in my report concerning the death of Kingsley Dixon.

In the death of John Clarence Highfold, Commissioner Muirhead noted numerous failures in the police inquiries into the death which led to the following statement by the Commissioner at page 36 of the report:

Detective Connor said that during the course of his investigations he received no directions from the Coroner's office, he presumed that Highfold died as a result of epilepsy, although he had no medical knowledge, did not attend the autopsy, obtain a copy of the post mortem report or make any medical inquiries whatsoever.

The investigation was not thorough and provided little information for the Coroner or the pathologist. I agree with the submission of Counsel Assisting that it appears to have been conducted `in an atmosphere of pre judgment and in a sense of routine' and was performed by Detective Connor from the standpoint (to use his own words) of `a simple death in custody'.

It should also be noted that the inquest was conducted without witnesses being called at all and without the family being represented at the inquest or even being present. In conclusion, Commissioner Muirhead found the conclusion of the pathologist which was accepted by the coroner that the death of John Clarence Highfold was caused by Status epilepticus was wrong.

In the death of Charles Sydney Michael, Commissioner Muirhead held at page 29 of the report that the police investigation had been carried out in an ad hoc manner by inexperienced officers and held further at page 29 of the report in respect of the entire process of this investigation that:

I hold a strong view that the system in operation when Michael died was unsatisfactory and I cannot accept that investigation by officers of the Internal Investigation Unit should be regarded as sufficient . . . In this area special considerations apply. These are matters which must be fully addressed after general evidence is heard.

Police failed to follow their own routine orders to involve the Criminal Investigation Bureau in an investigation of his death. Police seized and then lost containers of body fluid for analysis and this fact was not known to the coroner. Again, in the final finding on the cause of death the coroner found that the death was due to a heart attack, possibly due to arhythmia caused by amitriptyline. Commissioner Muirhead did not accept that the drug would have caused arhythmia.

On the death of Christine Lesley Ann Jones, very interesting issues were raised in the case. Commissioner O'Dea was extremely unhappy, not surprisingly, that the investigation of this death was carried out by one of the officers who was involved in the detention of the person who had died. At page 20 of his report, he also made the following criticisms of the coronial inquests:
In my opinion the Coronial Inquest was deficient in three respects.

(i) The officer who assisted the Coroner was a serving police officer. It was inappropriate to have a serving police officer assisting the Coroner when the deaths to be investigated occurred at a police lockup. That proposition required no elaboration since it is clear there is a potential for conflict . . .
(ii) The Coroner did not seek to discover why Christine Jones died as distinct from how she died . . .

(iii) The question of failure of the police officers to perform expired air resuscitation upon Christine was not raised at the inquest. There was no evidence before the Coroner as to the futility of cardiac massage alone. Nor was there evidence that in fact a manual resuscitator was kept at the Midland Police Station a resuscitator of which neither Constable Glew nor Constable Smallwood were aware and the presence of which Sergeant Sharp failed to recall.

Commissioner O'Dea then made a range of positive recommendations arising from the evidence taken on this death, none of which were made by the coroner. I might add that this has been a feature of all of the Commissioners' reports.

Into the death of Malcolm Charles Smith, Commissioner Wootten made a number of criticisms of the police investigations, the pathological examination and the coroner's inquest, including the failure to interview either medical officers or prisoners after the death, and again no family being represented at the inquest or even present. Commissioner Wootten criticised the police report to the coroner for a serious error. This error involved a statement made to the coroner by the police that Malcolm Charles Smith had made numerous attempts to kill himself previously, evidence which in fact was clearly wrong. Commissioner Wootten rejected the coroner's finding that Malcolm Charles Smith's death was suicide. He said at page 6:

The police investigation was not thorough. No prisoner witnesses were interviewed. It was accepted with virtually no investigation that Malcolm had intended to kill himself on this and on earlier occasions of self-injury. Inadequate investigation of this issue continued at the coronial inquiry and, as a result, the coroner wrongly found that Malcolm's death was suicide. His death was the result of self-inflicted injury, but not with the intention of taking his own life.
Again those findings are repeated on page 66 of the report where the coroner is reported as saying:
I find that Malcolm Smith's death was caused by his own action in driving the paint brush into his eye with his own hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a tragic death.

—It was a tragic death. The coroner found death by suicide, in other words, that Malcolm intended to take his life. In my view, the evidence did not and does not support such a finding. The Commissioner goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I find that Malcolm Smith did not intend to kill himself and accordingly that his death was not suicide.

The report in fact lays out very clearly that what Malcolm Smith was doing, as he had done on two previous occasions, was following the biblical injunction to pluck out his offending eye because of the guilt he felt over the death of the person whose life he took.

One case that has not been reported but which I followed with great interest is the death of a Northern Territory Aboriginal, the first recorded case of an Aboriginal in the Northern Territory committing suicide by hanging. At the hearings in the Northern Territory senior police officers gave evidence to the Commission which, in my view, was astonishing in respect of the actions taken in this case. Among other things, they told the Commission that they had presumed that the death was suicide. No attempt whatever was made to investigate the cause of an unexplained injury to the back of the head of the deceased. The evidence of a prison officer was accepted that a cell check was made at 6 a.m.; yet a medical report received the day after the inquest which claimed that the death by hanging had occurred before 4.30 a.m. was not even brought to the attention of the coroner. The question whether suicide was physically possible was barely examined. The police interviewed no prisoners. Of the three officers on duty at the time of the death, only one was interviewed. His word was accepted, without any further scrutiny, that the death was suicide. The coroner's constable reported to the coroner before the autopsy had been performed that death was suicide. No exhibits were seized by the police. No police records or journals were examined. No investigation was conducted as to the motive for suicide.

I think I have succeeded in laying out evidence-I assure you, Mr President, that these are not exhaustive extracts because time does not permit me that luxury-that the Commission is far from simply covering the same ground covered by coronial inquiries. It is in fact revealing the most disturbing deficiencies in the coronial system across Australia. No doubt the commission will report and recommend on it. I might add-it is probably appropriate at this point to say this-that the report which is currently being considered by the Commission from Perth. Perth coroner David McCann is also extremely disturbing and the widespread criticisms that McCann makes of coronial processes in Western Australia. Among other things-I was very interested to read this-David McCann canvasses the issue of police officers in Western Australia refusing to give evidence on the deaths of people in their own custody on the grounds that they may incriminate themselves. David McCann raises the very interesting question whether police officers who refuse to give evidence on the deaths of citizens who they take into their custody, on the grounds that they may incriminate themselves, should still be serving as police officers. That is a very valid question to put.

Criticism has been made of the inquiry also as to the necessity to investigate the underlying issues involved and not simply to report on the deaths. I can assure you, Mr President, that this has been done very thoroughly indeed. There is one report so far published that I single out. If honourable senators do not have time to read all of the reports but if they have an interest in this subject, I commend to them a reading of the report into the death of Malcolm Charles Smith that has been presented by Commissioner Wootten. I will quote from page 73 of Commissioner Wootten's report. To background honourable senators briefly on this death, I mention that Malcolm Charles Smith was a New South Wales Aboriginal person who had been taken at the age of eight from his parents by the State in a manner tragically similar to that of so many cases across Australia. He was taken deliberately from his parents by the State as a result of a deliberate-I emphasise `deliberate'-public policy laid down by politicians of the day to eliminate the Aboriginal race in Australia and, in fact, to breed them out by taking part-Aboriginal children away from the `dying race', as Aboriginals were seen, and completely restricting their access to their own Aboriginal family until after 16 generations. I think that was the hypothesis at the time. Aboriginality would be bred out in that time. I add that crucial to that system was the practice that, when children were taken away from their parents, they were removed hundreds and, in some cases, thousands of kilometres away from their families. Malcolm Charles Smith did not see a single member of his family for some 10 years. He was in fact told at one stage-quite falsely-by the officers who were looking after him that his parents had died.
In commenting on this Commissioner Wootten said, on page 73:

This report has dealt with the taking away of Malcolm Smith from his family and its catastrophic effect on his life and ultimately his death. But this was not some isolated incident. Peter Read has calculated that 5,625 Aboriginal children were taken away from their families in New South Wales up to 1969 under the Aborigines Protection Act, the Aborigines Welfare Act and the Child Welfare Act.

I note that the Aboriginal Welfare Board which was responsible for oversighting this was not abolished in New South Wales and this practice did not cease until 1969. Commissioner Wootten goes on to say at page 76, and it is worth reading:

After World War II there was drafted an international Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide which codified principles developed in the Nuremberg trials. The convention did not come into force until 1961, although Australia had become a party to it in 1949.
He then goes on to quote from the Convention defining what genocide is. I will not read out all the parts, but the last parts are:

(3) deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction in whole or in part, (4) imposing measures intended to prevent births within the group, (5) forcibly transferring children of the group to another group.

It is therefore not emotive but simply a statement of fact to say that up until 1969 in this country politicians were bringing down policies, passing laws and oversighting a system that was clearly genocide under international conventions on the subject of genocide.

In conclusion, I will quote from page 7 of Commissioner Wootten's report, which again addresses the question of the investigation that Commissioner Wootten has undertaken in the most commendable manner about the underlying factors involving the death of this one individual and the sad and tragic case that the reading of this report reveals. He states:

In Part Three I seek to identify for further study, from evidence and information gained in the Malcolm Smith inquiry, issues underlying the occurrance of Aboriginal deaths in custody. Such issues are inevitably wide ranging. So long as Aboriginals are being detained and imprisoned at ten to twenty times the rate of non-Aboriginals, many will die in custody. So long as Aboriginals live in depressed communities without equal opportunities and hope for the future, so long as they remain an alienated, dispossessed people embittered by wrongs that have not been recognised or redressed, they will continue to come in conflict with the law and be taken into custody. So long as Aboriginals outside custody are dying twenty years and more earlier than non-Aboriginals, as the result of a high incidence of life style diseases, and of the alcoholism and violence which the stresses and frustrations of their lives produce, many will inevitably die in custody as well.

As I have said on a number of occasions in the past, those people who say to us that we should not feel guilty about the injustices done to Aboriginal people 200 years ago are absolutely correct in my view. I do not believe that we should either. I think that it is a fruitless exercise to feel guilty about what was done to Aboriginal people 200 years ago. One of the other reasons that I feel we should not feel guilty about what was done to Aboriginal people 200 years ago is that there is really not very much room left after we feel guilty about what is being done to Aboriginal people right now in this country and in the recent past.

I point out that when Malcolm Charles Smith died he was younger than I was. I point out again to honourable senators in this House that the laws and policies which governed the forcible removal of Aboriginal children as a race from their parents were repealed in the State of New South Wales only in 1969, that is barely 20 years ago. So we are living with the generations of those children, now adults, of our own age today. So we really do not have a lot of time or energy to expend on feeling guilty about what was done 200 years ago. We should be flat out trying to redress the legacy that we have been left with today.

The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody is performing an essential and important role. It has already brought down a range of important recommendations which, if they are not implemented, will not be the fault of the Commission; it will be the fault of the politicians of this country whose forebears have given us the appalling legacy we now have because of recent past and present policies. The Commission has already exposed serious deficiencies in the entire process of post-death investigations in the coronial system of this country which will doubtless lead to important recommendations for the major reform in this area which is clearly long overdue.

If reports of the quality of the one that I have just quoted, that from Commissioner Wootten still continue to be produced, the major underlying issues contributing to the appallingly high imprisonment rate of Australia's Aboriginal people will continue to be exposed. The total body of reports of the Commission, including its final report, as uncomfortable and as embarrassing as they will be to many people, will benefit all citizens of this country taken into custody-not just Aboriginals, but all citizens-and as a consequence will benefit the entire nation. The Commission should therefore receive, in my view, all of the assistance required to complete its important work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of the last couple of weeks the Senate has had a number of debates about the Antarctic. On a number of occasions I have drawn attention to two particular oil spills which are alleged to have taken place in the Antarctic. I have referred to both an accident involving an Argentinean vessel and an accident involving a Peruvian vessel. The Argentinean vessel in question, the Bahia Paraiso, in fact sank in the Antarctic with a resultant oil spill which was damaging to the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: My attention was drawn to an article in the Australian newspaper of 1 March 1989 which starts off with these words:
A Peruvian research ship that ran aground in the Antarctic is leaking oil, posing the second ecological threat to the continent's wildlife in less than a month.
A Chilean navy spokesman said last night there was a 130m-wide slick floating towards the coast.
Two of the 1980-tonne Humboldt's fuel tanks were punctured when it hit a rock off King George Island in the South Shetlands.
Late last month an Argentinian navy supply ship carrying 950,000 l of diesel fuel ran aground.

I rise only very briefly because today I was called upon by His Excellency Mr Gonzalo Bedoya, the Ambassador of Peru, who asked me to make a correction to the press report. The Ambassador advised me that the Peruvian ship, the BIC Humboldt ran aground while it was leaving Fildes Bay in the Antarctic. He advised me that according to the official information from the Peruvian Navy the BIC Humboldt at that time was laying on its centre port side on a flat bed of rock and was in no danger of sinking. He also indicated that the report from the Peruvian Navy claimed that the engine room was operative, the ship had electric energy and the water pumps were ready to be used in case that became necessary. The ship's keel apparently had not been punctured or pierced in any way, no sea water had entered the interior of the ship and also the fuel tanks had not been damaged nor fuel from them leaked outside the ship. He said that this report had been confirmed by Chilean scuba divers who had also verified that the wheel and propeller of the ship were in good condition. His Excellency indicated that as a result, Peruvian authorities were satisfied that no real ecological danger existed from this particular incident and that only small filtration had come from waste exhaust of the ship and that was subject to immediate control. His Excellency the Ambassador of Peru therefore asked me simply to place on the record the claim of the Peruvian Government, which I have no reason to take other than on its face value, that the Peruvian Government believed that there were a number of exaggerated reports arising from this particular incident involving the vessel the BIC Humboldt. After being beached for a week, the vessel was able to navigate by its own means and returned to Cove Porter and thence to Punta Arenas in Chile. Finally, it was confirmed, when the vessel returned, that the fuel tanks had been undamaged and that no pollution had occurred from this particular vessel. As I believe that the Ambassador of Peru is more than entitled to ask for a formal correction of the record in relation to what appears to have been an erroneous report in newspapers, and as that was a matter of substance raised in the debate, I thought it was entirely proper to make that explanation to the Senate and to put those facts on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight fairly briefly about the Uranium Review Committee which is under way within the Australian Labor Party at the moment. I am prompted to do so by a visit I made to the Pilbara this weekend to attend a bush meeting at Yule Brook where I met with the representatives of many Aboriginal groups. I went there at the invitation of the Pilbara community to speak particularly in a debate at the bush meeting on the question of uranium.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graham Campbell, was also in attendance at the meeting. He did not seem to understand that that was the agenda item for the morning and he quite deliberately tried to railroad the meeting to talk about all sorts of other issues which were of course important to Aboriginal people. His performance was less than acceptable to the Aboriginal people and really quite embarrassing for a Federal parliamentarian. He got very angry and stormed out of the meeting. He was asked by the Chairperson of the meeting to come back and was told to sit down and listen to the views of the Aboriginal people. Two members of the State branch of the Australian Labor Party were also in attendance at the meeting. I think that they too were quite embarrassed by their colleague's behaviour. Pam Buchannan and Larry Graham were there. They spoke in very supportive terms about Aboriginal people and the need to listen to Aboriginal people. They also stated quite clearly their own personal opposition to the Labor Party in Western Australia changing its position on uranium mining. Obviously, this is something of great concern to the Aboriginal people in the Pilbara.

The members failed to mention the review committee which is at present under way in the Labor Party. I found it quite surprising that they did not give the people there the information that they needed to make any submission to the inquiry. They did not even mention it at all. Of course, I mentioned it and suggested that if the community had strong views about uranium it should certainly be making a submission to the inquiry. It made me look further at the process of the inquiry. What I found was quite disturbing.

First of all, the inquiry is a quick tour around the capital cities of Australia. I think seven different cities are on the agenda of this eight-person committee. But people who wish to make submissions have had only two weeks' notice and it seems to have been kept almost a secret. I do not know how much advertising the Labor Party has done within its own circles, because I am not privy to that information, but certainly as far as the public are concerned there has been very little information available. I suppose that that is a deliberate silence on the part of the Party. It does not want to be embarrassed by an overwhelming anti-uranium response, which will begin to happen as soon as people hear about the committee.

In the Pilbara there are two of the three likely uranium mines which are ready to go ahead in Western Australia. There is the one at Rudall River, where Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd has done all of its exploration and is ready to go as soon as there is either a change in policy or a change in government. The people there are opposed to mining, or to the disturbance of their land which also happens to be within a national park. They do not want uranium mining to go ahead under any circumstances. They have not been given an opportunity to present themselves before this Committee unless they are prepared to go to the expense of travelling at very short notice to Perth to do so. Of course, Menyingee, near Onslow, is another mining site which has been explored by a French mining company called Total, and is ready to go. Again, that is in the Pilbara region which is in the area where this meeting was held last weekend. I think it is really very unfair that the people in the region have not had some special time set aside so that they could make submissions to this inquiry. They could at least be given more notice and some assistance to get to Perth if that is the only place in Western Australia to which the Committee can go. Preferably, of course, the Committee should go up and sit under the trees and listen to the voices of the Aboriginal people. The third mine site, which is all ready to go in Western Australia, is at Yeelirrie, which is near Kalgoorlie and that is under the auspices of the Western Mining Co. There is no hearing in the goldfields region.

There have been only a few hours set aside for the public to make submissions to this inquiry which is going around the country very quickly. Many people therefore feel that there is an air of inaccessability about the inquiry which is very limiting indeed. I wonder how much information has been given to people in the Party. There is also time set aside for people within the Party. Overall, it is a very, very short amount of time. I understand that the members of the committee were told fairly early that they would be presenting their report in November or December to the Federal Executive. It is therefore a puzzle as to why they have to rush around the country now in the space of only one month, without giving the people who wish to make submissions adequate time to put those submissions together.

There is also the question of the attendance of the members of the Committee at the two hearings which have taken place so far in Brisbane and Sydney over the last couple of weekends. Two of the members of Parliament who are members of the Committee have been in attendance at both of those meetings. They are Jeanette McHugh and Peter Milton, and Robert Mills from South Australia. However, as far as the other members of the Committee are concerned, there has not been consistent attendance. Senator Bob Collins has not attended either of the hearings, and Mr David Parker, the Deputy Premier of Western Australia has not attended either of the hearings. Senator Collins did not even bother to arrange a proxy to hear the points of view of people this weekend at the Sydney hearings. I think that that is a very poor showing indeed. I understand that it was very difficult for Senator Collins to get to the Sydney hearings because of other commitments in the Northern Territory, but there should have been better consultation by Mr Ian Henderson, who is organising this inquiry on behalf of the Labor Party, to ensure that the members of the Committee could at least attend the hearings, so that they could pick up the flavour of the submissions being presented.

Of course, there are some people on that Committee who are there to listen very supportively to what is coming forward despite the lack of notice and despite the lack of consultation from the people who are making submissions and whose views are overwhelmingly in the anti-uranium direction. I think it is very important for people in the community to understand that written submissions can be made even after the committee has visited their particular State on its whistle stop tour. I think it is also very important to remind members of the Committee, and of the Labor Party in general, that public opinion in Australia is further and further against uranium mining. Overseas public opinion is further and further against nuclear power. It is not an option on moral grounds, on environmental grounds, and certainly not on economic grounds.

I think the people in the Labor Party who are pushing this barrow, consistently as they have since 1982, need to be reminded-and I will be reminding the people at the hearings in Perth in a couple of weeks' time-that this is still a very important issue in the electorate and that the Labor Party will be making a grave mistake as people are quite reasonably surmising that the decision has already been made and that this Committee is merely a whitewash. I think it would be a great shame if the Labor Party made the mistake of pushing its uranium policy further and further into the direction of mining. The three mines policy is, of course, totally illogical. Either one is for uranium mining, with all its consequent difficulties, or one is opposed to uranium mining. That is the preferred position of well over half the Australian population.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday of this week I asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, whether or not he or his Department has taken any action in response to alleged requests by Senator Graham Richardson to terminate the employment of a former research assistant and speech writer to the Australian Ambassador in Washington, a Mr Michael Davis. The Minister replied at that stage that he had no knowledge of Mr Michael Davis, but yesterday he replied in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: My Department has told me that Mr Michael Davis commenced employment with the Embassy in Washington in the locally engaged staff position of research officer to the Ambassador on 25 October 1988.
The Minister continued:

It has no record of any request or requests by Senator Graham Richardson to terminate the employment of Mr Davis. Senator Richardson has assured me-and he is an honourable man-that he made no such request. The services of Mr Davis were not terminated by the Embassy but he submitted his resignation on 21 February 1989 and left the employment of the Embassy on 29 March 1989.

The answer given by the Minister is somewhat at odds with information that has come into my possession by way of a fax which was sent by Mr Michael Davis from the Australian Embassy on 16 March 1989 on Embassy of Australia, Washington, DC, letterhead, wherein Mr Davis said that on Wednesday, 8 February 1989 the Deputy Head of Mission, Mr Max Hughes, had told him that he would have to finish up at the Embassy by the end of March 1989. Mr Davis was told that no other job at the Embassy or any of the Australian Consulates-General was available to him. The reason given was that the new Ambassador would want a new speech writer whose style was different from that of Mr Davis. Mr Davis was given to understand that his dismissal was due to inadequacy of work performance, however no indication of this was given at any stage between 26 October and 8 February. The fax continued:

The real reason is that Senator Graham Richardson, in pursuing an internal ALP struggle associated with the Kingsford-Smith preselection, has prevailed upon senior officials in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to effect the dismissal of Mr Davis because he is in support of the candidacy of Mr Ron Hoenig, Mayor of Botany, against Mr Laurie Brereton, the member for Heffron.

The officers in the Embassy with whom I have dealt on this matter, Mr Max Hughes and Mr Bill Rowe, the Consul-General, have been decent about this. They can tell the name of the Canberra official who gave their instruction.

Mr Peter Fitzgerald, the Mayor of Drummoyne, was told by Senator Richardson personally, `. . . and as for Davis, I'll get him'. Mr Fitzgerald, a support of Mayor Hoenig, was discussing with Senator Richardson the inappropriateness of Laurie Brereton as a Federal Labor candidate at the time of the threat.

Mr Davis then arrived back in Sydney. The concern I have is that the Minister has stated that Mr Davis did not have his employment terminated, but in fact resigned. The dates are relevant. Mr Davis asserts in his written statement, which is signed by him, that he was told on 8 February that he would have to finish up, that there was no more work for him. The Minister says that he allegedly resigned on 21 February, yet Mr Davis faxed this statement to Australia from Washington on 16 March. The dates very simply do not add up. If the situation is that either there is no letter of resignation or the letter of resignation was coerced and Mr Davis was, in fact, sacked, the Minister has indeed misled the Parliament. The determination of the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales to see Mr Laurie Brereton come into the Parliament and have Mr Hoenig defeated on Saturday next, 6 May, may have meant that the Department has been used as part of a faction fight, which is quite unacceptable. The matter is very serious. I have chosen to raise it in the adjournment debate tonight because I feel it is in the public interest that the matter be aired before the preselection is held on Saturday next, 6 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jean-Marie Tjibaou, the father of Kanak independence, leader of the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front (FLNKS) was assassinated this evening in New Caledonia.This is a tragedy of extraordinary proportions for the Kanak people and the future of peace and stability in New Caledonia. As I said, from the early 1970s Jean-Marie Tjibaou was the founder and leader of the Kanak demands for independence. He was an outstanding figure. I had the good fortune to meet him on at least two occasions. I met him only a week ago on Monday in New Caledonia when I was the leader of a parliamentary delegation from Australia, of which Senator Hill was also a member. In more than an hour's discussion, he again emphasised to me that he was a man who could be considered in any country of the world an outstanding political leader.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember a particular point of our meeting. I asked a question about some particular matter of the Matignon Accord. That is the Accord signed by the French Government, the FLNKS and the Rally for Caledonia in the Republic (RPCR). The RPCR is associated with the French settlers in New Caledonia. Those three groups signed the accord for a 10-year program leading to an act of self-determination in 1988. When I asked the question about some aspect of the Matignon Accord, Jean-Marie Tjibaou went to his briefcase, pulled out the document and described it as `the Bible'. He was obviously proud of his very significant association with and involvement in bringing about the Accord. The information that has come through from New Caledonia this evening is still sketchy. It may be very unfortunate that he was assassinated by militants in the FLNKS who disagreed with the signing of the Matignon Accord. The very same accord that he called `the Bible' may well have been the reason that some mad men or women went about his assassination.

Jean-Marie Tjibaou met many people in Australia and came to Australia on a number of occasions. All those who met him were impressed by his sincerity, intelligence, warmth and humanity. I first met him in 1983 and at that stage also met Eloi Machoro, another FLNKS leader who was shot dead in 1986. For those of us who have supported Kanak independence, it becomes a sorry tale to realise that the people we meet, feel warm towards and support, pay with their lives for the fact that they want to support independence for their country.

The Matignon Accord was an historic breakthrough in the history of New Caledonia in that it provided a peaceful way to resolve the matters in dispute between the Kanaks and the French settlers, called caldoches, and the French Government. When we were there only last week, we were all impressed by the fact that the country seemed peaceful and tranquil and that although there were still differences of opinion between the FLNKS and the RPCR, by comparison with what was occurring only a matter of a year or so ago we had great optimism that the process would lead to a successful conclusion. I hoped it would lead to New Caledonia being independent.

Since I have had an interest in foreign affairs matters, I have always been irked by the fact that it is often the so-called good guys who get killed or assassinated. Those who have worked for independence, democracy, liberty, and human rights always seem to be the first to suffer the ultimate consequence of violence, particularly those who have fought for independence for their country. We all know the story of Mahatma Gandhi, the leader for Indian independence, assassinated by a fanatic just as India received independence. We all know the story of Steve Biko, a leading South African student who argued for the end of apartheid and human rights and full democracy for all the people of South Africa. He died in South African police custody.

I also know of the case, which is not well known in Australia-I certainly was not aware of it until my visit to Burma in February this year-of General Aung Saan, the founder of Burmese independence, who was assassinated just as Burma gained independence.

We have the dreadful tragedy of Jean-Marie Tjibaou, who was assassinated this evening as New Caledonia was moving forward with great hope for the future. I should also mention that a message has just come through that his deputy, Yeweine Yeweine, has also died as a result of the attack tonight. Someone else was wounded, but the two main leaders of the FLNKS were killed on the island of Ouvea while attending ceremonies in memory of those who died 12 months ago tomorrow on that island during disturbances.

In the report that has come in tonight concerning Tjibaou's assassination, it is said that, during the ceremony, Jean-Marie Tjibaou paid tribute not only to dead Kanaks but also to the others who died-obviously the French gendarmes. One can again see the statesmanship of Jean-Marie Tjibaou in that he was attempting to show a reconciliation between the various groups in New Caledonia by making those remarks. My only hope is that those remarks were not further encouragement to the fanatics who killed him as he was attempting a reconciliation by mourning loss of life.

There is no doubt that tomorrow not only New Caledonia but much of the South Pacific will be in mourning because one of its most significant political leaders is dead. I believe that the French Government will be extraordinarily distressed by Tjibaou's assassination because France recognised his extraordinary qualities to which Premier Rocard paid tribute during the process of the Matignon Accord. I trust that, when more information comes through, the Australian Parliament will pay proper tribute to the work done by Jean-Marie Tjibaou and Yeweine Yeweine.

The point should be made that a country close to Australia has had political assassinations. This further emphasises the point that Australia is in a region-the South Pacific-that can no longer be considered to be totally placid. There are stresses and strains. The democracy we take for granted and the tolerance we have in our society despite our political differences, unfortunately do not exist in the way we would hope they would in other countries in our region.

Many of the parliamentary disputes that we have in this chamber and in this Parliament really pale into insignificance when someone like Jean-Marie Tjibaou is assassinated. The arguments that we have over such things as preselections, elections to parliamentary caucus and so on are really minuscule when compared with people in other parts of the world paying with their lives for arguing for those same rights.

Despite the obvious extraordinary stress and strain that will occur in New Caledonia over the next few days, I hope that peace and stability in that country can be maintained. I am sure that the Australian Government and the Australian Opposition parties will express strong support and do all that they can to encourage all the parties in New Caledonia to remain peaceful and not to start a cycle of retribution resulting in further bloodshed. It would be a final tribute to Jean-Marine Tjibaou if no more people die in a cycle of vengeance because of these dreadful assassinations tonight.

I hope that the Australian Parliament and the Australian Government will send suitable representatives to his funeral whenever it is held. I would certainly like to be involved. That may not be possible but I certainly hope that the Government and the Opposition parties are properly represented at his funeral.

In conclusion, I repeat that, personally, this is a terrible shock. I know that Senator Hill, who was a member of the delegation, will speak next. He met Jean-Marie Tjibaou. He went to New Caledonia and he has taken an interest in that country. Like me, he is terribly shocked and disappointed at what has happened. One despairs when a person like Jean-Marie Tjibaou, who has given so much to his country, is assassinated by a lunatic at a time when progress is being made to achieve the goal he had set himself. I hope that, at an appropriate time, the Senate will carry a resolution recognising his great contribution to Kanak independence and the people of the South Pacific.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated by Senator Schacht, I take this opportunity to say a few words on the same subject. This is a day of great sadness for all of us who are interested in peace and stability within the South Pacific in general and New Caledonia in particular. As I indicated, I am glad of the opportunity to say a few words in tribute to Jean-Marie Tjibaou and Yeweine Yeweine, the vice-president of the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front (FLNKS) who, we have just heard, also died in the attack.

SPEECH.PARA: Tragedy has never been far from Jean-marie Tjibaou. Because you knew him also and admired his work, Mr President, you would recall that he suffered a personal tragedy in 1984 during the FLNKS campaign following its boycott of the November territial assembly elections when settlers ambused a group of 14 FLNKS supporters near his home town, killing 10 from his tribe, including two of his brothers.

The assassination today took place on the eve of the first anniversary of the death of 19 Melanesians on the island of Ouvea who were killed on 5 May last year. Jean-Marie Tjibaou and his deputy were on the island today to commemorate their deaths. When we were in New Caledonia only a week ago, a ceremony took place to mark the deaths of the four gendarmes who were killed on Ouvea a few days before the death of the Melanesians. So it is a sad picture of violence and death. This is a very depressing day for all of us who had become so much more hopeful for the future of New Caledonia.

I met Jean-Marie Tjibaou in Australia, and then at the United Nations in 1986. At that time the two parliamentary advisers, Senator Bolkus and I, were working for the reinscription of New Caledonia on the list of colonised countries of the world, and Jean-Marie Tjibaou was in New York quite often, working towards the same objective. I got to know him a little during that time. I had met him previously in Australia and I remember that we jointly participated in a conference on the South Pacific in Washington in 1986. It was good to see him again in New Caledonia a week ago. He showed the same optimism and sense of humour which I will always remember. Certainly he seemed pleased to see me again, as he would be pleased to see anyone who had any interest in the future well-being of his country.

I went to New Caledonia for the referendum in September 1987. That was a vote on whether or not New Caledonia wished to remain with France. I came back deeply concerned about the future of New Caledonia. The atmosphere was stressful and, objectively, one could really have little optimism for the future. As Senator Schacht mentioned, I went back last week for a couple of days with the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade of this Parliament because I was interested to see for myself whether the changes of which I had read and seen in the media were valid; in other words, whether there had been a significant change of attitude. I came back extremely heartened and hopeful.

I was amazed at the changes that had occurred in such a short period of some 18 months. I know that in part those changes related to the change of government in France and different attitudes from France, but probably some credit should be given to a lot of people. Certainly more than a fair share of the credit should be given to Jean-Marie Tjibaou himself because he had to lead the Kanak people in a new direction. That meant taking a slower path towards independence that required fairly dramatic steps and, in the meantime, a year of direct rule from France, the experiment with the provincial elections and a series of new events for the Kanak people. He was able to show them that leadership. He and the Opposition party in New Caledonia jointly pledged in Paris that they would work together under the Matignon Accords towards a new future for New Caledonia, a future of trust in each other, working towards an ultimate referendum on the subject of independence in a decade's time.

In speaking to the major political parties, the leaders of the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front, the Caldoche and the French, one could not but come away with a feeling that New Caledonia had turned the corner and the future looked extremely hopeful. I particularly stress the French because I can remember meeting the High Commissioner there with his aides 18 months ago, and on that occasion meeting a High Commissioner whose attitude was that we must work with the Kanak people towards our mutual well-being. That reflected the changes that I said I thought it was incredible could have occurred within such a short period of time.

This must not be a victory for extremists. I am sure that it would be the one wish of Jean-Marie Tjiboau, if he had no other, that the path of peace must continue and the Melanesian people must continue to work with the French towards a solution of the problems in New Caledonia that will provide peace, stability, security and increased economic well-being for all of the people of that country. I hope we have an opportunity at some time to pay respect on a more considered basis to the memory of Jean-Marie Tjibaou, but I briefly wanted tonight to associate myself and the Opposition with the comments made by Senator Schacht, who was speaking both personally and on behalf of the Government. This is a sad day for the Pacific but it must not be a wasted day. The life of Jean-Marie Tjibaou must not be wasted. All of us, and there are plenty of us in this place, who want to do our bit to help peace and stability in the Pacific must resolve to work even harder towards that objective.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is not usual for the President of the Senate to take part in a debate. This is the first time I have done so, and I will be very brief. I first met Jean-Marie Tjibaou in 1978 at the South Pacific Conference held in Noumea, when I was one of the parliamentary observers from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. At that stage we had to meet in what I can only describe as a clandestine manner. The meeting was organised by the Australian High Commission. Things had changed quite dramatically by 1983 when I led the Australian delegation to the South Pacific Conference in Saipan. I think you, Senator Hill, were a member of that delegation.

INTERJECT.PARA: I was able to spend a great deal of time with Jean-Marie Tjibaou because I think he was a member of the official delegation from New Caledonia. In fact, he might have been the leader. We were able to discuss at great length the problems of the independence movement. He was dedicated to the ideals and aspirations of the Kanak people and to the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front. There are already rumours that he was assassinated by members of his own organisation. If that is true it is a worse tragedy than I first thought. I am appalled by the news and can only support the views that were put forward tonight by Senator Schacht and Senator Hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight Senator Bishop continued with her line of attack on me concerning the employment of a Mr Michael Davis as a locally engaged staff member of the Australian Embassy in Washington. I quite rightly ignored her first attempt but, given that she has made a second, I believe it is proper that I reply.

SPEECH.PARA: In the period of almost two years that Senator Bishop has been here in the Senate there are four things by which she can be remembered. The first and, I think, the extraordinary thing by which she can be remembered is that she is the only senator, so far as I am aware, ever able to employ a professional public relations consultant to publicise her career. She has a consultant to make sure that there are photographs-no matter how unsightly we may find them-of her in football jumpers in magazines; to make sure that there are mentions of her in gossip columns; and to make sure that, generally speaking, we know she is alive.

Secondly, she will be remembered as the person who defeated Senator Puplick in a Liberal Party preselection ballot. That was some achievement. Senator Puplick had previously enjoyed a reputation as something of a numbers man. I do not quite understand what all that means, but my impression was that he had been good at what he did. But Senator Puplick was defeated by Senator Bishop, and a professional public relations consultant was employed by her. It was obvious that within the Liberal Party money and power could override ability.

While Senator Puplick has been strangely silent on the environment for the past two years, I can at least say that I remember some contributions he has made in the Senate. While I may have passionately disagreed with him at the time, I can say that the contributions that he made on Lionel Murphy and on the Australia Card I at least remember.

Senator Bishop, however, can be remembered in this chamber for the third and fourth things to which I shall refer. Both of them, of course, are not only tinged but dominated by failure. The third was her remarks in the Castlereagh by-election-a rather pathetic attempt to involve the Labor Party in electoral fraud. Disowned, of course, by her own Party in New South Wales, her Liberal Government in New South Wales, those allegations died a natural death.

The fourth thing for which she will be remembered after two years in the Australian Senate concerns the latest failure. I refer to some allegations by Mr Michael Davis. The allegation that Senator Bishop has pursued is that I asked someone somewhere to sack Mr Michael Davis from a position he occupied in the Australian Embassy in Washington. The first thing I should say about that, to place it on record, is that I never asked directly, or suggested indirectly, to anyone in the Australian Embassy in Washington, or in the Department of Foreign Affairs in Australia, that he should assist in the sacking of Mr Michael Davis. If there is anything more spectacularly irrelevant to the job that I do or to the Australian Senate than the employment of a Mr Michael Davis, I cannot recall just what it might be. However, I repeat the assurance: I have never suggested to anyone that Mr Michael Davis should be sacked. I never knew that he had been employed until I arrived in Washington in December, and certainly there could be few things that could alarm me less than that employment.

Nonetheless, Mr Davis-a person who purports to be a supporter of the Labor Party, who seeks a vote in a Labor Party preselection-chooses to use the vehicle of an extreme right wing Liberal senator as his redress in the Australian Parliament. I will allow the membership of the Party in Kingsford-Smith to make its own judgment as to why the only person who could raise his cause, for better or for worse, in the Australian Parliament would be an extreme right wing figure of the kind of Senator Bishop. Nonetheless, on Saturday, in the electorate of Kingsford-Smith, the Labor Party's rank and file will make its judgment. I suspect that when that judgment is made, it will be far more inclined to my beliefs than to those of Senator Bishop.

In making that judgment, I am reminded of an article-or of a portion of an article-which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald a few weeks ago, upon Mr Davis's return to Australia. I may say that that event remained unheralded in all publications in the country, except for the `Stay in Touch' column of the Sydney Morning Herald. In that column over the past month I have seen a number of stories which have sought to denigrate Laurie Brereton, a member of the New South Wales Parliament, in his campaign for preselection for the Federal seat of Kingsford-Smith. Apparently, a Mr Kennedy is the editor of that column. He, I am told, is a close friend of Mr Davis, in the same way that Senator Bishop obviously is now. Mr Kennedy will have the same effect on the Labor Party's preselection processes as Senator Bishop. Every day Mr Kennedy has produced a horror story-or so he thought-about the Kingsford-Smith preselection. Every day, Mr Davis's line, his obsessive opposition to Mr Brereton, has received a run. The first that I knew either that Mr Davis had been sacked or that someone like me might be accused of organising that dismissal was from that column, where it was alleged that Mr Davis, in his courageous, crusader-like return from the United States, was to sue this prominent member of the Labor Party who had organised his dismissal.

Apparently, it is now revealed, by no less a source than the extreme right wing senator from the Liberal Party, Senator Bishop, that I am that person. It surprises me that, in the month that has passed since this breathless allegation received its publicity in the Sydney Morning Herald, I have not been sued. I might say that I would welcome that suit. I challenge Mr Davis-no one cares about Senator Bishop-to produce evidence that I ever spoke to anyone and suggested that he should be sacked. Inquiries that I have made since suggest, by the way, that to get the job in the first place he used a reference that I had provided to him. You see, Mr President, I have known Mr Davis for many years. I did provide him with a reference to get a job. Admittedly, it was a job in the State Public Service and this was some years ago. Apparently that same reference was trotted out when he sought employment at the Australian Embassy in Washington and that was done unbeknown to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sure; the same level of friend as Tommy Domican was.
